Self-assigning so I know to track it for mentoring.
Thanks @zystvan for the work! Looks great and makes our secondary panes more consistent.
@wldcordeiro marking this as yours as it's close to your work. it's mostly just blocked...

If it's a shortcut, it's OK to call the string `.key`, but the localization comment should make it clear it's a shortcut.

If it's an accesskey, it should be called `correspondinglabel.accesskey`

::: devtools/client/locales/en-US/debugger.properties
@@ +19,5 @@
> +copySourceUrl=Copy Source Url
> +
> +# LOCALIZATION NOTE (copySourceUrl.key): Access key to copy the source URL of a file from
> +# the context menu.
> +copySourceUrl.key=X
I think @jasonLaster landed this in his recent PR.
@wldcordeiro lets get more context here so that potentially others could work on it as well
I'll be working on this, I'm doing a lot with search so to summarize the "waves"

1. [x] Add search bottom bar to house search modifiers and function search
2. [x] Move function search into search bar
3. [x] Refactor autocomplete and search bar to reuse components and clean up UI/UX
4. [ ] Move state of editor search including modifiers and function searching into redux.

Investigated a bit and the issue seems linked to the fact that the codemirror instance is being destroyed and recreated when the layout is switched.

When it is recreated in components/Editor::componentDidMount, a code mirror document is created on the fly reusing this.props.sourceText. However this document is not tracked by the source-documents.js "store". So at this point, code mirror points to a document that is not handled by the debugger. It would be better to set a valid  debugger document rather than doing this.

On top of that, when a document is opened in CodeMirror, a property "cm" is created on the document object to indicate that this document is linked to the code mirror instance. When we destroy codemirror, we should at least unlink the current document loaded in code mirror.
now fixed

Last update [9bf2ad8...fc607d4](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/compare/9bf2ad8fdb80853faf54a394a14a91b23a7a03a7...fc607d4c1519e458fcee46da53cd6b03d08cd844?el=footer&src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
We fixed the initial concern about search slowing down viewing a source, but we should fix the secondary concern of search being slow in general. This effects opening and closing the search bar as well as updating searches.
The easiest way to test this is to debug a big file and turn on the profiling tools and then hit `<cmd>+f`


```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/editor/source-search.js b/src/utils/editor/source-search.js
index a40f31a..f8b0bae 100644
--- a/src/utils/editor/source-search.js
+++ b/src/utils/editor/source-search.js
@@ -35,6 +35,9 @@ function getSearchState(cm: any, query, modifiers) {

   state.results = [];
   while (cursor.findNext()) {
+    // this is the place i think we're slow...
+    // i bet we can do this in batch or a regex...
+    // also we can lean on CM and do a PR up stream
     state.results.push(cursor.pos);
   }
```
@ryanjduffy thanks for the research. A good test to try this on is the debugger's `bundle.js`, which you can get to by having the debugger opened in firefox. This case does not have many long lines, but is still slow.
@jasonLaster seemed to address this so I'm closing for now. If we find that there's still slowness we can reopen or whatever.
@jasonLaster I thought that while loop looked like it could be problematic. Must be a way to reduce the overhead.
Starting looking at this. At least a portion of the issue is that CodeMirror mutates a lot of DOM nodes when a search is performed. In the profiler, a bulk of the time in FF was spent in styling. Chrome didn't exhibit the same lag on showing the search bar but actually searching was slow in both.
Adding a guard in `toggleSearch()` seems to improve the common case of just starting a search by cmd+f. Doesn't get to the root cause, of course.

```
      if (selection) {
        this.setSearchValue(selection);
        this.doSearch(selection);
      }
```
May need some upstream changes to fix this. CM has a `viewportMargin` property to manage the amount of code rendered at any point in time. Unfortunately, it limits it line and not by width. So, if you have a large, many lined, file, the performance isn't too bad. If you have a large, few lines but very wide (e.g. minified file), you're still out of luck.
Created a rough PR to start some discussion. Seems to improve search bar and search performance on large files but could use some more informed eyes on it!
Thanks @jcreighton!

I wonder if you could do this in CSS?  If you animated (over a second or so) the disappearance of a node you could keep them hanging around while react replaces them.  We just need to ensure that the new thing that replaces the old thing stops the old animation from continuing. 
@tromey flashing is a tough problem we’ve punted on. but I bet we can do something like… not clear the state for half a second and wait to see if we pause again... The tough thing is that darn `resume` event
This should be easier now because we keep track of the fact that we're currently stepping and that we have an action that fires when we finish stepping. With that said, this not currently a priority, so I'll move it to the enhancements board.

If someone is interested in picking it up, I can share some context.
I looked at this a bit today.  Changing the pause reducer and WhyPaused helps; but the Scope pane still flashes, so more work would be required there.

The bigger point here is that this change should depend on the resumption reason: maybe it's ok to keep the panes as-is for a step in/out/over, but a plain resume should probably collapse everything.

Flashing changes in the scope pane (say, when a variable's value changes) should probably be done in a separate bug.
This is very nice. I've a couple of suggestions, but I will send a PR instead of listing them here as it'll be faster! ✌🏼
this looks right @lasfin! I'll test soon
Works great! Thanks so much

Thanks!
@nchevobbe is this a console bug or debugger bug?
Just looked into it again and I think it's an issue with how the source url is represented in the server:

take a look at this [example](https://bad-eval.glitch.me/)

```js
function stuff() {
  console.log("why, hello there!")
  var script = "if(true) {\nundefined()\n}";
  eval(script);
}
```

The log URL is fine, but the eval is not. Notice `%20`... 

<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/7bb0e1822c91dd07e6f275669d58a364/Screen%20Shot%202017-10-17%20at%206.49.59%20PM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-10-17 at 6.49.59 PM.png' width=426>

moving to bugzilla so it can be tracked by the console component:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1409571

Hi @jasonLaster!

Sorry for the late response. I've had a busy week at work.  
But here we go: 

On `onKeyDown` event, there were some chained `if/else` conditions.  
I created the object `keyDownHandlers` which is used by the event handler simplifying the condition chain to this:

```js
keyDownHandlers[e.key] && keyDownHandlers[e.key]
      .call(this, e, searchResults, resultCount);
```

I'd appreciate any thought on this.

Not sure if I've understood this clearly, 
- but by typing "a" in search, we shouldn't be showing any output as "anonymous function" which are assigned to members
- "property" if searched should list / reference to that anonymous fn

@ruturajv We should still have functions output as anonymous. The following situations should be anonymous

```js
(function() {
  console.log("IIFE");
})();
```

```js
const things = [1, 2, 3];
const thingsSqrd = things.map(function(i) { return i * i }); // if this were an arrow function it'd still be anonymous
```

This is only when you have a function that is assigned to a variable so

```js
const doThing = () => console.log("hey");
const doOtherThing = function() { console.log("HI"); };
```

Regarding properties, don't worry, that's a different discussion and already handled in our function searching logic. 😄 

Hope that clarifies.
[I also pushed to devtools-core a new variable]

Take a look and see if you find these sensible:

- **call stack zebra**: The dark theme and light theme need to use exactly the opposite variables. This should ideally be done via better variable construction, but I just did separate selectors for now.
I also added a hover state for dark theme for buttons, accordion headers and frames.

- **pause box**: used a slightly less saturated color and removed the border. It actually applies to all active breakpoint greens, but it almost doesn't show except for the large area pause box.

- **consistency**: I changed the input color to normal body text color. And I actually like the placeholder being more faded than the "No xxx" messages in other sections, since it's really a placeholder and not a message.


I still didn't get to, and have questions on:
- select state (do you mean to change this color throughout the entire UI ?)
- editor highlight (what is that exactly?)
- color contrast

Checking this out locally now...

Great idea!  I've definitely hit this before as well. 
Here are some notes on the existing design.

## Firefox

Main interface for toggling is located at the bottom of the sources list.

<img width="156" alt="black box toggle button" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/23834747/ce7d7fa4-0718-11e7-9ea1-5a43159e9aad.png">

View when a source file is blackboxed

<img width="909" alt="screen shot 2017-03-12 at 11 39 57 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/23834756/f2a01928-0718-11e7-83b1-d7ab51004d38.png">

Auto-blackbox minified sources preference, which defaulted to **on**.

<img width="360" alt="screen shot 2017-03-12 at 11 43 09 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/23834770/18b2adec-0719-11e7-9d37-0aba0f3adf14.png">

## Chrome

Context menu when clicking in the source code editor area

<img width="262" alt="screen shot 2017-03-12 at 11 45 24 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/23834802/a20b455e-0719-11e7-8540-065c26654347.png">

<img width="617" alt="screen shot 2017-03-12 at 11 46 10 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/23834808/b2e17bbe-0719-11e7-9cb0-9aff9fbb8e7e.png">

<img width="615" alt="screen shot 2017-03-12 at 11 46 22 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/23834810/bb6678c0-0719-11e7-80ac-948584b0d9a2.png">

<img width="694" alt="screen shot 2017-03-12 at 11 46 45 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/23834812/c3f56a1e-0719-11e7-956a-65586f44a2a4.png">

> *@jasonLaster* commented on this pull request.

> Thanks. One thought on an interesting implementation question
> ------------------------------
>
> In src/components/shared/menu.js
> <https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2357#discussion_r105664254>
> :
>
> > @@ -14,35 +14,25 @@ function createPopup(doc) {
>      e.returnValue = false;
>    }
>
> -  let mask = document.querySelector("#contextmenu-mask");
> -  if (!mask) {
> -    mask = doc.createElement("div");
> -    mask.id = "contextmenu-mask";
> -    if (document.body) {
> -      document.body.appendChild(mask);
> +  let debuggerWindow = document.getElementsByClassName("debugger")[0];
> +  if (debuggerWindow) {
> +    debuggerWindow.onclick = () => {
> +      if (popup) {
> +        popup.hidePopup();
> +      }
>
> my concern with this approach is that some click handlers will prevent
> propogation so this will not always work.
>
> I think the safer thing to do would be to limit the impact of right
> clicking on a mask so that it doesn't show a context menu.
>
> for instance preventDefault, stop propogation
>

@arthur801031 i dropped the support for saving persisted lines because that is a little bit of a headache at the moment...

I don't think we want to expose codeMirror globally and I'm not sure how we can show breakpoint sources either... One argument for removing this now is that if the line is changed between refreshes our breakpoint line will be out of date or perhaps we'll get the snippet from the selected source, but that is the wrong source...

Either way, we can think through this feature after this lands
Hmm, not sure. Let me know what you find
This is a good way to test the behavior. With that said, I think i prefer the case sensitive approach.


```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/tests/sources-tree.js b/src/utils/tests/sources-tree.js
index 568cb34..76cb1f3 100644
--- a/src/utils/tests/sources-tree.js
+++ b/src/utils/tests/sources-tree.js
@@ -10,6 +10,12 @@ describe("sources-tree", () => {
     url: "http://example.com/a/b/c.js",
     actor: "actor1"
   });
+
+  const aBcSource2 = Map({
+    url: "http://example.com/a/B/c2.js",
+    actor: "actor1"
+  });
+
   const abcdeSource = Map({
     url: "http://example.com/a/b/c/d/e.js",
     actor: "actor2"
@@ -223,6 +229,33 @@ describe("sources-tree", () => {
     expect(abcNode.path).to.be("/example.com/a/b/c.js");
   });

+  it("can collapse a single source", () => {
+    const fullTree = createNode("root", "", []);
+    addToTree(fullTree, abcSource, aBcSource2);
+    expect(fullTree.contents.length).to.be(1);
+    const tree = collapseTree(fullTree);
+
+    const host = tree.contents[0];
+    expect(host.name).to.be("example.com");
+    expect(host.contents.length).to.be(1);
+
+    const abFolder = host.contents[0];
+    expect(abFolder.name).to.be("a/b");
+    expect(abFolder.contents.length).to.be(1);
+
+    const abcNode = abFolder.contents[0];
+    expect(abcNode.name).to.be("c.js");
+    expect(abcNode.path).to.be("/example.com/a/b/c.js");
+
+    const abFolder = host.contents[1];
+    expect(abFolder.name).to.be("a/b");
+    expect(abFolder.contents.length).to.be(1);
+
+    const abcNode = abFolder.contents[1];
+    expect(abcNode.name).to.be("c2.js");
+    expect(abcNode.path).to.be("/example.com/a/b/c.js");
+  });
+
```
I think this is the correct behavior because the server could treat `/a/b/c` differently from `a/B/C`
This is a good idea, we kind of do this already too with countMatches.

I invested a little more.  When the component is mount `CodeMirror-linewidget` width is calculated and `CodeMirror-sizer` too.

I started on this idea:

I propose to remove the function wich calculates the width of `CodeMirror-linewidget`. 

So `CodeMirror-linewidget` depends to the width of `CodeMirror-sizer`.

We just need to add a function to resize `CodeMirror-sizer` when the editor resizes

Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
Would be best if you could defer the line calculation until it was needed to scroll it into view. Otherwise, you have to no only find the string but also derive the line number. You could incrementally sort it out (e.g. count the line for the first match, cache it, count the lines from the first match to the second match and sum it to the cached value, etc) but it's likely a lot of wasted effort since in most cases the user doesn't need every match.
watchout for the rebase

@jasonLaster - is the screenshot a mock ? cause when I created a simple HTML
```html
<html>
	<head>
		<title>Function References</title>
	</head>
	<body>
<script type="text/javascript">
(function() {
  console.log("IIFE");
})();

const things = [1, 2, 3];
// if this were an arrow function it'd still be anonymous
const thingsSqrd = things.map(function(i) { return i * i });

const doThing = () => console.log("hey");
const doOtherThing = function() { console.log("HI"); };

function commonFunction() {
  console.log("I just relax...");
}
</script>
	</body>
</html>
```

and tried to search `commonFunction` or `anon`, It didn't find anything.
![search](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/227817/23936763/dcae7d9a-0979-11e7-8501-e1fcd940adaf.png)


Can you try with .html as well as .php? I'm not sure if we are treating php files as sources like we do html.

![html-debug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/227817/23938118/fb649416-0980-11e7-8797-947411622ebd.png)

I didn't get a chance to test it yet but it might be possible to do something kind of like this to achieve what you suggested @jasonLaster not sure how it performs versus what @ryanjduffy suggested.

```js
sourceText
  .split(/\\r?\\n/)
  .reduce((acc, line) => {
    acc.push(query // query being the regexp object we return from buildQuery
      .exec(line)
      .filter(l => l) // Remove the nulls from those that don't match.
      .map(...)); // format like codemirror's returns.
    return acc;
  });
```
Thanks for finding this :mag:
Here's the location grip. The issue with `href`, `hostname` and other default properties is that they have a getter and setter and not the value.

```json

  "ownProperties": {
    "href": {

      "configurable": false,
      "enumerable": true,
      "writable": false,
      "value": {
        "type": "object",
        "actor": "server2.conn1.child1/obj62",
        "class": "Function",
        "extensible": true,
        "frozen": false,
        "sealed": false,
        "name": "toString",
        "displayName": "toString"
      }
    },
    "valueOf": {
      "configurable": false,
      "enumerable": true,
      "writable": false,
      "value": {
        "type": "object",
        "actor": "server2.conn1.child1/obj63",
        "class": "Function",
        "extensible": true,
        "frozen": false,
        "sealed": false,
        "name": "valueOf",
        "displayName": "valueOf"
      }
    },
    "toJSON": {
      "configurable": false,
      "enumerable": true,
      "writable": false,
      "value": {
        "type": "undefined"
      }
    }
  },
  "prototype": {
    "type": "object",
    "actor": "server2.conn1.child1/obj64",
    "class": "LocationPrototype",
    "extensible": true,
    "frozen": false,
    "sealed": false,
    "ownPropertyLength": 1,
    "preview": {
      "kind": "Object",
      "ownProperties": {},
      "ownPropertiesLength": 1,
      "safeGetterValues": {}
    }
  },
  "ownSymbols": []
}
```
When I try to `parse(pathPart)` I'd get a `null` for the host because the URL parsing expects a protocol but `pathPart` is usually just `www.example.com`
Here's a patch for the utils/editor https://gist.github.com/jasonLaster/6bce4fefe93f0f03dd2dd8930c6646ed
ahh - i see. In that case, we can do something simpler :)
I can work on cleaning up the css

Hmm I think you're running into #2378.
Correct me if I'm wrong but shouldn't we always have one source? The document itself? Or should we only show the document if we detect script tags in it? I'm confused. It seems like the bug is that in certain cases we aren't including the document as a source.
I started on this using a variation of @wldcordeiro's suggestion. Initial search seemed to be faster with my rough algorithm but I was surprised when my naive 'only find the first instance in the line' approach succeeded in finding every instance in the line. Since that clearly couldn't have been the case, I discovered that the loop code in `getSearchState()` seems to be unnecessary as the incremental search in `doSearch()` and `searchNext` work fine without it.
@ryanjduffy Do you have a public branch or a patch you could share? I could test it out too.  😄 
It can't depend upon the width of `CodeMirror-sizer` because that node reflects the width of the content and not that of the viewport. The result would be a regression of #2287 in which the close button would be hidden for long lines again.
Wrote up a *very* rough approach that adds an `onResize` callback to `Splitbox` from `devtools-modules` which, when called in the app, updates the ui state in redux with a fake "size" to trigger an update of the editor and thereby a `setSize()` on the CodeMirror.

Not sure if/when I'll be able to polish it up so sharing here in case someone else wants to take the torch.

```diff

--- a/src/actions/ui.js
+++ b/src/actions/ui.js
@@ -37,9 +37,17 @@ function togglePaneCollapse(position: string, paneCollapsed: boolean) {
   };
 }
 
+function editorResized () {
+  return {
+    type: "EDITOR_RESIZED",
+    size: window.performance.now()
+  };
+}
+
 module.exports = {
   toggleFileSearch,
   closeFileSearch,
+  editorResized,
   showSource,
   togglePaneCollapse
 };
```

Also added the following to `onStopMove` in `Splitbox`

```
    if (this.props.onResize) {
      const { vert, height, width } = this.state;
      this.props.onResize({
        size: vert ? height : width
      });
    }
```
I don't have much to share. I'm not even convinced my search logic is valid since it seems to be superseded by the code in `doSearch()`. You can test my theory by commenting out lines 36-43 in `source-search.js`.
It only shows scripts, like the old Firefox debugger. You can take a look at issue #2231
Hi sorry for the incomplete comments.

Navigation buttons in the search bar:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3506479/23985994/97d1ab82-0a2a-11e7-97f4-1031964412ef.png)

Basic behavior: 
- Appears only when there are more than 1 search result.
- Loop through the result (the only indication for first or last record is in the text next to the buttons) 

Created 2 new SVG's for the Arrows, so you might want to use your own svg library.

There is one thing that need to update about this feature is the indication of user selection. I tried to give a nice click feedback by increasing the Fill color (I used the --theme-comment, but there isn't darker theme color).
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3506479/23986251/e5dd0366-0a2b-11e7-9151-f89e2de6132f.png)

There is an enhancement that might be cool, that when you use the keyboard shortcut the matching button will be activated, what do you think?
Another thing the buttons jumps a little base on the summary result, might be better to use absolute position. 

There is one comment, it looks like the close button is disabled, it uses the --theme-comment-alt maybe this should also be changed.




> Another thing the buttons jumps a little base on the summary result, might be better to use absolute position.

I think the containing element of the button needs to have `flex-shrink: 0;` to avoid resizing with the summary changes.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5119937/23986930/658509b2-0a2f-11e7-9937-dcc4fdb8595e.png)

```diff
+++ b/src/components/Editor/index.js

     // We only want to do the flashing animation if it's not a debug
     // line, which has it's own styling.
+    // Also, if it the first time the debugger is being loaded, we don't want
+    // to flash the previously saved selected line.
     if (
-      !this.props.selectedFrame ||
-      this.props.selectedFrame.location.line !== line
+      this.lastJumpLine &&
+      (!this.props.selectedFrame ||
+      this.props.selectedFrame.location.line !== line)
     ) {
       this.editor.codeMirror.addLineClass(line - 1, "line", "highlight-line");
     }
```

@yuliaSharabi from what I understand, `autoprefixer` can add most vendor prefix which have equivalent in other browser like `-webkit-transition` and `-moz-transition` but `-moz-focus-inner` doesn't appear to have equivalent in other browsers and is firefox specific.

Here are some examples from chrome:

### Callee

```js
let to = cm.lineAtHeight(cm.getWrapperElement().clientHeight, "page");
```

### Promises

```js
return Promise.all(
  frames.map(frame => {
    return getOriginalLocation(frame.location).then(loc => {
      return Object.assign(frame, {
        location: loc,
      });
    });
  }),
);
```

One good option here is to check the context type before we try to parse the code and if it is not parseable a.k.a HTML we should not try. In these cases we should hide the "Search For" container

Ok so it looks like we can't prettify Big files and so the `.editor-mount` has been set to 100% for these big files. by doing that it hasn't taken the search bar into concideration and when that is opened it pushes everything down resulting in everything being pushed off screen.

Hey @wldcordeiro this issue has become kinda vague.

- "go to line" is a fun feature, but probably a separate issue
- I would guess we should remove "class" search for now and perhaps find a home for it later
- icons for types of symbols is a good idea, but I think we should wait for a designer
- wildcards is a good idea. we should file an issue for that.
Yep - i'm seeing that too. 

By the way, there are two cases here. 
1. Opening the pane via the context menu and 
2. Opening the pane via the cmd+b
Cool!
1.  Can you provide more detail?  Is this via the UI or from console or local dev?

2.  There's something in the Chrome UX that doesn't feel quite right.  

-  One difficult problem is that you need to add a breakpoint to a line before you even know you can add "sub breakpoints" on individual statements on that line, so I'd likely have never noticed this feature.  

-  I do like that the background color is shaded up until the sub-breakpoint to show progress; I like that a lot.  

-  The number of sub-breakpoints in a single statement is ... a lot.  Maybe a `title` attribute over each breakpoint could help clarify what's going on (?).  

-  Sub-breakpoint might look better in light grey to cut down on noise.

Overall the functionality is nice but discoverability and usability seem the top issues.
Good feedback!

1. I added it by pausing in the `addBreakpoint` function and setting the column value in the console :)

2.  Chrome UX

> One difficult problem is that you need to add a breakpoint to a line before you even know you can add "sub breakpoints".

I agree. That does feel awkward. I've thought that it would be nice to enter a "column" bp mode where you can click on tokens and add a breakpoint. For example, hold down "alt" and click somewhere on `this.render`. It's also possible to enter column breakpoint mode by clicking an icon in the footer.

> The number of sub-breakpoints in a single statement is ... a lot

I agree. I feel like that behavior adds a lot of noise and we should be able to teach users where they can click.

The breakpoint location also seems important. Chrome has a case where the breakpoint is inside a member expression `Object. > assign(` and I would think you'd want it to be on the outside `> Object.assign(`.


Awesome! I'll give this some further testing but seeing this makes me really happy! 🙌 
@jasonLaster 

> "go to line" is a fun feature, but probably a separate issue

Agreed, I think that would be an issue of its own.

> I would guess we should remove "class" search for now and perhaps find a home for it later

Yeah not really super useful, could just merge into variables as it's a form of declaration. 

> icons for types of symbols is a good idea, but I think we should wait for a designer

Probably for the best.

> wildcards is a good idea. we should file an issue for that.

Agreed
This is a duplicate of #2427

- the breakpoint marker lost the line number
- the fold marker needs padding and a lighter color
- the code fold gutter column seems to wide

1. fold markers are hidden except when hovering over the gutter

3. the fold inline badge is really nice

Hey Bryan, thanks for the PR. The first thing that caught my eye was that you can export individual functions instead of using one big export default. See https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/3e86312a46a0e37450785b27a90224be647a58da/src/utils/editor/expression.js#L7
https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/3e86312a46a0e37450785b27a90224be647a58da/src/components/App.js#L22-L26

Also, default exports from ES modules require this `.default` at the end of the requires. Check out the example above.

Closing this as already-fixed. There is a octagonal pause button that is for pausing on all exceptions. See this screenshot, https://pageshot.net/images/de18e141-16e5-4902-a132-e250369c7775.png
Looks good, contributors in the future can tell what's required, and provides more stability.
Here's what I'd recommend as an MVP of this feature.  I think we can go well beyond this recommendation later but here's the starting point.

The main interaction point is a context menu in the Sources Tree.  This menu item allows to turn on and off the black boxing of a single script.  Sources which are currently black boxed should probably have some indicator such as the eye icon instead of the normal file icon... not sure.

The editor will indicate when the current script is black boxed.  The current system hides the entire editor area, this might be a nice solution as it would prevent users from adding breakpoints which will be ignored.  I'm offering a small indicator at the bottom of the editor as a starting point.

### Blackbox Script

For a script which isn't already blackboxed there should be an option to turn on blackboxing for it.

This text should read `Blackbox Script` which turns on blackboxing for this script.

<img width="279" alt="screen shot 2017-03-29 at 11 43 34 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/24466354/339eef2a-1476-11e7-9586-dee259fa3185.png">

### Un-Blackbox Script

For a script which is already blackboxed there should exist a menu item for turning blackboxing off for it.

<img width="347" alt="screen shot 2017-03-29 at 11 51 54 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/24466399/5ff6c782-1476-11e7-80a4-48e9dccd7497.png">

### Is Blackboxed

For a script which is blackboxed there should be an indicator in the Editor.  This indicator could also act as a button to "Un-Blackbox Script".  Colors here should not be continued, only used as an example.

<img width="923" alt="screen shot 2017-03-29 at 11 48 08 am" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2134/24466478/a1220546-1476-11e7-9fb1-04800f08eff6.png">

Hmm, why do we need this? :)
> Hmm, why do we need this? :)

@AnshulMalik is working on this
It would be nice to have some kind of indicator in the file tree.
one option


```diff
diff --git a/src/components/App.js b/src/components/App.js
index 3d4e53d..6c2d1db 100644
--- a/src/components/App.js
+++ b/src/components/App.js
@@ -79,6 +79,12 @@ class App extends Component {
     const { horizontal } = this.state;

     const overflowX = endPanelCollapsed ? "hidden" : "auto";
+    const onResize = (panel, size) => {
+      if (panel == "start") {
+        this.setState({startPanelSize: size})
+      }
+      this.setState({endPanelSize: size})
+    }

     return dom.div(
       { className: "debugger" },
@@ -88,6 +94,7 @@ class App extends Component {
         minSize: 10,
         maxSize: "50%",
         splitterSize: 1,
+        onResize,
         startPanel: Sources({ sources, horizontal }),
         startPanelCollapsed,
         endPanel: SplitBox({
@@ -96,6 +103,7 @@ class App extends Component {

           maxSize: "80%",
           splitterSize: 1,
+          onResize,
           endPanelControl: true,
           startPanel: this.renderEditorPane(),
           endPanel: SecondaryPanes({ horizontal }),
```
another option would use child context for splitter, which would be similar to how App uses context [here](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/components/App.js#L46-L49). Except, children of splitter who care would listen to a panelSize context item...
Also, next to "Black Boxed", I would add "Un-black box ?" as a blue link
We could simply strike through the text in the source tree.

Thanks for filing @tommai78101.

We're somewhat limited by what codemirror offers us here. They're generally pretty good, but I know that there are cases where it is dissappointing.

I think the user has three options:

1. scroll with the trackpad
2. prettify 
3. copy to their favorite editor and search their... 

This is ultimately a pretty difficult UX problem that we're not equipped to handle well at the moment as we're still tackling some pretty fundamental pieces like Preview and Search.

Hi @jasonLaster 

The expanded properties would not be updated while stepping is because we're getting the properties from the cache actor instead of the current item's properties. The solution that I got fixes this issue but there is one drawback: we're not actually updating the cache actor; instead, we modify the cache actor locally and return this object to [getChildren](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/components/shared/ObjectInspector.js#L126).

Please let me know if there is a better way to tackle this issue. 😄
No pressure :) thanks !
Nice!
Looking good!

Here's an approach I think would work

```diff
diff --git a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
index 7b139e5..baaa6ae 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
@@ -253,10 +253,20 @@ class SourceTabs extends Component {
       return;
     }

-    const sourceTabs = this.props.sourceTabs;
+    const { sourceTabs, selectedSource } = this.props;
     const sourceTabEls = this.refs.sourceTabs.children;
     const hiddenSourceTabs = getHiddenTabs(sourceTabs, sourceTabEls);

+    // if the selectedSource is in the hidden tabs list
+    // then figure out how to show it in the list of tabs
+    // naively, find the last shown tab and place it before that tab
+    // the challenge is if the selected source is wider than that tab.
+    // in that case we need to try placing it befor the next available tab
+
+    // when we find the location to place the tab
+    // we should fire a new action (updateSourceTabs), which will set the
+    // new tabs list in the redux store
+
     this.setState({ hiddenSourceTabs });
   }
```
I have uploaded a patch in [bug 1338582](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1338582) that creates a simple `PausedDebuggerOverlay`.
I've added [instructions](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1338582#c4) on how to use this from the debugger too.

The overlay only displays a message for now.

We need to figure out how to make the step/resume buttons work. Either clicking on them could emit an event that the toolbox would get, or the overlay could itself tell the script actor to step/resume, but that would require the debugger front-end to know what that happens and put itself in the right state as a result.

I'll think about that some more.
The tests are failing now, as expected. I'll land this so they report correctly. @jasonLaster is working on fixing them up in #2508.

1. Context menu for adding / removing
2. Indicator in Source Tree and Editor of `isBlackboxed` (Editor could be hidden like the old debugger)
3. (Stretch Goal) Better Editor integration by showing the editor but preventing users from creating breakpoints 

And we should open up a separate issue for discussing what we'd really like to see in the full version of Blackboxing.

After looking into the problem it turn out that there was another bug

### STR
1. Open TodoMVC example in browser
2. Open `js/views/app-view.js` file in debugger.html
3. Open function search in editor and enter `a`.
4. Navigate to lower result by pressing `down` arrow key a few times
5. Now enter `a` in function search to narrow the result
![Bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1755089/24619913/57f42aec-18b9-11e7-9b2b-e8ecc577bcee.gif)

This problem was because we are trying to scroll to result that don't exist anymore.
Is this a dupe #2524?

Hi @bomsy and @jasonLaster 

I've reverted to previous implementation where the code logic for detecting/updating `actors` is in `shared/ObjectInspector.js`. This has 2 benefits:
1. I think this implementation is more reliable than the one that was in `src/utils/object-inspector.js` because I had to use multiple `if conditions` to avoid setting function objects.
2. We can update `actors` in `shared/ObjectInspector.js`, but we can't do that in `src/utils/object-inspector.js`.

To @bomsy: 
I'm not sure if we can know when component loads (i.e during stepping) or internal components being render. What we have right now checks whether or not `actors` goes stale. If it does, we update `actors`.

Thanks.  That fixed up the first issue.  Now FF launches OK.  But I don't
see anything "interesting" in the web page after FF launches.  Maybe I am
doing something wrong?

now; did not see them earlier today.  Maybe I messed up my install?

I wonder, if we should use some [debounce function](https://davidwalsh.name/javascript-debounce-function) and completely ignore taking the user to exact line on the editor. For such an idle "hold down/up arrow" the user is probably just interested in the list and not see the position in the file.

@jasonLaster I'm pushing some changes that fix the regressions now.

Some notes on the enhancements though...


> fold markers are hidden except when hovering over the gutter

I'm not sure this is easily doable, the gutter in CodeMirror is weird in that the background is one element `.CodeMirror-gutters` and the actual content of the gutter is within a completely different adjacent element (maybe a very specific selector heh?)
 
> active markers are orange and always visible

I like the idea of some kind of highlight for the active marker. 👍
 
> the fold inline badge is really nice

I do like their badge, it is pretty nice looking compared to the one we inherited from `codemirror-mozilla.css`

A bit of testing around and I got this patch. It seems to do what we want but may have some edge-cases I didn't adjust for.

```patch
index d1b8dbdf..27bf3001 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
@@ -428,6 +428,12 @@ const SearchBar = React.createClass({
   },

   onKeyUp(e: SyntheticKeyboardEvent) {
+    const { symbolSearchResults, selectedResultIndex } = this.state;
+    if (this.state.symbolSearchEnabled) {
+      this.onSelectResultItem(symbolSearchResults[selectedResultIndex]);
+      e.preventDefault();
+    }
+
     if (e.key != "Enter") {
       return;
     }
@@ -449,7 +455,6 @@ const SearchBar = React.createClass({
         this.state.selectedResultIndex - 1
       );
       this.setState({ selectedResultIndex });
-      this.onSelectResultItem(searchResults[selectedResultIndex]);
       e.preventDefault();
     } else if (e.key === "ArrowDown") {
       const selectedResultIndex = Math.min(
@@ -457,7 +462,6 @@ const SearchBar = React.createClass({
         this.state.selectedResultIndex + 1
       );
       this.setState({ selectedResultIndex });
-      this.onSelectResultItem(searchResults[selectedResultIndex]);
       e.preventDefault();
     } else if (e.key === "Enter") {
       if (searchResults.length) {
```
The jank is just not due to scrolling the editor in View. I disabled that (as @wldcordeiro  had suggested). Commented out `this.onSelectResultItem(searchResults[selectedResultIndex]);`

Yet it was present when just simply holding "downArrow" and navigating through the list. Probably there is more to this jank !  :(
Wow that looks great, thanks for adding this and all your work to make it so nice 
Hmm, I got some design help earlier in the week and I think it would be nice to move the function and symbol search to a modal (command palette) similar to Atom and VS Code. 

https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/editingevolved#_go-to-symbol

There are a couple of reasons for this:

1. The modal is task oriented, find and select an item
2. it doesn't push the editor down
3. it's a convention with other editors
4. we can start adding other commands to the command palette 

I'm going to close this issue as I don't think we should act on this now. What do you think @wldcordeiro @ruturajv?




Hmm, my guess is that it has something to do with this line:

this does not fix it though
```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/result-list.js b/src/utils/result-list.js
index 854009d..c31e03b 100644
--- a/src/utils/result-list.js
+++ b/src/utils/result-list.js
@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@ function scrollList(resultList, index) {
   const resultEl = resultList[index];

   if (isFirefox()) {
-    resultEl.scrollIntoView({ block: "end", behavior: "smooth" });
+    resultEl.scrollIntoView({ block: "end" });
   } else {
     chromeScrollList(resultEl, index);
   }
```

Function search on Windows should be `ctrl+shift+O`  does that work?
I think function search is using the `symbolSearch.search.key` I'm not sure where `functionSearch.search.key` is used.
`ctrl+shift+o` works in 55.0a1 where it overrides the same shortcut for opening the toolbox options (the latter ones get opened in 54.0a2). Please add the key modifiers to the localization comments in the future.

@jbhoosreddy are you still getting to this?

@jbhoosreddy taking your head off it because it's been some time
So, debugger-html does use the menu component in some places, but https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/components/shared/Dropdown.js still doesn't use the menu component.
Thanks for filing @nt1m. 

This conversation would probably be better in IRC or [slack](https://devtools-html-slack.herokuapp.com) where we can discuss individual components: 

* Menu - is shared in [modules](https://github.com/devtools-html/devtools-core/blob/master/packages/devtools-modules/client/framework/menu.js#L1). I think dropdown is a different enough UI that we would not want to use the context menu.
* Tree - is shared in [modules](https://github.com/devtools-html/devtools-core/blob/master/packages/devtools-modules/client/shared/components/tree.js#L1) 
* HTMLTooltip is a component I'm not sure if we want to share at the moment. It is not React, which is important.
* Tabs - are now in [modules](https://github.com/devtools-html/devtools-core/blob/master/packages/devtools-modules/client/shared/components/tabs/tabbar.js#L1) so that the netmonitor can use them. I'm not sure if we would want to use the Tab bar, but our UI for the editor is very complex so I would expect this to be a decent amount of work.

I'm interested in working on a set of shared components, but I think we should figure this out on a case by case basis.

One example of a component that we'd like to share is the Splitter, which is now in it's own package so it can be well maintained.

We are using storybook here to work on it in isolation and would like to have additional examples and testing as well.

https://github.com/devtools-html/devtools-core/tree/master/packages/devtools-splitter

Hmm, @captainbrosset I'm beginning to reconsider the decision to move the debugger properties file:

1. there is already a [properties file][file] in shared that will need to be merged 
2. there are other components that rely on [client/debugger.properties][search] such as variables view and the old debugger
3. I'm not sure what the localization overhead of moving locale files is

perhaps we add a simple string in the overlay like "Paused in the debugger" and work on extracting shared pause reasons at a later point?


[file]: http://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/shared/locales/en-US/debugger.properties
[search]: http://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/search?q=debugger.properties&case=true&path=
> there is already a properties file in shared that will need to be merged

Yeah, I saw that, I thought maybe we could merge the 2 files and it wouldn't be a big deal.

> there are other components that rely on client/debugger.properties such as variables view and the old debugger

Right, I didn't know that. I suspect it would be enouhg to just change all instances of `devtools/client/locales/debugger.properties` with `devtools/shared/locales/debugger.properties` though.

> I'm not sure what the localization overhead of moving locale files is

I have no idea. That's a good point. I think localization might have to be redone entirely because of that. Of course if we tell localizers that it's just a file move, they might be able to just copy translations across. But that point makes the whole idea much more complex indeed.

So, although I think 1 and 2 are simple enough to fix, I agree that 3 is unknown and might take time. So I'll add just a simple string for now in the shared locale and add a TODO in the code so we can do this later. Works for me!

Thanks for taking a look at that!
Thanks for the quick reply. I'll close this for now and we can re-open it later
This is now fixed thanks to @arthur801031's work persisting breakpoints!

Making progress on this ...
My current approach is to do it all on the server-side, so I might not make any change to the debugger.html code for this. At least for now.

I will need someone who knows the ThreadActor code to tell me if that's ok though, but I still need some more time before that. One thing that doesn't work yet is pause on exceptions. I'll work on that next.

Hmm, after thinking about it a bit more I can see a couple of problems with this approach:

1. keys are often **not** ordered alphabetically. 
2. keys can be numerical
3. keys can be prefixed with an underscore...

I'm now leaning towards not bucketing object properties and only bucketing arrays

Hi @LeslieMurphy, could you join our [slack](https://devtools-html-slack.herokuapp.com) so we can look into this? 
I started looking into this a bit more and it looks like the old debugger handled getters and setters pretty [well][1].

The basic approach as I understand it is that when they encountered a property that only had a getter, they would evaluate some code that created a new property that reflected the value. This strategy was called `getterOrSetterEvalMacro`.

[1]: http://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/client/shared/widgets/VariablesView.jsm#1134
What i shared earlier is relevant when you want to edit a getter, which is  a feature the old debugger supported.

Here's the [codepath][1] that the old debugger used for adding the getter values. What I like about it is that it is much cleaner than fetching each value for the getter.

Here is a simplified response object for the variable `location`. Notice how `href` and `origin` are both `ownProperties` and have entries in `safeGetterValues`. 


```json
{
  "from": "server2.conn2.child1/obj45",
  "prototype": {
    "type": "object",
    "actor": "server2.conn2.child1/obj68",
    "class": "LocationPrototype",
    "extensible": true,
    "frozen": false,
    "sealed": false,
    "ownPropertyLength": 1,
    "preview": {
      "kind": "Object",
      "ownProperties": {},
      "ownPropertiesLength": 1,
      "safeGetterValues": {}
    }
  },
  "ownProperties": {
    "href": {
      "configurable": false,
      "enumerable": true,
      "get": {
        "type": "object",
        "actor": "server2.conn2.child1/obj46",
        "class": "Function",
        "extensible": true,
        "frozen": false,
        "sealed": false,
        "name": "get href",
        "displayName": "get href"
      },
      "set": {
        "type": "object",
        "actor": "server2.conn2.child1/obj47",
        "class": "Function",
        "extensible": true,
        "frozen": false,
        "sealed": false,
        "name": "set href",
        "displayName": "set href"
      }
    },
    "origin": {
      "configurable": false,
      "enumerable": true,
      "get": {
        "type": "object",
        "actor": "server2.conn2.child1/obj48",
        "class": "Function",
        "extensible": true,
        "frozen": false,
        "sealed": false,
        "name": "get origin",
        "displayName": "get origin"
      },
      "set": {
        "type": "undefined"
      }
    }
  },
  "safeGetterValues": {
    "href": {
      "getterValue": "https://devtools-html.github.io/debugger-examples/examples/todomvc/",
      "getterPrototypeLevel": 0,
      "enumerable": true
    },
    "origin": {
      "getterValue": "https://devtools-html.github.io",
      "getterPrototypeLevel": 0,
      "enumerable": true
    }
  }
}
```


We can update our `getProperties` code to do something similar to the old debugger:

```diff
diff --git a/src/client/firefox/commands.js b/src/client/firefox/commands.js
index 8589e8e..71c5195 100644
--- a/src/client/firefox/commands.js
+++ b/src/client/firefox/commands.js
@@ -178,6 +178,18 @@ function getProperties(grip: Grip): Promise<*> {
   const objClient = threadClient.pauseGrip(grip);

   return objClient.getPrototypeAndProperties().then(resp => {
+    const { ownProperties, safeGetterValues } = resp;
+
+    for (let name in safeGetterValues) {
+      if (name in ownProperties) {
+        let { getterValue, getterPrototypeLevel } = safeGetterValues[name];
+        ownProperties[name].getterValue = getterValue;
+        ownProperties[name].getterPrototypeLevel = getterPrototypeLevel;
+      } else {
+        ownProperties[name] = safeGetterValues[name];
+      }
+    }
+
     return resp;
   });
 }
```

We might also need to update `ObjectInspector` to show the getter value, but it's also possible that it will just work.

[1]: http://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/client/shared/widgets/VariablesViewController.jsm#389-408
I think we could do something where you hide the fold markers by default and only show them if the gutter is hovered `gutter::hover .fold-marker { display: block } ` if that doesn't work, on gutter hover we add a class the the fold marker parent element...
![paused-screen](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1152698/24818074/5643f80c-1bdf-11e7-86ad-d74bb8f2d8ca.gif)

Making progress on this ...
My current approach is to do it all on the server-side, so I might not make any change to the debugger.html code for this. At least for now.

I will need someone who knows the ThreadActor code to tell me if that's ok though, but I still need some more time before that. One thing that doesn't work yet is pause on exceptions. I'll work on that next.
@jasonLaster Only for the new debugger.

Can we do something like this ?
```diff
diff --git a/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js b/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
index b16ee37..4ffde22 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
@@ -473,7 +473,13 @@ class SearchBar extends Component {
   }
 
   async onChange(e: any) {
-    return this.doSearch(e.target.value);
+    let query = e.target.value;
+
+    if (query[0] == "@") {
+      query = query.slice(1);
+      this.toggleSymbolSearch(e, { toggle: false, searchType: "functions" });
+    }
+    return this.doSearch(query);
   }
 
   onKeyUp(e: SyntheticKeyboardEvent) {
```

@jasonLaster and I discussed about this issue and decided to hide the `Reveal in Tree` menu item for pretty-printed tabs since there is no appropriate fix at this moment. 

The cause of this issue is that there is no pretty-printed source in the `sourceTree`, so [findSource](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/utils/sources-tree.js#L369) returns null and it cannot find a source to reveal.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2622?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [a849101...66d9eb0](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2622?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
Tried something for testing react components, this method uses enzyme to make testing react components less painful

```
import { createFactory } from "react";
import { shallow } from "enzyme";
import Close from "../../components/shared/Button/Close";

const CloseButton = createFactory(Close);

describe("CloseButton", () => {
  it("should call handleClick function", () => {
    const onClick = jest.genMockFunction();
    const wrapper = shallow(new CloseButton({ handleClick: onClick }));

    wrapper.find(".close-btn").simulate("click");

    expect(onClick).toBeCalled();
  });
});
```

blackboxing works with breakpoints, just not pause on next execution. that's fine
Lgtm
Got creative:

```javascript
let subtractions = [];

if (shouldShowFooter(selectedSource, horizontal)) {
  subtractions.push(cssVars.footerHeight);
}

if (searchOn) {
  subtractions.push(cssVars.searchbarHeight, cssVars.secondSearchbarHeight);
}

return {
  height: subtractions.length === 0
    ? "100%"
    : `calc(100% - ${subtractions.join(" - ")})`
};
```

```
Time:        1.089s
Ran all test suites matching "src/components".
  console.error ../node_modules/enzyme/build/react-compat.js:131
    react-addons-test-utils is an implicit dependency in order to support react@0.13-14. Please add the appropriate version to your devDependencies. See https://github.com/airbnb/enzyme#installation
```

This is exactly the kind of test I would like to see in the codebase

perhaps we render and simulate with reacts renderer's https://facebook.github.io/react/docs/test-utils.html

We should PR this style and also the fixture style!

React also recommends the use of Enzyme. It   requires `react-addon-test-utils` package to be installed manually.

Also enzyme requires react-dom v15
4.2, we have 15.3.2. And upgrading it breaks the existing test cases. So need to find some workaround.

@jasonLaster Enzyme also has functionality to test against snapshot. So we test and save it's state and next time use it to check if something has changed.

# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2633?src=pr&el=h1) Report

lets also get a unit test in there
One interesting thing to note is that we are currently duplicating our tests:
1. Web Test Runner: [test/integration](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/test/integration/tests/scopes.js#L51)
2. Mochitests: [test/mochitest](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/test/mochitest/browser_dbg-scopes.js)

The WTR test for scopes tests expanding nodes, while the mochitest does not. It would be nice if we updated this so the two tests are the same.

The [docs] describe running the WTR tests.

[docs]: https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/docs/local-development.md#integration-tests

I updated the scopes tests [here](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2635) hopefully this will land today so that you can have consistent tests to work with.

https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/commit/2c22306d9d9c4680bd48375fa80c5e7f531cbc1e

Will continue looking into it

Also important to note it happens in both Chrome and Firefox, so it's not isolated to the Chrome or Firefox files.
Here is the start of a test

```js
const {
  initDebugger,
  reload,
  selectSource,
  waitForDispatch
} = require("../utils");

function countTabs(dbg) {
  return dbg.selectors.getSourceTabs(dbg.getState()).size
}

module.exports = async function(ctx) {
  const { ok, is, info, requestLongerTimeout } = ctx;

  const dbg = await initDebugger("doc-scripts.html");


  selectSource(dbg, "simple1");
  selectSource(dbg, "simple2");

  expect(countTabs(dbg)).to.equal(2);

  await reload(dbg);
  expect(countTabs(dbg)).to.equal(2);
};

```
Here's a test. Notice the index comes second:
https://gist.github.com/jasonLaster/99fb7bd80f5537358a934f0ece63f0dc

```js
  it.only("foo", () => {
    const sources = [
      "https://davidwalsh.name/wp-content/prism.js",
      "https://davidwalsh.name/"
    ];
    const sourceList = createSourcesList(sources);
    const tree = createTree(sourceList, "");
    console.log(tree.sourceTree);
    // console.log("second", tree.sourceTree.contents[1]);
  });

```


Here's the failure:

```
    { name: 'root',
      path: '',
      contents:
       [ { name: 'davidwalsh.name',
           path: '/davidwalsh.name',
           contents: [Object] },
         { name: 'davidwalsh.name',
           path: '/davidwalsh.name',
           contents: [Object] } ] }
```

Notice two directories `'/davidwalsh.name'` `'/davidwalsh.name'`. This does not happen if the index comes second.

I can't reproduce this issue, works fine here.

Hey @magsout I'm making this issue available again. Feel free to reclaim it if you have time.
Hey @roieu, how's it going?

It seems like this work might be blocked on a notion of "blurred". Feel free to hop in slack and chat about it. 

> Yes. Looks like using just CSS to "hide all fold markers unless hovering on gutter" may not work because of their placement in DOM tree and limitation of CSS selectors.(I might be wrong here

@irfanhudda I was trying to do this as well, it's complicated. The "gutter" itself lives at a different level in the tree than the markers. I think there  is likely some really specific CSS selector like (pseudo selectors here) `.gutter:hover ~ .gutter-elems .hover-marker`. If you find a good solution I'd love to see it! 😄 
We've got some demos of the debugger running in Emacs and could do the same with Atom.

We haven't done much on this front, but have designed the APIs so you could either drop it in and connect to node or a browser with our Redux backend or use our utils or UI.

Stop by our slack and we can discuss!

Here's a mockup of how we could handle toggling library frames. 

The benefit of this UI is that it's possible to quickly see the library frames and select a frame to explore. Try not to focus on the choices of color, but what whether this helps

1. toggle library frames
2. select a frame
3. it's keyboard accessible

Hmm, we might need to also add prevent default here:
https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/a29ec8c650c895590a9a59a3ee6c8cd9da68bcdb/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js#L479-L485
I looked into how we could add a breakpoint somewhere on the line and found that CodeMirror supports it with "bookmarks"


Here's the code to add a column breakpoint

```js
function addColumnBp({line, column}, editor) {
  const widget = document.createElement("span")
  widget.innerText = "+"
  widget.classList.add("inline-bp")

  return doc.setBookmark({ line: 38, ch: 13}, { widget })
```

We'll want to hold onto the bookmarks so that we can easily remove them as well with the `clear` command

done

Hey @ruturajv, 

1. it looks like functions are picked up [here](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/utils/tests/fixtures/func.js#L5)

2. I worry we'll pick up every variable assignment which will lead to a lot of duplication:

3. we'll miss global variables assigned this way, but that's probably okay for now. Given we'll have a simpler system for the time being.


```js
let a = 2;
a = 3;
a = 4;
```

closing this now as it's gone stale, but we can revisit it at any point
Some notes from the PR

adding blurred makes me concerned that we could be making things more difficult for ourselves in the future:  

* blurred could be a state for many elements
* blurred/focused might not be weird in some cases - an element is not focused, but it is blurred

I would like to better understand how atom does it. I started looking at their HTML:
One thing I do like is that it uses `::before` for the background which is nice

![](http://recordit.co/LzeyoWtBkG.gif)


also, here's the code: https://github.com/atom/tree-view

Looks like we were catching an edge case where exceptions were strings!

* updated the code
* added another unit test

<img width="1041" alt="screen shot 2017-04-21 at 4 49 39 pm" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/254562/25295805/2d76c038-26b3-11e7-9933-1493272e33b9.png">

Hey @tommai78101 , first, I will close this here, since it's not an issue with the debugger, but with the console, which are not in github at the moment.

I have a hard time understanding what you want to do and what is wrong, please, be as specific and detailed as you can when filing bugs so we can fact on them faster.

Now, I think I get it, you think your code is supposed to throw an error, but you don't see it in the console.
Now, can you try this : 
```js
console.log("(shoptoolbar.js) Executing a then().");
promise.then(function(retailer) {
	console.log("(shoptoolbar.js) Inside the then().  <------------");
	if (retailer instanceof IDBRequest) {
		console.log("(shoptoolbar.js) Swapping the result 1.");
		console.log(retailer.result);  //<--------   Just move this line up/down to trigger the error
		console.log(retailer);
		retailer = retailer.result;
		console.log(retailer);
		console.log("(shoptoolbar.js) Swapping the result 2.");
	}
	else {
		console.log("(shoptoolbar.js) EXCEPTION <------------------------.");
	}
}).catch(e => console.warn(e));
```
I guess this should show you the error you expect.
See the warning in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/JavaScript_code_modules/Promise.jsm/Promise#then() which explains what is going on.

You could use https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowEventHandlers/onunhandledrejection to log all you unhandled rejection in Promise callback to prevent such things to happen.
Thanks, and sorry for being too hasty (train leaves a bit early due to rush hour).

I will take a look at it once I get home, and will see what I can do with my local codebase. 
ahaa!! thanks.

![gif of left clicking to add a breakpoint, right clicking to open context menu w/o adding breakpoint](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7bu2sehHjuq2l8nm/giphy.gif)

Left clicking produces a breakpoint as expected. Right clicking opens the context menu, no breakpoint appears in the UI, and according to Redux devtools, no breakpoint is added.

I'm new, so I might be doing something wrong!

@jasonLaster There is a problem with a current implementation, if somebody hovers over `model` from `this.model` then the watch expression added is `model` while it should be  `this.model`. I tried going thru `ObjectInspector`'s getChildren, etc.. but Monday has caught up with its daily grind :) and can't single-handedly focus

Need a function / method that'll get me the entire path, ie. `this.model`

Help appreciated  - Thanks !
@jasonLaster looking at this one as candidate for Capriza Hackaton
nice!!
Hey @jcreighton I spent a couple hour studying this and I think we can follow the same pattern that we use for Editor Breakpoints and coverage markers. i.e. conditionally render a highlight range w/ codemirror

Here is a [branch] I setup with this idea. Note that it is incomplete:

1. `highlightFunction` has dummy data
2. we should only render the range as long as we're looking at that source, so we need to know the sourceId
3. `HighlightFunction` will always update, so we need to polish the `shouldUpdate`

I personally think this pattern of conditionally rendering aka using React is awesome and we can apply it to our highlight lines... 

Lastly, perhaps we do something when we select an item where we select the location and also fire off a `highlightFunction` action in the UI reducer. The advantage is that we separate the two things so that we can highlight and unhighlight functions a little bit differently... I think this is good, not really sure. Just want to make sure that we can easily unhighlight :)

[branch]: https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/compare/master...jasonLaster:highlighters?expand=1

finished in #2719

I worked with Peter and @Garbee on this today 

1. we created a new image for the mozilla + node dependencies + m-c
2. we ran yarn in the image and `yarn lint-css`
3. we pulled down m-c code and ran `./mach build`


```bash
hg clone https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/mozilla-inbound
cd mozilla-inbound
export SHELL=/bin/bash
touch .mozconfig
echo "ac_add_options --enable-artifact-builds" >> .mozconfig
echo "mk_add_options MOZ_OBJDIR=./objdir-frontend" >> .mozconfig
chmod +x .mozconfig
```

@virzen I haven't looked yet, but you might want to use the `record<>` notation for the flow issue. THe give away is immutable
Here is a quick optimized Dockerfile for what is currently present.

<details>
<summary>Dockerfile</summary>

```dockerfile
FROM ubuntu:trusty

# Install Firefox build dependencies.
# Packages are from https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/python/mozboot/mozboot/debian.py
RUN apt-get update -qq \
 && apt-get upgrade -qqy \
 && apt-get install -qqy \
  autoconf2.13 \
  build-essential \
  ccache \
  python-dev \
  python-pip \
  python-setuptools \
  unzip \
  uuid \
  zip \
  libasound2-dev \
  libcurl4-openssl-dev \
  libdbus-1-dev \
  libdbus-glib-1-dev \
  libgconf2-dev \
  libgtk-3-dev \
  libgtk2.0-dev \
  libiw-dev \
  libnotify-dev \
  libpulse-dev \
  libx11-xcb-dev \
  libxt-dev \
  mesa-common-dev \
  python-dbus \
  xvfb \
  wget \
  yasm \
  git \
  curl \
  apt-transport-https \
  ocaml \
  libelf-dev \
  python-software-properties \
  && wget -O bootstrap.py https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/raw-file/default/python/mozboot/bin/bootstrap.py \
  && python bootstrap.py --no-interactive --application-choice=browser \
  && curl -sSL https://dl.yarnpkg.com/debian/pubkey.gpg | apt-key add - \
  && echo "deb https://dl.yarnpkg.com/debian/ stable main" | tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/yarn.list \
  && curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_7.x | sudo -E bash - \
  && apt-get install -yqq yarn nodejs \
  && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Pull down m-c and add a simple mozconfig
# We'll be able to update the m-c repo at runtime
RUN hg clone https://hg.mozilla.org/integration/mozilla-inbound
RUN touch ./mozilla-inbound/.mozconfig \
  && echo "ac_add_options --enable-artifact-builds" >> ./mozilla-inbound/.mozconfig \
  && echo "mk_add_options MOZ_OBJDIR=./objdir-frontend" >> ./mozilla-inbound/.mozconfig \
  && chmod +x ./mozilla-inbound/.mozconfig
```

</details>

🎉 No problem!

```
Time:        1.089s
Ran all test suites matching "src/components".
  console.error ../node_modules/enzyme/build/react-compat.js:131
    react-addons-test-utils is an implicit dependency in order to support react@0.13-14. Please add the appropriate version to your devDependencies. See https://github.com/airbnb/enzyme#installation
```

This is exactly the kind of test I would like to see in the codebase

perhaps we render and simulate with reacts renderer's https://facebook.github.io/react/docs/test-utils.html

The other style test that we should have is where we render the component to JSON and save it as a fixture.

We should PR this style and also the fixture style!
Great write up. I know this is possible as these testing solutions predate 15.4
Tried something for testing react components, this method uses enzyme to make testing react components less painful

```
import { createFactory } from "react";
import { shallow } from "enzyme";
import Close from "../../components/shared/Button/Close";

const CloseButton = createFactory(Close);

describe("CloseButton", () => {
  it("should call handleClick function", () => {
    const onClick = jest.genMockFunction();
    const wrapper = shallow(new CloseButton({ handleClick: onClick }));

    wrapper.find(".close-btn").simulate("click");

    expect(onClick).toBeCalled();
  });
});
```

React also recommends the use of Enzyme. It   requires `react-addon-test-utils` package to be installed manually.

Also enzyme requires react-dom v15
4.2, we have 15.3.2. And upgrading it breaks the existing test cases. So need to find some workaround.

@jasonLaster Enzyme also has functionality to test against snapshot. So we test and save it's state and next time use it to check if something has changed.

1
Thanks @arthur801031 
@jasonLaster and I discussed about this issue and decided to hide the `Reveal in Tree` menu item for pretty-printed tabs since there is no appropriate fix at this moment. 

The cause of this issue is that there is no pretty-printed source in the `sourceTree`, so [findSource](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/utils/sources-tree.js#L369) returns null and it cannot find a source to reveal.

I got stuck with [my unit test](https://github.com/andreicristianpetcu/debugger.html/blob/d982d2c3b2e6c8168815353a174f4290ea9229d0/src/components/tests/Outline.js#L37-L44) :( maybe somebody can help me out.
The Outline generates a list of functions and variables when the [symbolDeclarations](https://github.com/andreicristianpetcu/debugger.html/blob/d982d2c3b2e6c8168815353a174f4290ea9229d0/src/components/Outline.js#L23-L62) property changes. It basically ends up being a `<div class="outline"><ul><li>my_example_function</li></ul></div>` at least this is what happens in the browser when I dbeug.

The problem is that in my unit test it happens differently. When I call [component.html()](https://github.com/andreicristianpetcu/debugger.html/blob/d982d2c3b2e6c8168815353a174f4290ea9229d0/src/components/tests/Outline.js#L42) I only get `<div class="outline"><ul></ul></div>` without any `li` with my_example_function.

What am I doing wrong? The function ends up in [renderFunction](https://github.com/andreicristianpetcu/debugger.html/blob/d982d2c3b2e6c8168815353a174f4290ea9229d0/src/components/Outline.js#L41) but not in the final HTML.
@jasonLaster I think your test has the same issue as mine: if I break the functionalitty, it still passes.

For example if I make [renderFunctions](https://github.com/jasonLaster/debugger.html/blob/ac8a938cbe54c95ffe3bee5fe89ed77be634f13e/src/components/Outline.js#L51-L53)  so that it returns null, the test still passes.

```javascript
  renderFunctions() {
    const { symbolDeclarations } = this.state;
    if (!symbolDeclarations) {
      return;
    }

    const { functions } = symbolDeclarations;

    // return functions
    // .filter(func => func.value != "anonymous")
    // .map(this.renderFunction);
    return null;
  }
```
A test that always passes is not usefull.

The code generates a [`li` inside the `ul`](https://github.com/jasonLaster/debugger.html/blob/ac8a938cbe54c95ffe3bee5fe89ed77be634f13e/src/components/Outline.js#L39-L41) but both my test and yours never check for the [`li`](https://github.com/jasonLaster/debugger.html/blob/ac8a938cbe54c95ffe3bee5fe89ed77be634f13e/src/components/tests/__snapshots__/Outline.js.snap#L11-L15). It seems like the [resultList test does a similar check](https://github.com/jasonLaster/debugger.html/blob/ac8a938cbe54c95ffe3bee5fe89ed77be634f13e/src/components/tests/__snapshots__/resultList.js.snap#L11-L46). I will try to see why it works and mine does not.

In my test I mocked the parser in order to force it to be sync and not async. I have an issue in my test and I wanted to rule out the async stuff. I will set it back as it was once I fix the issue.

EDIT: For people seeing this issue and that are not [on Slack](https://devtools-html.slack.com/messages/C3VTWQ4KZ/). I [made it work](https://github.com/andreicristianpetcu/debugger.html/commit/55265f943c9d2a031272c7409c0b7846c80653ca) with a lot of help from Slack users :D

One interesting thing to note is that we are currently duplicating our tests:
1. Web Test Runner: [test/integration](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/test/integration/tests/scopes.js#L51)
2. Mochitests: [test/mochitest](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/test/mochitest/browser_dbg-scopes.js)

The WTR test for scopes tests expanding nodes, while the mochitest does not. It would be nice if we updated this so the two tests are the same.

The [docs] describe running the WTR tests.

[docs]: https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/docs/local-development.md#integration-tests

I updated the scopes tests [here](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2635) hopefully this will land today so that you can have consistent tests to work with.
