## Version **1.3.0** just got published. 
Your tests are still failing with this version. [Compare the changes 🚨](/devtools-html/debugger.html/compare/greenkeeper%2Fprettier-1.3.0) 

<details>
<summary>Release Notes</summary>
<strong>1.3.0</strong>

<h2>Facebook Adoption Update</h2>
<p>The reason why I (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/vjeux" class="user-mention">@vjeux</a>) embarked on this journey working on prettier has always been to get the entire Facebook codebase converted over. I would like to give an update on how it is going and what is the process to get there.</p>
<p>The first projects to adopt prettier were Jest, React and immutable-js. Those are small codebases in the order of hundreds of files that have their own infrastructure. There are a handful of people working on them full time.</p>
<p>Then, Oculus and Nuclide converted their codebase over. The scale is bigger with a few thousands of files and tens of full time contributors but looks pretty similar to the first projects. The conversions went in one big codemod and that's it.</p>
<p>Now, the entire Facebook codebase is way bigger than this and it's not feasible to just convert everything in one go and to convince everyone that their entire codebase is going to be reformatted under their feet. So we need to find a more incremental approach.</p>
<h3>Scaling adoption</h3>
<p>Running prettier on a piece of code is a pretty expensive operation, it makes your pull request look bad because of a lot of unrelated changes and it causes merge conflicts for all the outstanding pull requests. So <strong>once a file has been formatted, you should do everything to make sure it remains formatted</strong>.</p>
<ul>
<li>When pretty-printing a file, add <code>@format</code> to the first block comment like <code>@flow</code>.</li>
<li>Have a lint rule with autofix that checks if the file is correctly pretty printed when <code>@format</code> is present.
<ul>
<li>When running Nuclide, it's going to show as an inline warning and have a fix button.</li>
<li>When sending a pull request, it's going to show the lint failing with a [Yn] prompt that you can just press enter.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Update the default code templates to add <code>@format</code> to the header.</li>
<li>When you run code formatting via cmd-shift-c inside of Nuclide, automatically insert the <code>@format</code> header.</li>
<li>Disable all the stylistic rules like max-len when <code>@format</code> is in the header.</li>
<li>Have script to run prettier through an entire folder with everything configured as a one line operation.</li>
<li>Have a good guide to help people that want to convert their codebase over with instructions and best practices.</li>
<li>When pushing a new release of prettier, also run it through all the files with <code>@format</code> in order to avoid getting warnings afterwards.</li>
<li>Add tracking for the number of files with <code>@format</code> over time.</li>
</ul>
<p>We finally got all those things wired up 1.5 weeks ago and the reception has been insane. Many people from various teams converted their codebase to prettier on their own. As of today, 15% of Facebook codebase has been converted over!</p>
<p><a href="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/197597/25565785/ed4abca4-2d82-11e7-9c26-380733444543.png" target="_blank"><img src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/197597/25565785/ed4abca4-2d82-11e7-9c26-380733444543.png" width="250" style="max-width:100%;"></a></p>
<p>When I started working on prettier, I had a hunch that people were hungry for tools to solve formatting. But I had no idea that once the tooling was in place, people would rush to convert their codebase over! This is great confirmation that this project is useful to people and not just a gimmicky tool.</p>
<h2>TypeScript Support Progress</h2>
<p><a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/despairblue" class="user-mention">@despairblue</a>, <a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/azz" class="user-mention">@azz</a> and <a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/JamesHenry" class="user-mention">@JamesHenry</a> have been hard at work around getting TypeScript supported by prettier as it's the top requested feature. 2000 out of 11000 files in the TypeScript test suite are not yet properly printed. You can follow progress on <a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/issues/1480" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1480" data-id="225636114" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1480</a> and do not hesitate to help out!</p>
<h2>Flow</h2>
<h3>Add trailing commas on flow generics (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1381" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1381" data-id="223491329" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1381</a>)</h3>
<p>The <code>--trailing-comma=all</code> option is supposed to add trailing commas everywhere possible, but as an oversight we forgot to do it for flow generics.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
type Errors <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">Immutable</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Map</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>
  Ahohohhohohohohohohohohohohooh,
  Fbt <span class="pl-k">|</span> <span class="pl-smi">Immutable</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Map</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>ErrorIndex, Fbt<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>;

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
type Errors <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">Immutable</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Map</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>
  Ahohohhohohohohohohohohohohooh,
  Fbt <span class="pl-k">|</span> <span class="pl-smi">Immutable</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Map</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>ErrorIndex, Fbt<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>,
<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>;</pre></div>
<h3>Inline nullable in flow generics (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1426" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1426" data-id="224481161" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1426</a>)</h3>
<p>The phase after printing things correctly is to tweak the output to make it closer to the way people write code in practice. Inlining optional flow types is a small thing that makes a difference.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
type Cursor <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">Promise</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>
  <span class="pl-k">?</span>{
    newCursor<span class="pl-k">?:</span> number,
    formatted<span class="pl-k">:</span> string,
  }
<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>;

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
type Cursor <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">Promise</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-k">?</span>{
  newCursor<span class="pl-k">?:</span> number,
  formatted<span class="pl-k">:</span> string,
}<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>;</pre></div>
<h3>Allow flow declarations to break on StringLiteralTypeAnnotations (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1437" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1437" data-id="224791002" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1437</a>)</h3>
<p>We can always find more places to add breaks when things don't fit 80 columns. This time it's around declaring a type as a constant string.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">export</span> <span class="pl-smi">type</span> <span class="pl-smi">AdamPlacementValidationSingleErrorKey</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>SOME_FANCY_TARGETS.GLOBAL_TARGET<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>;

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">export</span> <span class="pl-smi">type</span> <span class="pl-smi">AdamPlacementValidationSingleErrorKey</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span>
  <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>SOME_FANCY_TARGETS.GLOBAL_TARGET<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>;</pre></div>
<h3>Add space around <code>=</code> for flow generics default arguments (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1476" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1476" data-id="225531182" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1476</a>)</h3>
<p>Another example of small thing where we can improve the display of flow code. For function default arguments we put a space around <code>=</code> but didn't around flow generics.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">class</span> <span class="pl-en">PolyDefault</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-c1">T</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>string<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> {}

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">class</span> <span class="pl-en">PolyDefault</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-c1">T</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> string<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> {}</pre></div>
<h3>Don't break for unparenthesised single argument flow function (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1452" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1452" data-id="224969973" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1452</a>)</h3>
<p>I'm trying to figure out something to write here, but ... it just looks weird!</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> selectorByPath<span class="pl-k">:</span>
  <span class="pl-c1">Path</span>
 <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> SomethingSelector<span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>
  SomethingUEditorContextType,
  SomethingUEditorContextType,
  SomethingBulkValue<span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>string<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-en">memoizeWithArgs</span>(<span class="pl-c">/* ... */</span>)

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> selectorByPath<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">Path</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> SomethingSelector<span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>
  SomethingUEditorContextType,
  SomethingUEditorContextType,
  SomethingBulkValue<span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>string<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-en">memoizeWithArgs</span>(<span class="pl-c">/* ... */</span>);</pre></div>
<h3>Fix optional flow parenthesis (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1357" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1357" data-id="222938015" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1357</a>)</h3>
<p>We were a bit too lenient around parenthesis for optional flow types. In one case in the entire Facebook codebase, it generated code with different semantics. As part of this fix, we hardened the list of types that can be written without parenthesis.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
type <span class="pl-c1">X</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">?</span>(<span class="pl-smi">number</span>, <span class="pl-smi">number</span>) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-smi">number</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-k">void</span>;

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
type <span class="pl-c1">X</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> (<span class="pl-k">?</span>(<span class="pl-smi">number</span>, <span class="pl-smi">number</span>) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> number) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-k">void</span>;</pre></div>
<h3>Skip trailing commas with FlowShorthandWithOneArg (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1364" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1364" data-id="223171283" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1364</a>)</h3>
<p>It is a parse error to add a trailing comma without parenthesis for arguments of arrow function types. We found one case in Facebook codebase when this happened, it's a very rare occurrence.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
type IdeConnectionFactory <span class="pl-k">=</span>
  child_process$ChildProcess,
  <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> FlowIDEConnection <span class="pl-k">=</span> defaultIDEConnectionFactory;

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
type IdeConnectionFactory <span class="pl-k">=</span>
  child_process$ChildProcess
  <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> FlowIDEConnection <span class="pl-k">=</span> defaultIDEConnectionFactory;</pre></div>
<h3>Reorder flow object props (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1451" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1451" data-id="224961215" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1451</a>)</h3>
<p>This one is an example where the way the AST is structured is not our favor. Instead of having a list of elements inside of a type, the AST is structured in a way where normal keys and array keys each have their own group. In order to restore the initial order, we're now reading from the original source :(</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
type Foo <span class="pl-k">=</span> {
  [key<span class="pl-k">:</span> string]<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-k">void</span>,
  alpha<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>hello<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,
  beta<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span>
};

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
type Foo <span class="pl-k">=</span> {
  alpha<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>hello<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,
  [key<span class="pl-k">:</span> string]<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-k">void</span>,
  beta<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">10</span>
}</pre></div>
<h2>Template Literal</h2>
<h3>Proper indentation for template literals (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1385" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1385" data-id="223537336" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1385</a>)</h3>
<p>A long standing issue with template literals and prettier is around the indentation of code inside of <code>${}</code>. It used to be the indentation of the backtick but turned out to give poor results. Instead people tend to use the indent of the <code>${</code>. We changed this behavior and it magically made GraphQL queries look pretty!</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-smi">Relay</span>.<span class="pl-en">createContainer</span>({
  <span class="pl-en">nodes</span><span class="pl-k">:</span> ({ solution_type, time_frame }) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-en">Relay.QL</span><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>
<span class="pl-s">    <span class="pl-en">fragment</span> {</span>
<span class="pl-s">      <span class="pl-v">__typename</span></span>
<span class="pl-s">      ${<span class="pl-v">OptimalSolutionsSection</span>.<span class="pl-v">getFragment</span>("<span class="pl-v">node</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>, {</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">    solution_type,</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">    time_frame</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">  })}</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">    }</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">  `</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">})</span></span></pre></div>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-smi">Relay</span>.<span class="pl-en">createContainer</span>({
  <span class="pl-en">nodes</span><span class="pl-k">:</span> ({ solution_type, time_frame }) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-en">Relay.QL</span><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>
<span class="pl-s">    <span class="pl-en">fragment</span> {</span>
<span class="pl-s">      <span class="pl-v">__typename</span></span>
<span class="pl-s">      ${<span class="pl-v">OptimalSolutionsSection</span>.<span class="pl-v">getFragment</span>("<span class="pl-v">node</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>, {</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">        solution_type,</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">        time_frame</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">      })}</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">    }</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">  `</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-s">})</span></span></pre></div>
<h3>Do not indent calls with a single template literal argument (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/873" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/873" data-id="211795192" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#873</a>)</h3>
<p>Template literals are very hard to deal with for a pretty printer because the spaces inside are meaningful so you can't re-indent them. We didn't know what to do for a call with a single template literal so we didn't do anything, but we kept receiving reports of people saying that prettier indented it the wrong way, so we are now inlining them. Fingers crossed it is going to cover most use cases.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-en">insertRule</span>(
  <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span>*, *:before, *:after {</span>
<span class="pl-s">    box-sizing: inherit;</span>
<span class="pl-s">  }<span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>
);

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-en">insertRule</span>(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span>*, *:before, *:after {</span>
<span class="pl-s">  box-sizing: inherit;</span>
<span class="pl-s">}<span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>);</pre></div>
<h3>Fix windows line ending on template literals (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1439" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1439" data-id="224847986" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1439</a>)</h3>
<p>We manipulate line endings in a lot of places in prettier and took great care of handling both <code>\n</code> and <code>\r\n</code> except for template literals where we forgot. Now this is fixed!</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">aLongString</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>
<span class="pl-s"></span>
<span class="pl-s">Line 1</span>
<span class="pl-s"></span>
<span class="pl-s">Line 2</span>
<span class="pl-s"></span>
<span class="pl-s">Line 3</span>
<span class="pl-s"></span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>;

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">aLongString</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>
<span class="pl-s">Line 1</span>
<span class="pl-s">Line 2</span>
<span class="pl-s">Line 3</span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>;</pre></div>
<h3>Inline template literals as arrow body (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1485" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1485" data-id="225744027" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1485</a>)</h3>
<p>We already inline template literals that are tagged (eg <code>graphql`query`</code>) but didn't for plain template literals. For the anecdote, it turns out the code was supposed to support it but it was using <code>TemplateElement</code> instead of <code>TemplateLiteral</code> :(</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">inlineStore</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">preloadedState</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span>
  <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>
<span class="pl-s">  &lt;script&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-s">    window.preloadedState = <span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-pse">${</span><span class="pl-c1">JSON</span>.<span class="pl-en">stringify</span>(preloadedState).<span class="pl-c1">replace</span>(<span class="pl-sr"><span class="pl-pds">/</span>&lt;<span class="pl-pds">/</span>g</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-cce">\\</span>u003c<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-pse">}</span></span></span>
<span class="pl-s">  &lt;/script&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">inlineStore</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">preloadedState</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span>
<span class="pl-s">  &lt;script&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-s">    window.preloadedState = <span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-pse">${</span><span class="pl-c1">JSON</span>.<span class="pl-en">stringify</span>(preloadedState).<span class="pl-c1">replace</span>(<span class="pl-sr"><span class="pl-pds">/</span>&lt;<span class="pl-pds">/</span>g</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-cce">\\</span>u003c<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-pse">}</span></span></span>
<span class="pl-s">  &lt;/script&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">`</span></span></pre></div>
<h2>Ternaries</h2>
<h3>Add parenthesis for unusual nested ternaries (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1386" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1386" data-id="223538015" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1386</a>)</h3>
<p>While working on printing nested ternaries, everyone focused on the ones with the shape of an if then else <code>cond1 ? elem1_if : cond2 ? elem2_if : elem_else</code> which is the most common. But, if you move move some <code>?</code> and <code>:</code> around you can have another pattern. It looks almost the same but has a different meaning. In order to reduce confusion, we're adding parenthesis around the uncommon form.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
cond1 <span class="pl-k">?</span> cond2 <span class="pl-k">?</span> elem2_if <span class="pl-k">:</span> elem2_else <span class="pl-k">:</span> elem1_else

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
cond1 <span class="pl-k">?</span> (cond2 <span class="pl-k">?</span> elem2_if <span class="pl-k">:</span> elem2_else) <span class="pl-k">:</span> elem1_else</pre></div>
<h3>Only add parenthesis on ternaries inside of arrow functions if doesn't break (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1450" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1450" data-id="224958719" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1450</a>)</h3>
<p>There's an eslint rule <a href="http://eslint.org/docs/rules/no-confusing-arrow"><code>no-confusing-arrows</code></a> which suggests adding parenthesis for ternaries in arrow functions without brackets.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-en">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">a</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">?</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span> <span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>;
<span class="pl-k">var</span> x <span class="pl-k">=</span> a <span class="pl-k">&lt;=</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">?</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span> <span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>;</pre></div>
<p>It makes sense when code is in one line, but when it is split into multiple lines, the parenthesis are unnecessary given the indentation, so we now only put them when they serve their disambiguation purpose.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-en">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">a</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">?</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span> <span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>);
<span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-en">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">a</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span>
  (<span class="pl-c1">1</span>
    <span class="pl-k">?</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span>
    <span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>);

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-en">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">a</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> (<span class="pl-c1">1</span> <span class="pl-k">?</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span> <span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>);
<span class="pl-k">var</span> <span class="pl-en">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">a</span> <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span>
  <span class="pl-c1">1</span>
    <span class="pl-k">?</span> <span class="pl-c1">2</span>
    <span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">3</span>;</pre></div>
<h2>General JavaScript Improvements</h2>
<h3>Inline function declaration with single arg as object (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1173" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1173" data-id="220508614" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1173</a>)</h3>
<p>This one was often requested for React Stateless Functional Components (SFC). If you make use of a lot of them, it's likely going to be a big change for you.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">X</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> (
  props<span class="pl-k">:</span> {
    a<span class="pl-k">:</span> boolean,
  },
) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>div <span class="pl-k">/</span><span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>;

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">X</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> (props<span class="pl-k">:</span> {
  a<span class="pl-k">:</span> boolean,
}) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>div <span class="pl-k">/</span><span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>;</pre></div>
<h3>Break inline object first in function arguments (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1453" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1453" data-id="224973725" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1453</a>)</h3>
<p>One thing we discovered early on is that people usually break the arguments of the function before breaking the return type. Unfortunately, the code responsible to inline single destructuring argument broke that assumption and it introduced bad looking code like this example. The good news is that it enables us to turn on inlining for single arguments that are typed with an object.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">class</span> <span class="pl-en">X</span> {
  <span class="pl-k">async</span> <span class="pl-en">onDidInsertSuggestion</span>({editor, triggerPosition, suggestion})<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">Promise</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>
    <span class="pl-k">void</span>
  <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> {
  }
}

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">class</span> <span class="pl-en">X</span> {
  <span class="pl-k">async</span> <span class="pl-en">onDidInsertSuggestion</span>({
    editor,
    triggerPosition,
    suggestion
  })<span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">Promise</span><span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-k">void</span><span class="pl-k">&gt;</span> {
  }
}</pre></div>
<h3>Don't break on empty arrays and objects (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1440" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1440" data-id="224861358" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1440</a>)</h3>
<p>This one has been a long standing issue and is an easy fix, but was an invaluable tool: whenever someone reported that <code>[]</code> or <code>{}</code> would break, we were able to fix the example by fixing something else. So it was a great way to surface edge cases. Fortunately, this vein has now ran out and all the recent examples just look bad with no other reason than the fact that they are breaking. So it's time to finally do it!</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">a</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">someVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeLong</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Expression</span> <span class="pl-k">||</span> [
];

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">a</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">someVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeryVeLong</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Expression</span> <span class="pl-k">||</span> [];</pre></div>
<h3>Do not break on [0] (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1441" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1441" data-id="224864922" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1441</a>)</h3>
<p>We have a lot of issues where code breaks in array access when it doesn't look good. We don't yet have a good generic solution for it, but we can add a specific fix a common situation: <code>[0]</code>.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-en">queryThenMutateDOM</span>(() <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> {
  title <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">SomeThing</span>.<span class="pl-c1">call</span>(root, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>someLongStringThatPushesThisTextReall<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)[
    <span class="pl-c1">0</span>
  ];
});

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-en">queryThenMutateDOM</span>(() <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> {
  title <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">SomeThing</span>.<span class="pl-c1">call</span>(
    root,
    <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>someLongStringThatPushesThisTextReall<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,
  )[<span class="pl-c1">0</span>];
});</pre></div>
<h3>Indent do while condition  (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1373" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1373" data-id="223277133" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1373</a>)</h3>
<p>We were not using the correct indentation logic for do-while condition but someone noticed, now we do!</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">do</span> {}
<span class="pl-k">while</span> (someVeryLongStringA <span class="pl-k">&amp;&amp;</span> someVeryLongStringB <span class="pl-k">&amp;&amp;</span> someVeryLongStringC <span class="pl-k">&amp;&amp;</span> someVeryLongStringD);

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">do</span> {}
<span class="pl-k">while</span> (
  someVeryLongStringA <span class="pl-k">&amp;&amp;</span>
  someVeryLongStringB <span class="pl-k">&amp;&amp;</span>
  someVeryLongStringC <span class="pl-k">&amp;&amp;</span>
  someVeryLongStringD
);</pre></div>
<h3>Preserve inline comment as last argument (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1390" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1390" data-id="223573544" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1390</a>)</h3>
<p>We forgot to add one case in the comment detection code when they appear last for JSX attributes and function arguments which made them go after the closing. In the case of JSX, it generated code that had a different meaning. Fortunately, since we don't usually commit commented out code it didn't affect production code, but it is not a good experience while coding.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> (
  <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>div
    attr1<span class="pl-k">=</span>{<span class="pl-c1">1</span>}<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span>   attr3={3}</span>
    {children}
  <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-k">/</span>div<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>
);

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-c1">x</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> (
  <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span>div
    attr1<span class="pl-k">=</span>{<span class="pl-c1">1</span>}
<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span>   attr3={3}</span>
  <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>
    {children}
  <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span><span class="pl-k">/</span>div<span class="pl-k">&gt;</span>
);</pre></div>
<h3>Break class expression returned by arrow call (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1464" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1464" data-id="225271288" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1464</a>)</h3>
<p>In 1.0, we made class be inline inside of arrow functions. It turns out that it doesn't work great when the class is non trivial, so we are reverting this change. We're trying really hard to avoid making trashy decisions like this where the style changes back and forth, but we allow ourselves to do it sometimes to fix mistakes!</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">export</span> <span class="pl-c1">default</span> (<span class="pl-smi">ViewComponent</span><span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">Function</span>, <span class="pl-smi">ContainerComponent</span><span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">Function</span>) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span> <span class="pl-k">class</span>
  <span class="pl-k">extends</span> <span class="pl-smi">React</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Component</span> {
  <span class="pl-k">static</span> propTypes <span class="pl-k">=</span> {};
};

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">export</span> <span class="pl-c1">default</span> (<span class="pl-smi">ViewComponent</span><span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">Function</span>, <span class="pl-smi">ContainerComponent</span><span class="pl-k">:</span> <span class="pl-c1">Function</span>) <span class="pl-k">=&gt;</span>
  <span class="pl-k">class</span> <span class="pl-k">extends</span> <span class="pl-e">React</span>.<span class="pl-smi">Component</span> {
    <span class="pl-k">static</span> propTypes <span class="pl-k">=</span> {};
  };</pre></div>
<h3>Fix empty line in block with EmptyStatement (<a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/prettier/prettier/pull/1375" class="issue-link js-issue-link" data-url="https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/1375" data-id="223323206" data-error-text="Failed to load issue title" data-permission-text="Issue title is private">#1375</a>)</h3>
<p>This one was found by fuzzing. You're unlikely going to hit this in real code but it's good to know it is fixed!</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-js"><pre><span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Input</span>
<span class="pl-k">if</span> (a) {
  b;


  ;
}

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> Before</span>
<span class="pl-k">if</span> (a) {
  b;

}

<span class="pl-c"><span class="pl-c">//</span> After</span>
<span class="pl-k">if</span> (a) {
  b;

}</pre></div>
</details>

I looked at the perf for stepping earlier with @gregtatum and found three things

1. json parsing is slow in the launchpad (can't fix that)
2. immutable hydration in the pause reducer
3. getAndProcessFrames is slow because of toJS

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2834?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2834?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [d359105...43b87a0](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2834?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

So I was thinking about this even more. In fact I had it partially right - actual type of those pops is:
`(...args: any[]) => (ThunkArgs => any)`
because `dispatch` is returning an `action` (what got dispatched)

but thats just in this use case, treating components as app agnostic it should be specified as:
`(...args: any[]) => any` (as long as component is not interested in the prop's return value)

because component doesnt really care about actions and thunks, function prop is kinda its output API and in that regard I think those return types should be skipped (specified as `any`)

WDYT?

I agree. The flow+redux docs cover this as well. I like the types you
currently have :)
On Sat, May 6, 2017 at 5:06 PM Mateusz Burzyński <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> actual type of those pops is:
> (...args: any[]) => (ThunkArgs => any)
> because dispatch is returning an action (what got dispatched)
>
> but thats just in this use case, treating components as app agnostic it
> should be specified as:
> (...args: any[]) => any (as long as component is not interested in the
> prop's return value)
>
> because component doesnt really care about actions and thunks, function
> prop is kinda its output API and in that regard I think those return types
> should be skipped (specified as any)
>

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2837?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2837?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [d359105...d222531](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2837?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

so now in the PR we have such props flow types, all of these are dispatch wrapped action creators
```javascript
props: {
    selectSource: (string, ?SelectSourceOptions) => Thunk,
    toggleFileSearch: (?boolean) => Thunk,
    toggleFileSearchModifier: string => void,
    toggleSymbolSearch: boolean => Thunk,
    setSelectedSymbolType: SymbolSearchType => Thunk,
    setFileSearchQuery: string => void,
    updateSearchResults: ({ count: number, index?: number }) => void
};
```
But actually as far as the component is concerned - they are just functions, not action creators, not thunks, just functions. From its perpective it only requires certain argument types because it will call those functions with such data - it is its  defined API. On the other hand their return types are completely irrelevant for it (in most cases, because in most cases component just call a function prop and doesnt use its return value for anything) - because from its perpective any function (with specified argument types) can just plug in to it. So such thinking led me to the thought that those should be in fact specified as
```javascript
props: {
    selectSource: (string, ?SelectSourceOptions) => any,
    toggleFileSearch: (?boolean) => any,
    toggleFileSearchModifier: string => any,
    toggleSymbolSearch: boolean => any,
    setSelectedSymbolType: SymbolSearchType => any,
    setFileSearchQuery: string => any,
    updateSearchResults: ({ count: number, index?: number }) => any
};
```

PS. those 2 PRs were my first attempts at using flow and typing components in general, so there is a chance Im talking bs ;p

Thanks @diessica! Looks great, will review shortly :)
Thanks for the writeup. One of the best things about getting help from smart people is that they take the time to think through some of these new conventions. I realize that you're new to flow, but you're doing a great job of articulating the trade-offs. 

I'm personally persuaded that the return type does not matter in this context as the components fire and forget actions. They never use the return. 

Given this, lets have all of our actions return `any` and keep them simple. I perhaps can be persuaded later that they are important, but for now I think this is correct in this context. 
Thanks for all the help, you should join our slack if you haven't already!

Thanks for reviewing! I'll look into it soon.
Ok, I've looked into it.  In Chrome, it flashes really fast, as you said. In Firefox is more weird and evident, because it shows a black border until it gets `--theme-splitter-color` value, apparently.

Chrome (current, with bug):

![mgfj8b3kyfvrggi_qv2c0ct-vlm-8lq05yoyrlypdlnc4yzodlgikncsmbtqskr3qw8onupezh-c4qka3xfsolnlsmh0egfbdyhze6lvomai4av1wcwksmudutgzhrrg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5303585/25783917/95337ce6-333a-11e7-81f6-d6e085e74e37.gif)

It seems related to the fact that the `active` class takes a bit to apply, so it flashes when it does, which end up definitely not easy to the eyes. Even worse in Firefox, because of the black border.

In `renderTabs()`, we could prevent rendering of source tabs until we get `selectedSource`. If there isn't a `selectedSource` already, tabs won't render. What do you think? Does it make sense to you?

Chrome (result from solution above):
![u6odktgvg54e2mg6puo6ouf2mc1dhi8f0enkwtjxxs63vuippmlgkhhn7v8bv9qq6jib0i3xjxr1gp7kb-pxqvnlsmh0egfbdyhze6lvomai4av1wcwksmudutgzhrrg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5303585/25784624/fbe08694-3346-11e7-9c7a-0c84be0858ea.gif)

There's a consistency issue with colored SVG's. I'm just not sure we intended for this visual effect along the source tree in terms of the color.
<img width="253" alt="screen shot 2017-05-10 at 9 31 23" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/394320/25885891/b3ea1566-3563-11e7-9d31-7030de36405d.png">

This is also evident in the react logo, which specifies a fill color in itself. But less conspicuous.

One possible solution is to remove the fills from the SVG, but not sure if license permits, plus doesn't always work visually (it doesn't for the webpack logo - it just turns to a full hexagon)

Thanks @amitzur, we were just talking about that as well.

I think Atom does a great job of simplifying the icon so that it fits with other icons. I will merge this work as we have done the "hard" thing here and we can create a new issue for using a better SVG and perhaps styling some of the other icons as well. For instance, I think "JS" would be really easy and would help a lot.

Sure.
1. Create an anonymous function, run & break in that function
   ```js
   setTimeout(function(){
     debugger;
   }, 50);
   ```
![screen shot 2017-05-12 at 12 50 22 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/317498/26008207/cab3adc0-3711-11e7-8a20-683069a466d0.png)
2. Name the function and do it again
   ```js
   setTimeout(function nameyMcNameface(){
     debugger;
   }, 50);
   ```
![screen shot 2017-05-12 at 12 51 15 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/317498/26008247/f23bbb26-3711-11e7-87bb-b46d6726ec85.png)

Note how you see "nameyMcNameface" in the second screenshot's stack frame (highlighted), *nothing* in the first (also highlighted).

Yeah, why is it undefined. It would be really nice to have `false`
Closing this as we can handle the params in their own bug :)
I was thinking about something like:

```
+ webassembly.org
|-- demo/Tanks
+ blob:webassembly.org
|-- xxx-xxx-xxx
+ wasm:webassembly.org
|-- demo/Tanks
```

wasm: is tricky with tanks with Tanks demo since wasm is generated by blob script, so it can be

```
+ wasm:blob:webassembly.org
|-- + demo/Tanks
|-- |-- xxxxx-xxxx
```

or

```
+ wasm:
|-- + blob:webassembly.org/demo/Tanks
|-- |--  xxxxx-xxxx
```

`wasm:` is differ between browsers (no standard). Firefox's can be `wasm:xxxxx-xxx` or `wasm:http://example.org/path/script.js:xxxx-xxx`, Chrome's `wasm://xxxx-xxxx` (?)

@karthikJagadeesh go for it!
The `SourcesTree.componentWillReceiveProps(nextProps)` function in `SourcesTree.js` seems to expect to be given additional sources via `nextProps.sources` every time it is called, but when `sources.size === 0` it recreates the tree - I'm not quite sure why, but the debuggeeUrl is part of the props and when it changes, this function is called with 0 sources, so it basically removes everything. 

I'm also getting different results when I call `actions.navigate(tabTarget._form.url);` in `firefox.js` immediately vs. when called after a scheduled setTimeout...
oh fascinating. so we need to be a bit stricter about when we build the tree. 

like slow down...

## Current changes:
```javascript
diff --git a/src/components/Editor/index.js b/src/components/Editor/index.js
index df440c06..b35a45e1 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/index.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/index.js
@@ -770,7 +770,7 @@ class Editor extends PureComponent {
       getExpression: this.props.getExpression
     });

-    if (!value || value.type == "undefined") {
+    if (value.type == "undefined") {
       return;
     }

diff --git a/src/utils/editor/expression.js b/src/utils/editor/expression.js
index 039ffe24..3e02a44b 100644
--- a/src/utils/editor/expression.js
+++ b/src/utils/editor/expression.js
@@ -84,7 +84,7 @@ export function getExpressionValue(
   { getExpression }: Object
 ) {
   const variableValue = get(selectedExpression, "contents.value");
-  if (variableValue) {
+  if (typeof variableValue === "boolean" || variableValue) {
     return variableValue;
   }
```

From what I experienced, the code vanishes also for the simple STRs below:
1. stop on a breakpoint
2. switch to any other tool
3. switch back to debugger

The following error is logged in the console:
> codemirror.bundle.js:8022:24
> Error: This document is already in use.

I think I tried locally with the latest master from debugger and I still get the issue.

I'm pretty sure this will actually have to be fixed in mozilla central, since we use a different version of the editor component when we are embedded in Firefox. 

I attached a patch to https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1365059 that fixes the issue for me

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2985?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2985?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [399b863...adcdc86](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2985?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

I just looked into it with the help of @bomsy and @Anshul and we found that binding variables from outer scopes are not re-created on subsequent steps. 

In terms of steps:
- script actor calls [`_paused`][pas] to create a pause packet
- script actor calls [`_createFrameActor`][fas], 
  - which subsequently creates an environment actor, 
  - which [creates actors][bis] for each binding
  - this calls [`objectGrip`][og] which has the bug.

The bug is that `objectGrip` believes that the actor is registered because `pool.objectActors` has the value. Unfortunately, for some reason the pool does not have the actor. 

The interesting thing is that `objectGrip` is a weak map so the actor must be retained somewhere. The next step is to find the retaining path and see if we can safely remove it.


[oas]:https://github.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/blob/master/devtools/server/actors/script.js#L1698-L1700
[pas]:https://github.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/blob/master/devtools/server/actors/script.js#L705-L706
[fas]:https://github.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/blob/master/devtools/server/actors/script.js#L1629-L1640
[bis]:https://github.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/blob/master/devtools/server/actors/environment.js#L145-L149
[og]:https://github.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/blob/master/devtools/server/actors/script.js#L1698-L1701

This bug makes it hard to do my job. :(

I need to set breakpoints to find out why new Pandora is busted in Nightly, but it's not possible with https://www.pandora.com/web-client/37.2b288d7f92d80323cb24.js in the new debugger. 😭 
Uh, I just restarted the browser and got the pretty printer button for this file... but it didn't do anything. Closing and re-opening the debugger made it actually work. 

![pandora](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/67283/26330671/b577e364-3f12-11e7-81ed-36ec72c53aa8.gif)

edit: nevermind, I realize I flipped back to the old debugger. It's been a long day. :p

> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2997?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [884ff3f...d30b005](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/2997?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

I think you found a really nice solution.
So, I have a solution but it is imperfect:

I am not setting the breakpoint's initial state in the addBreakpoint reducer. Instead, (as you can see here: https://github.com/codehag/debugger.html/blob/b67525b5be007f077253f471e97ea030564a71d6/src/actions/sources.js#L66) after the breakpoint is added, I check if it should be disabled, and fire the action to disable it.

This solution is imperfect because the breakpoint blinks to enabled, and then to disabled if it is disabled.

I think that a full solution would require refactoring the `addBreakpoint` reducer so that enabling a break point does not rely on it. I've narrowed down the new bug of skipping breakpoints being a result of that. I suspect that the call to the server returns a slid location because the server expects a different breakpoint, and adding a breakpoint to a disabled breakpoint doesn't make sense to it. maybe. 

I decided that since it took so much time to get to this point, to stop here and get some feedback. Let me know what you think @jasonLaster (and anyone else interested)
Thanks for the help. I'm going to close this as it's gotten a bit stale. Feel free to pick it up again
@jasonLaster, can I take this as my first PR?
Thanks for filing @hex13 
Sure!

I just spent 60 seconds with the main thread hung waiting on a search for a minified file (beach ball unresponsive browser). Worse yet, I wasn't actively searching, I had a search already in the search box from a previous file. This feels pretty bad behavior going out on a major release :-/

The time is being spent in CodeMirror token matching: https://perfht.ml/2r0hOOK
Caused primarily by the garbage collection of the tokens: https://perfht.ml/2r0046c

STR:
* Visit: http://alteredqualia.com/xg/examples/hannibal_draco.html
* Open xg.min.625.js in the debugger.
* Search for `dofEnabled`
Thanks @ryanjduffy you're absolutely right. I just made this PR https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3008 to remove the search results, which speeds it up tremendously.

Now we just need to do something like wellington's algorithm to compute the location of the matches per document and then use that to make a new search.results list that we can use.

Thanks for filing: part of the issue is the cursor starting at index 0. That part comes from this change that bz made: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1357206

I'm curious about the other parts though as I didn't realize they were affected as well.
Thanks for filing the other regressions. I see them too on nightly, but not in chrome which leads me to believe it is related to bz's change
Thanks @gijsk this is a dupe of #2849 which we'll fix soon. It's the biggest issue with the new debugger UI at the moment :)
@karlcow can you tell us specifically which device you select in RDM? I used a nexus device here, not sure it makes a big difference?

Thanks @gijsk. keeping the expand state for variables is on our list. We had it in the debugger for the past couple months but found some cases where we were keeping stale data when we maintained the expand state. We hope to revisit this after launch in june.

scroll state is slightly different because stepping involves resuming and repausing, so there is a flicker. We have an issue for avoiding that but it is lower priority.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3036?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [e037212...a6b25e0](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3036?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

hmm - switching tools seems fine, but vertical/horizontal does not.

#### Tools
![](http://g.recordit.co/QNiIQ1dcVq.gif)

#### Horizontal
![](http://g.recordit.co/Y7qUXPpnLr.gif)
Changed from my original approach of walking up the AST from a location to find scope boundaries to finding all functions and filtering from there. Both cases required an AST traversal (the former relied on an existing `getClosestScope`) but it was too difficult to "find" potential scopes in the original approach.

A possible solution to reducing AST traversals is to rewrite the functions that require AST searching to all run at the same time and cache relevant data. I've structured this function to adapt well to that in that it retrieves all functions (the cacheable data) and separates map/filter/reduces it to get to a result set based on a location. A similar approach could be taken with the other parser functions.
Added a parser function in #3041 to start enabling this feature.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3048?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [dc84089...8742078](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3048?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Reps should have what's needed to _show_ the icon.
For element-node and text-node, it checks if `grip.preview.isConnected` is true, and if some props were passed (`onDOMNodeMouseOver`, `onDOMNodeMouseOut`, `onInspectIconClick`)

So the following show the icon in the debugger …
```diff
diff --git a/src/components/shared/Rep.js b/src/components/shared/Rep.js
index 16a565a1..1675a32e 100644
--- a/src/components/shared/Rep.js
+++ b/src/components/shared/Rep.js
@@ -9,9 +9,15 @@ type RenderRepOptions = {
 };

 import { REPS } from "devtools-reps";
-const { Rep: _Rep, Grip } = REPS;
-const Rep = createFactory(_Rep);
+const { Rep, Grip } = REPS;

 export default function renderRep({ object, mode }: RenderRepOptions) {
-  return Rep({ object, defaultRep: Grip, mode });
+  return Rep({
+    object,
+    defaultRep: Grip,
+    mode,
+    onDOMNodeMouseOver: x => console.log(x),
+    onDOMNodeMouseOut: x => console.log(x),
+    onInspectIconClick: x => console.log(x),
+  });
 }
```
… but does not do the linking by itself.
You then have to call `toolbox.highlighterUtils` functions like [we do in the console.](http://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/rev/dc1f84cb436f47b9d8b2fa2fecbb809c1acd7c89/devtools/client/webconsole/new-console-output/new-console-output-wrapper.js#94-120)

I don't really know the code of the debugger and how to get the reference to the toolbox though.
If anyone has an idea, please chim in so I can implement this.

Another issue to be take care of would be to stop the propagation of the click event on the inspect icon. If not, other click listeners could be triggered (like the ObjectInspector expand/collapse).
Thanks @svincent I should clarify in the roadmap. We think that libraries should be much more integrated into the debugger.We are starting with react so that we can focus on clearly good ideas, but we fully expect them to generalize to other libraries. An example of this is our new library call stack groups:

https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/issues/2980
Any STR?
@bomsy I think it is because the selected token aka target element is undefined.

I'd just add that fix for now
@jbhoosreddy it certainly is:

https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/utils/object-inspector.js#L66-L69
