![](http://g.recordit.co/p1ZDleUT8a.gif)
closing this as @nchevobbe is close to landing it in devtools-core. No longer a dbg concern :)
Moved text search to a worker, which makes it smooth. We still need to get the match index though...
Sorry for missing this @gerdneuman. Meant to get back and it fell off my queue.

We steal a lot of good ideas from VS Code, so this idea is not crazy. I'd like to revisit call stacks and Scopes/Variables, this summer. The current design makes sense conceptually to me as the call stack is hierarchically on top (frame -> scope -> variable). 

We've simplified the call stack dramatically by grouping framework frames which will make the UI more useful i believe. The next step for me is to think through how we show you the variables you likely care about.

This is two things:

1. clean up the variables when you are source mapped. we show the bundled variables _webpackContext2, babelDefault3... and not the original variables `toggleBtn`, `isActive`... 
2. highlight the expressions in scope. In practice variables are less useful than expressions `person` is not as good as `person.data.firstName`. We analyze the code in scope for these expressions when we preview a var. We are planning on doing a sweep of the code and showing inline previews similar to how google docs shows comments. I think that this will force us to think about the sidebar UX :)


Closing this issue because it's not actionable now, but hopefully we can keep talking about it.
Yes, that's a great idea. I'm adding it to our enhancements board so that we can evaluate when we plan. https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/projects/5

I'de like to consider running VS Code's intellisense server...
I believe it should be working now

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3223?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [93750a7...c8ba53f](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3223?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

I looked into this a bit today and found that it is caused by the Editor component unmounting when you select another tool

This patch below shows that we can:

a) track when the tool is active and only then switch modes
b) not move the tabs when the tool is de-activated ...

The code is ugly, so we'll want to clean it up

```diff
diff --git a/src/components/App.js b/src/components/App.js
index 8af09ff..727860c 100644
--- a/src/components/App.js
+++ b/src/components/App.js
@@ -84,8 +84,11 @@ class App extends Component {
     verticalLayoutBreakpoint.removeListener(this.onLayoutChange);
   }

-  onLayoutChange() {
-    this.setState({ horizontal: verticalLayoutBreakpoint.matches });
+  onLayoutChange(a, b, c) {
+    console.log("onLayoutChange");
+    if (window.isActive) {
+      this.setState({ horizontal: verticalLayoutBreakpoint.matches });
+    }
   }

   renderEditorPane() {
   
   diff --git a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
index 96f9271..3a5c9ca 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
@@ -135,7 +135,7 @@ class SourceTabs extends PureComponent {
     );

     this.onResize = debounce(() => {
-      this.updateHiddenSourceTabs();
+      // this.updateHiddenSourceTabs();
     });
   }

   diff --git a/src/utils/bootstrap.js b/src/utils/bootstrap.js
index 9231c5c..620bd00 100644
--- a/src/utils/bootstrap.js
+++ b/src/utils/bootstrap.js
@@ -17,8 +17,17 @@ import selectors from "../selectors";
 import App from "../components/App";

 export function bootstrapStore(client, services) {
+  window.isActive = true;
+  window.addEventListener("blur", () => {
+    console.log("blur");
+    window.isActive = false;
+  });
+  window.addEventListener("focus", () => {
+    console.log("focus");
+    window.isActive = true;
+  });
   const createStore = configureStore({
-    log: getValue("logging.actions"),
+    log: true, // getValue("logging.actions"),
     timing: getValue("performance.actions"),
     makeThunkArgs: (args, state) => {
       return Object.assign({}, args, { client }, services);
```
This is the same problem as #3033.

closing, as we will not do this in the short term w/o source maps...
Dup of https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1317721
@asolove and I talked offline and had some interesting takeaways:

1. CodeMirror children implicitely depend on the codemirror document being set. i.e. breakpoints should be added after the document is set. This means that the Editor document should be set in component will receive props and the breakpoints should be set in in component did update. We can have some assertions that guard against mistakes.

2. CodeMirror perf comes from using codemirror's operation method. The API is a callback `cm.operation(() => {})`. It would be nice to use CM's two low level methods startOperation and endOperation.

3. It's possible that two children might have some state dependencies that will need to move up to redux. This is generally nice. With that said, we should be careful because sometimes we fire actions that don't change the state.

4. toggleBreakpoint and toggleBreakpointDisabledStatus could move to the editor actions. [gist](https://gist.github.com/cea1a446f2b3efa78e6cefa51f03f68f)

5. expressions can be killed [gist](https://gist.github.com/jasonLaster/65db67960708fa14482a6df127a67095)

Things might seem a bit confusing as teams are moving from Bugzilla to GitHub and all of this is still in discussion/transition. For now, [debugger.html](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html) and [perf.html](https://github.com/devtools-html/perf.html) can be found on GitHub. Thanks @zimbabao and @codehag!


yes, we were skipping an old test. hopefully it will be stable now
I made a couple updates:

1. support removing a breakpoint in a generated source
2. added an integration test for toggling bps in a generated source
3. support jumping between original and generated sources
I've substantially simplified things based on my discussion with @jasonLaster and @codehag's code review comments. I think this small PR is now ready to go. Waiting to hear back from CodeMirror about how to batch editor changes.
Looks like `doc.setGutterMarker` does not exist in the panels version of codemirror. We should probably update codemirror on the panel and continue from there 
A couple of thoughts about it
- [ ] Use the HOC pattern for tabs (i.e split to `Tabs.js` and `Tab.js`)
- [ ] Use more generic naming  i.e `SourceTabs` to `Tabs`
- [ ] Separate tab actions from source actions file #3666
- [ ] Have separate reducers for the tabs #3646
- [ ] Remove dependencies on source urls

> The problem is that we rely on the breakpoint client location, which does not update based on the sliding. We can either update it to do that, or stop using the breakpoint client entirely. The benefit is that we can simplify the system so the redux store is the one source of truth.
>

I did a bit of dbg hacking with Jaideep today and got the bp bug is now ready to merge with some caveats:
1. Toggling sources requires a cm upgrade in a new PR

I will take a look at getting that mochitest up and running / add a test!

We have the following cases with the debugger interacting with client breakpoints:
- Debugger is reloaded (client breakpoints are discarded)
- Debuggee is reloaded (client breakpoints are used to break immediately if a breakpoint is detected.)

If we clear the client breakpoints, this would simplify our code (which would be great). The drawback being that we will need to pause everything on the debuggee until we know that we do not need to break on an early breakpoint, this might be disruptive to the user. What do you folks think?

I suspect there might be a deeper problem in how we are adding/syncing breakpoints. If it is jumping when the debugger is reloaded, then this is likely the case....

I might also be confused because of how we are calling client / server breakpoints...  this might need of renaming -- the client here is really the debugger frontend code, and what is referred to as client breakpoints in the code is a representation on the client of the server breakpoints, as far as I understand.
looking into the failure on removing breakpoints might have an idea what the issue is ...

# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3309?src=pr&el=h1) Report

> The diff coverage is `n/a`.

[Continue to review full report at Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3309?src=pr&el=continue).
> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3309?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [a7ebeaa...2e95201](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3309?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

The issue here is that JSON isn't itself valid, stand-alone JavaScript. So when the string is passed to the [debugger.html parser](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/utils/parser/utils/ast.js#L23), it fails. It shouldn't inhibit the debugger since the failure only means that particular script will be omitted from the AST for the HTML page.

@darkwing Are you able to debug other scripts on the page?

I could build in more intelligence into `parse-script-tags` to respect the `type` attribute and thereby not try to parse non-JS code but it wouldn't prevent that error from printing when a script tag contained otherwise invalid JS. Provided debugging works well otherwise, a simpler solution might be to either make the warning more descriptive or suppress the warning altogether in this scenario.
Interesting.  The button's title is "Search for sources (⌘+P)" so maybe that should also be changed if it's different functionality?

> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3361?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [0533fbd...d1b0204](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3361?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

After thinking about it a bit more, I think we first want to simplify how we store prefs. There are two problems that I see with prefs:

1. it's possible the current value of prefs is different from the current value of the store
2. the code is making the reducers ugly! 

Here's a patch where we remove some of the pref updating logic from the reducers. (In my mind, this should be our first goal) 💃 

```diff
diff --git a/src/reducers/breakpoints.js b/src/reducers/breakpoints.js
index 8769f0a..7df4fd1 100644
--- a/src/reducers/breakpoints.js
+++ b/src/reducers/breakpoints.js
@@ -53,10 +53,6 @@ function update(
       const newState = addBreakpoint(state, action);
       // TODO: remove this when we have a prefs reducer
       const stateWithShim = addPendingBreakpoint(newState, action);
-      setPendingBreakpoints(stateWithShim);
-
-      // const stateWithShim = addPrefBreakpoint(newState, action);
-
       return stateWithShim;
     }

diff --git a/src/reducers/ui.js b/src/reducers/ui.js
index ef56e94..6c9876d 100644
--- a/src/reducers/ui.js
+++ b/src/reducers/ui.js
@@ -98,18 +98,6 @@ function update(
     case "TOGGLE_FILE_SEARCH_MODIFIER": {
       const actionVal = !state.getIn(["fileSearchModifiers", action.modifier]);

-      if (action.modifier == "caseSensitive") {
-        prefs.fileSearchCaseSensitive = actionVal;
-      }
-
-      if (action.modifier == "wholeWord") {
-        prefs.fileSearchWholeWord = actionVal;
-      }
-
-      if (action.modifier == "regexMatch") {
-        prefs.fileSearchRegexMatch = actionVal;
-      }
-
       return state.setIn(["fileSearchModifiers", action.modifier], actionVal);
     }

@@ -123,11 +111,9 @@ function update(

     case "TOGGLE_PANE": {
       if (action.position == "start") {
-        prefs.startPanelCollapsed = action.paneCollapsed;
         return state.set("startPanelCollapsed", action.paneCollapsed);
       }

-      prefs.endPanelCollapsed = action.paneCollapsed;
       return state.set("endPanelCollapsed", action.paneCollapsed);
     }
```

Isn't it nice, it's great! It's the best! 

---

But... if we take the prefs out of the reducers, how do we update the prefs? I think there are two ways that come to mind. 

1. introduce a prefs reducer
2. add a store subscriber


Here is what the subscriber would look like:

```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/bootstrap.js b/src/utils/bootstrap.js
index 9231c5c..31bcfac 100644
--- a/src/utils/bootstrap.js
+++ b/src/utils/bootstrap.js
@@ -31,6 +31,8 @@ export function bootstrapStore(client, services) {
     store.dispatch
   );

+  store.subscribe(() => updatePrefs(store.getState()));

   return { store, actions, selectors };
 }

diff --git a/src/utils/prefs.js b/src/utils/prefs.js
index 7ecc5c5..ea59137 100644
--- a/src/utils/prefs.js
+++ b/src/utils/prefs.js
@@ -51,4 +51,14 @@ if (prefs.debuggerPrefsSchemaVersion !== prefsSchemaVersion) {

+export function updatePrefs(state) {
+  prefs.each(prefName => {
+    const selector = selectors[`get${capitalize(prefName)}`];
+    const prefValue = selector(state);
+    if (prefs[prefName] !== prefValue) {
+      prefs[prefName] = prefValue;
+    }
+  });
+}
+
```

Both methods would work, but i think there are some advantages to using a subscriber. The subscriber does not care about the actions that should change the state. It also is not interested in how the state was changed. It JUST cares that the state changed. Think of this like a component, the component UI does not care when or why the data changed, it just reflects the current state of the data in UI form. 


--- 

Going back to the initial question of pending breakpoints. At the moment I assume that we have a `breakpoints.pendingBreakpoints` field, but we **should** kill it because its redundant.

Here's a new selector that is all we would need.

```diff
+ function getPendingBreakpoints(state) {
+   const breakpoints = getBreakpoints(state);

+   return breakpoints.map(breakpoint => {
+     return breakpoint
+       .omit("location.sourceId")
+       .omit("generatedLocation.sourceId");
+   });
+ }
```


Here is what everything would look like together [branch](https://github.com/jasonLaster/debugger.html/commit/3c7938c282fef4de752094e65f8c76331f921d3b). Note the insane amount of :red: everywhere. This is a massive cleanup :)

---

So, what does this mean going forward for other fields we would like to persist:

1. add a pref field
2. add a selector that matches the form `get<PrefField>`
3. update a reducer `getInitialState` function

This is very similar to what we do now, except you **DONT** have to think about how the pref is updated.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3364?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [0533fbd...becb75e](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3364?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

@clarkbw suggests trying a middleware solution

https://github.com/clarkbw/Gecko-Profiler-Addon/commit/d86dcf0c4158c14a04337c7b9c5de11a9a613eee
I'll jump on this. Easing back in and I've used this recently. 😄 
I think both ideas have some good stuff in there. I think one issue with the subscriber is that it relies on duplicating state, rather than our use case, which is that we have data that is at the moment only represented in prefs. Subscribers work best if we have a state that needs to be persisted, but we don't have that. A good example of a place where this would fail is pendingBreakpoints. Also, The example that you gave is a good one: `fileSearchCaseSensitive` for instance has no representation in the application aside from in prefs, and would not be updated unless it is somehow represented in state. 

I think that's pointing us to the real issue we are having actually. We do not have a reducer clearly showing what is happening in the persisted state (prefs). This means that we do not have a single store. We have multiple stores. And that is what we are missing. I mistakenly thought that we should get rid of PendingBreakpoints, but perhaps what we need is a place where the persisted state is represented, since it is effectively application state. Otherwise we are breaking from the idea of having a single store. (this is where my misconception came from)

While I think that @clarkbw has an interesting proposal, I do not think it is the best case for us, as it introduces unnecessary complexity where we already have other tools that can accomplish the same thing. Also, it will not resolve the issue that we are using state that isnt in our central reducer.

What I would propose, @jasonLaster is that we combine parts of both our ideas, both 1 & 2. 

Instead, we combine what we have now, plus a clear representation of persisted state. For this we would use a "PersistedState" reducer, which represents the missing application state. But rather than what I initially suggested of directly updating prefs, we are instead using this state to represent the persisted state.
We only act on changes to the `PersistedState` reducer, rather than the overall state. It would look something like this:

```javascript
// @flow

/**
 * Persisted State reducer
 * @module reducers/persisted-state
 */
import * as I from "immutable";

import { prefs } from "../utils/prefs";
import {
  makePendingLocationId,
  createPendingBreakpoint
} from "../utils/breakpoint";
import makeRecord from "../utils/makeRecord";

export function initialState() {
  return makeRecord(restorePersistedData)();
}

function update(state = initialState(), action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case "ADD_BREAKPOINT": { // we can still have fine grained control of our state
      const newState = addPendingBreakpoint(state, action); // we are being declaritive here
      prefs.pendingBreakpoints = newState.get('pendingBreakpoints'); // and we are being declarative here
      return newState;
    }
    // ... and others
    default: {
      return state;
    }
  }
}

function addPendingBreakpoint(state, action) {
  if (action.status === "done") {
    const { value: { breakpoint, previousLocation } } = action;
    const pendingBreakpoint = createPendingBreakpoint(breakpoint);
    const id = pendingBreakpoint.id;

    if (previousLocation) {
      const previousLocationId = makePendingLocationId(previousLocation);
      return state
        .deleteIn(["pendingBreakpoints", previousLocationId])
        .setIn(["pendingBreakpoints", id], pendingBreakpoint);
    }

    return state.setIn(["pendingBreakpoints", id], pendingBreakpoint);
  }

  return state;
}

function restorePersistedData() {
  return I.Map(prefs);
}

export default update;
```

And we use subscribers to listen to the changes, knowing when our persisted data is changed via this reducer

# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3370?src=pr&el=h1) Report

I can reproduce it with the booleans example without having to clone the repository: https://devtools-html.github.io/debugger-examples/examples/booleans/

this should be fixed post refactor.

I'm seeing an error w/ `clearDebugLine` not having the editor:

```js
	  clearDebugLine(selectedFrame) {
	    if (selectedFrame) {
	      var line = selectedFrame.location.line;
	      if (this.debugExpression) {
	        this.debugExpression.clear();
	      }
	
	      this.state.editor.codeMirror.removeLineClass(line - 1, "line", "new-debug-line");
	    }
	  }
```

This is what i'm currently seeing:

![](http://g.recordit.co/5rl94cKFi6.gif)

what do you mean by the line numbers are off:

1. the line number value is wrong
2. they're hidden and the breakpoint is hidden
3. the debugger does not jump to the correct location
4. some other weird behavior :)

fixed
fixed
@firhatsungkar any luck?
When I see it, what I see is that the debugger breaks and highlights an incorrect line, e.g. breaking on line 403, it would then effectively be on line 402 (determined by looking at the variable values), and will then be a line behind constantly.

Additionally, the call stack has the wrong line number in, iirc.

I've also seen this type of behaviour with xml files, but that may be a slightly different issue.
We discussed this a fair bit so I'll try to summarize why I think this should be avoided.

Quoting @jasonLaster on Slack "we introduced the panel scrollbar so that we would let you scroll for variables". I assume we are talking about the object inspector here? I think this is a valid use case for having a horizontal scrollbar, but it should be restricted to the object inspector panels.

1. The design of this sidepanel has actions/buttons both on the right and on the left. With a horizontal scrollbar some of them are always hidden.
2. Visually, all the centered buttons such as "Expand rows" in the screenshot seem out of place.
3. Finally, a horizontal scrollbar is usable if you are using a touchpad with 2-finger scroll, but it is difficult for mouse users.

[When testing, this scrollbar got mostly triggered by the callstack (with not-that-long function/file names). Maybe the callstack should not trigger an overflow? Related issue about ellipsis in the callstack with good inputs from @bomsy : https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/issues/3259]
duplicate of #3280
Ahh, I wonder if this is a dupe of #3282? The server is off by one with XUL documents (affects the old ui too). 


Ahh 
Happy to land this and iterate. I'll leave some UX feedback on the parent issue
- [x] the results should scroll
- [ ] the selection highlight is too strong in dark theme
- [ ] we should exclude watch expressions (sources should have a URL)

---

STEPS TO REPRODUCE:

1)  Load the testcase I'm about to attach in a clean profile. (https://bug1383209.bmoattachments.org/attachment.cgi?id=8888883)
2)  Cmd+Option+K to open the console.
3)  Click the link on the "ReferenceError" line (linking to line 1201 of the JS file).

ACTUAL RESULTS: Debugger opens, loads JS file, does NOT scroll to the line.

EXPECTED RESULTS: Scroll to the line and select it.  This works fine with the old debugger frontend.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION: If the debugger is already open when loading the testcase, then scrolling to the line does work, but it doesn't get highlighted (unlike with the old debugger frontend).

This bug makes debugging errors really annoying.

I just ran through this and I couldn't create the same issue.  Here are my steps.

1. nightly, clean profile
```bash
export TMP_PROFILE=`mktemp -d`
/Applications/FirefoxNightly.app/Contents/MacOS/firefox --profile $TMP_PROFILE
```
1.  open devtools / settings turn on browser chrome / remote debugging in bottom right
1.  go to `about:addons` / appearance and enable dark compact theme
1. restart browser
```bash
/Applications/FirefoxNightly.app/Contents/MacOS/firefox --profile $TMP_PROFILE --jsdebugger
```
1.  open `about:addons` again (I used restore prev. session, probably doesn't matter)
1.  switch to debugger
1. open `AddonManager.jsm` via cmd+P 
1. set breakpoint on the first line of `getPrefferedIconURL` (2335) 
  1. Note that function search for `getPrefferedIconURL` didn't work
1. switch extensions tab (within about:addons) and back to the appearance tab
1. the breakpoint will hit. Add these 3 watches:

aAddon.id
aAddon.icons
aAddon.iconURL

1.  hit continue a few times

AR: Seems to work as expected for me.

UER: Watch expression values remain after continue.

![](http://g.recordit.co/gRe69H1SxU.gif)
this is a bad fix https://gist.github.com/97dcee6db4dae1daa098ba5bd24cc466

but demonstrates the problem is w/ long content

ah, `height: fit-content` where supported fixes the problem with commandbar. :wink:
http://caniuse.com/#feat=intrinsic-width
`.secondary-panes { height: fit-content; overflow-y: scroll; }`
So, that "patch" I thought over... Leads to broken output. Also, since Sticky is still "in development" as a spec, this particular case *seems* to not be specified. If you check Note 3 in [the sticky spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-position-3/#sticky-pos) it reads:

> Say what happens if it already overflows the containing block

I think this is the case we're hitting. Since the height is already "overflowing" the boundary, the engines aren't sure what to do with a sticky node. Gecko is choosing to stick it, what I'd say is correct since that provides the functionality we want. While Blink is choosing to keep the sticky node as a relative item constantly.

So, that work-around is not going to work until we have it specified who is at fault and the other engine fixes it. Still working on another patch though.

However as a note for future reference as well, this can only accurately be tested with a full page refresh cycle. Live editing is triggering different interactions compared to a fresh load in different cases. In both Chrome and FF. It's quirky for sure.
Here is a patch for styling project search:
https://gist.github.com/jasonLaster/b02fa35094cf5ef3d5055d329408aefc
@jbhoosreddy @nchevobbe i'm worried that to properly diagnose this, we need to know about the grip we're previewing which will change OI in a decently large way.

Also just realized the other step to reproduce this is to try deleting a number of watch expressions at once.  

1. Create several watch expressions for anything
1. Pause on a breakpoint where the sidebar overflows
2. Click the remove button on the first watch expression
3. The other watch expressions should slide up and the next remove button should be under your mouse however the scroll bar often interferes with the button
After playing with different tabs states before step 3 (reload dualuse.html), it shows different UI issues (log.js tab is closed, or active/not active): debugger line is not seleceted but maybe flashes, or tab is not selected.

that sounds good - i like having parent passed down to `renderItem`. I'll see what I can do with the `tree` component.
This is very similar to two different cases:

1. pretty printing a generated source
2. pretty printing an original source

I was thinking to do it directly in the `createNode` function, which would then return `{name, path, contents, parent}`.
This way we would have access to the parent item for each item (and not only in the renderItem function).

<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/fe51b57fb6c4c07c76125a42ff3a4227/Screen%20Shot%202017-07-26%20at%2012.28.53%20PM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-07-26 at 12.28.53 PM.png' width=374>

Yulia and I were discussing this in the Slack channel just now as well. She has an [alternative approach](https://devtools-html.slack.com/files/yulia/F6E3LDUUU/foo.diff) worth looking into as well which removes sticky entirely and applies some minor restructuring to get the same effect.

Both are completely valid solutions. The only worry about `sticky` is if the spec and/or implementations changes in the future then this *could* break. But I find that personally doubtful since the case we are hitting is an inner niche-case with the spec and the overflow sets the wrapper up around that flaw.

Either way works though. So whatever is desired I can amend the PR to implement.

> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3465?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [a3cff60...c137889](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3465?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Here's a small testcase:

turns out we assume that if the URL doesn't have an extension it is a dir

```
const testData = [
  {
    "id": "server1.conn13.child1/37",
    "url": "https://unpkg.com/codemirror@5.15.2",
  },
  {
    "id": "server1.conn13.child1/39",
    "url": "https://unpkg.com/codemirror@5.15.2/mode/xml/xml.js",
  },
]
```
I've dug into this for the past 4 hours w/ @gregtatum's help and we found that the code assumed that new URL parts that were already in the tree would be directories (see [here]).

Fixing this requires a fancy rigermarole where we take the child who's a source and replace it with a new directory subtree. Not fun.

I'll make a small patch tomorrow, that keeps the tree from blowing up, but we'll need to revisit this [branch] after release and put in a real fix.


[branch]:https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/compare/next...jasonLaster:fix-source-tree-paths?expand=1

[here]:https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/next/src/utils/sources-tree.js#L200-L202
@codehag @jasonLaster with the changes you've made I think this is ready. I have nothing else I need to modify. There are some changes in the PR though that seem to have come from elsewhere. 🙁 
hmm I poked around in this code a bit -- I will also take a look.

Is the last comment's test case a good testing point?
:+1: great suggestions

I think I found what is happening. the last bracket requires that you step over twice, it doesnt show the return value on the first step.

I think we don't want to have two steps at the end of the function. any ideas on how to avoid that?
Would be great to have an STR for this!
closing in favor of #3469 
Please make sure the new setup handles the issue raised in https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/issues/3450 (the error text bleeding all over the UI) sanely.
Yes, of course :) we have decided that it doesn't make sense to give so much information, and we are opting for a simplified text which is "no results found" rather than including the attempted search query.
we can do this post release
i will close this for now as we have a fix. we can revisit if there are issues
@codehag Could you file an issue about that? Preferably with a gif or some video on what's going on. I can take a look at it tomorrow or over the weekend.
As a future note it would be good to make sure the Flow types are all fully covered and strict here. I think that will help for longer term maintenance. I also think having code comments with examples of why a lot of the code is there would help. This code is hard and mysterious so I think it would be good have lots of comments everywhere.

For instance with the existing isDirectory function the following comment would have helped immensely:

```js
/**
 * This function is a simple heuristic to initially determine if something is a directory or a file.
 *
 * Check for the case of "/" or "".
 * Plus match for "path/to/something/"
 * Do no match for "path/to/something", assume that is a file.
 */
function isDirectory() { ... }
```
> I think we don't want to have two steps at the end of the function. any ideas on how to avoid that?

So Debugger API shows return value at [Debugger.Frame::onPop](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Tools/Debugger-API/Debugger.Frame) -- you cannot ignore this one. It comes after last step, which can be somehow ignored, but it is hard. A frame has location (offset) property, but it does not give you much.
> I think we don't want to have two steps at the end of the function. any ideas on how to avoid that?

This is what I was looking into when I found that I couldn't see the &lt;return&gt; at all.

I'm not sure whether I'll implement it or not, but the basic idea is to add a new debugger API so the server can tell whether it's stopped at a return opcode, and, if so, keep going until the frame pop.
@tromey That would be nice.
> to add a new debugger API 

@tromey I don't think you needs a new api -- all you need to disable breaking point in SpiderMonkey just before frame pops. (I know how to do it for wasm part -- I was modeling it after the JS behavior)
@tromey @yurydelendik lets move this to a more specific bugzilla ticket.
> lets move this to a more specific bugzilla ticket

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=923975

I'm wondering now if it would make more sense to only dim the `[default properties]` node when it is collapsed (as well as the `__proto__` one), and render it as a regular one when it is expanded.

The reason being that if you did expand the node, this means that you are probably interested in seeing what's inside, and having the node semi-transparent does not help.

As a bonus, it would be super easy to do :)

I am not to sure what is being changed here, are the screenshots before and after or are they showing two different changes?
I just wanted to start on this issue but it seems to be fixed!
@jasonLaster can you verify?
nice find.

@ryanjduffy do you think this is related to `parse-script-tags`?
Likely. I'll look into it
The issue here is that JSON isn't itself valid, stand-alone JavaScript. So when the string is passed to the [debugger.html parser](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/utils/parser/utils/ast.js#L23), it fails. It shouldn't inhibit the debugger since the failure only means that particular script will be omitted from the AST for the HTML page.

@darkwing Are you able to debug other scripts on the page?

I could build in more intelligence into `parse-script-tags` to respect the `type` attribute and thereby not try to parse non-JS code but it wouldn't prevent that error from printing when a script tag contained otherwise invalid JS. Provided debugging works well otherwise, a simpler solution might be to either make the warning more descriptive or suppress the warning altogether in this scenario.
@ryanjduffy are you still looking into this?
Hmm, actually it throws the same error when in a SCRIPT tag within (index):

<img width="540" alt="err" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46655/28078769-8abfc296-662b-11e7-8b7f-50d6efb48d65.png">

I should point out I'm seeing this in Chrome, BTW.
thanks - we should at a minimum add a mochitest so that we can lock down this behavior.
@darkwing - do you have an STR for this case?

:thumbsup: 


After thinking about it a bit more, I think we first want to simplify how we store prefs. There are two problems that I see with prefs:

1. it's possible the current value of prefs is different from the current value of the store
2. the code is making the reducers ugly! 

Here's a patch where we remove some of the pref updating logic from the reducers. (In my mind, this should be our first goal) 💃 

```diff
diff --git a/src/reducers/breakpoints.js b/src/reducers/breakpoints.js
index 8769f0a..7df4fd1 100644
--- a/src/reducers/breakpoints.js
+++ b/src/reducers/breakpoints.js
@@ -53,10 +53,6 @@ function update(
       const newState = addBreakpoint(state, action);
       // TODO: remove this when we have a prefs reducer
       const stateWithShim = addPendingBreakpoint(newState, action);
-      setPendingBreakpoints(stateWithShim);
-
-      // const stateWithShim = addPrefBreakpoint(newState, action);
-
       return stateWithShim;
     }

diff --git a/src/reducers/ui.js b/src/reducers/ui.js
index ef56e94..6c9876d 100644
--- a/src/reducers/ui.js
+++ b/src/reducers/ui.js
@@ -98,18 +98,6 @@ function update(
     case "TOGGLE_FILE_SEARCH_MODIFIER": {
       const actionVal = !state.getIn(["fileSearchModifiers", action.modifier]);

-      if (action.modifier == "caseSensitive") {
-        prefs.fileSearchCaseSensitive = actionVal;
-      }
-
-      if (action.modifier == "wholeWord") {
-        prefs.fileSearchWholeWord = actionVal;
-      }
-
-      if (action.modifier == "regexMatch") {
-        prefs.fileSearchRegexMatch = actionVal;
-      }
-
       return state.setIn(["fileSearchModifiers", action.modifier], actionVal);
     }

@@ -123,11 +111,9 @@ function update(

     case "TOGGLE_PANE": {
       if (action.position == "start") {
-        prefs.startPanelCollapsed = action.paneCollapsed;
         return state.set("startPanelCollapsed", action.paneCollapsed);
       }

-      prefs.endPanelCollapsed = action.paneCollapsed;
       return state.set("endPanelCollapsed", action.paneCollapsed);
     }
```

Isn't it nice, it's great! It's the best! 

---

But... if we take the prefs out of the reducers, how do we update the prefs? I think there are two ways that come to mind. 

1. introduce a prefs reducer
2. add a store subscriber


Here is what the subscriber would look like:

```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/bootstrap.js b/src/utils/bootstrap.js
index 9231c5c..31bcfac 100644
--- a/src/utils/bootstrap.js
+++ b/src/utils/bootstrap.js
@@ -31,6 +31,8 @@ export function bootstrapStore(client, services) {
     store.dispatch
   );

+  store.subscribe(() => updatePrefs(store.getState()));

   return { store, actions, selectors };
 }

diff --git a/src/utils/prefs.js b/src/utils/prefs.js
index 7ecc5c5..ea59137 100644
--- a/src/utils/prefs.js
+++ b/src/utils/prefs.js
@@ -51,4 +51,14 @@ if (prefs.debuggerPrefsSchemaVersion !== prefsSchemaVersion) {

+export function updatePrefs(state) {
+  prefs.each(prefName => {
+    const selector = selectors[`get${capitalize(prefName)}`];
+    const prefValue = selector(state);
+    if (prefs[prefName] !== prefValue) {
+      prefs[prefName] = prefValue;
+    }
+  });
+}
+
```

Both methods would work, but i think there are some advantages to using a subscriber. The subscriber does not care about the actions that should change the state. It also is not interested in how the state was changed. It JUST cares that the state changed. Think of this like a component, the component UI does not care when or why the data changed, it just reflects the current state of the data in UI form. 


--- 

Going back to the initial question of pending breakpoints. At the moment I assume that we have a `breakpoints.pendingBreakpoints` field, but we **should** kill it because its redundant.

Here's a new selector that is all we would need.

```diff
+ function getPendingBreakpoints(state) {
+   const breakpoints = getBreakpoints(state);

+   return breakpoints.map(breakpoint => {
+     return breakpoint
+       .omit("location.sourceId")
+       .omit("generatedLocation.sourceId");
+   });
+ }
```


Here is what everything would look like together [branch](https://github.com/jasonLaster/debugger.html/commit/3c7938c282fef4de752094e65f8c76331f921d3b). Note the insane amount of :red: everywhere. This is a massive cleanup :)

---

So, what does this mean going forward for other fields we would like to persist:

1. add a pref field
2. add a selector that matches the form `get<PrefField>`
3. update a reducer `getInitialState` function

This is very similar to what we do now, except you **DONT** have to think about how the pref is updated.


@clarkbw suggests trying a middleware solution

https://github.com/clarkbw/Gecko-Profiler-Addon/commit/d86dcf0c4158c14a04337c7b9c5de11a9a613eee
closing this as pending BPs are now in their own reducer
I think both ideas have some good stuff in there. I think one issue with the subscriber is that it relies on duplicating state, rather than our use case, which is that we have data that is at the moment only represented in prefs. Subscribers work best if we have a state that needs to be persisted, but we don't have that. A good example of a place where this would fail is pendingBreakpoints. Also, The example that you gave is a good one: `fileSearchCaseSensitive` for instance has no representation in the application aside from in prefs, and would not be updated unless it is somehow represented in state. 

I think that's pointing us to the real issue we are having actually. We do not have a reducer clearly showing what is happening in the persisted state (prefs). This means that we do not have a single store. We have multiple stores. And that is what we are missing. I mistakenly thought that we should get rid of PendingBreakpoints, but perhaps what we need is a place where the persisted state is represented, since it is effectively application state. Otherwise we are breaking from the idea of having a single store. (this is where my misconception came from)

While I think that @clarkbw has an interesting proposal, I do not think it is the best case for us, as it introduces unnecessary complexity where we already have other tools that can accomplish the same thing. Also, it will not resolve the issue that we are using state that isnt in our central reducer.

What I would propose, @jasonLaster is that we combine parts of both our ideas, both 1 & 2. 

Instead, we combine what we have now, plus a clear representation of persisted state. For this we would use a "PersistedState" reducer, which represents the missing application state. But rather than what I initially suggested of directly updating prefs, we are instead using this state to represent the persisted state.
We only act on changes to the `PersistedState` reducer, rather than the overall state. It would look something like this:

```javascript
// @flow

/**
 * Persisted State reducer
 * @module reducers/persisted-state
 */
import * as I from "immutable";

import { prefs } from "../utils/prefs";
import {
  makePendingLocationId,
  createPendingBreakpoint
} from "../utils/breakpoint";
import makeRecord from "../utils/makeRecord";

export function initialState() {
  return makeRecord(restorePersistedData)();
}

function update(state = initialState(), action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case "ADD_BREAKPOINT": { // we can still have fine grained control of our state
      const newState = addPendingBreakpoint(state, action); // we are being declaritive here
      prefs.pendingBreakpoints = newState.get('pendingBreakpoints'); // and we are being declarative here
      return newState;
    }
    // ... and others
    default: {
      return state;
    }
  }
}

function addPendingBreakpoint(state, action) {
  if (action.status === "done") {
    const { value: { breakpoint, previousLocation } } = action;
    const pendingBreakpoint = createPendingBreakpoint(breakpoint);
    const id = pendingBreakpoint.id;

    if (previousLocation) {
      const previousLocationId = makePendingLocationId(previousLocation);
      return state
        .deleteIn(["pendingBreakpoints", previousLocationId])
        .setIn(["pendingBreakpoints", id], pendingBreakpoint);
    }

    return state.setIn(["pendingBreakpoints", id], pendingBreakpoint);
  }

  return state;
}

function restorePersistedData() {
  return I.Map(prefs);
}

export default update;
```

And we use subscribers to listen to the changes, knowing when our persisted data is changed via this reducer

I just set a breakpoint earlier in the function than I had been doing, that seems to have somehow kicked the debugger back onto the right line numbers, such that now I can't reproduce.

@jbhoosreddy are you currently on this?

no i've not started it yet. was going to pick it up next..
I took a look, and here is what is happening:

debug expressions is a single instance, each time we switch files the debug expression is pointing to a line on a single source. however when you select it via the callstack, it sets a new line.

I think we might want to rethink using the debug line to show where in the callstack a given call was made. If we use it, then it would be confusing -- as we are not currently paused at that location. Maybe we need a different visual cue for this?

Another issue i noticed, the debug line does not get cleared. This is also related to us only recording one instance of the debug line, and when we are switching we do not have that instance to clear

We might want to do this after asolove's debug line refactor
@Anzumana just jump in try one. no worries

Just spoke offline, and we only want to show one frame's debug line.
the util is in on core. I'm not working on using it yet.

opening (just incase)
I opened this bug to fix it:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1388128

If you want a quick fix you can:

1. go to about:config
2. search for `debugger.pending-breakpoints` 
3. set the value to `{}`

<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/3dbe8ec84ae32336d29941be3c31fcf6/Screen%20Shot%202017-08-07%20at%205.20.58%20PM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-08-07 at 5.20.58 PM.png' width=929>

Quite a bit changed in the code base, I will open a new pr based off of this one with the changes!
closing this as i assume we'll get the latest reps with the new OI
The tests failed two linting rules that did not get caught in my editor first time around. I closed the PR until I could get back around to fixing them. Will update this PR  in a bit to fix the lint rules below.
```/home/ubuntu/debugger.html/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Frames/WhyPaused.js
  22:1   error  Component definition is missing display name  react/display-name
  48:16  error  Component definition is missing display name  react/display-name
```

I'm actually a little confused by the error tbh. It's trivially fixed with
```
function renderMessage(pauseInfo: Pause) {
  if (!pauseInfo) {
    return null;
  }

  const message = get(pauseInfo, 'why.message');
  if (message) {
    return (
      <div className={'message'}>
        {message}
      </div>
    );
  }

  const exception = get(pauseInfo, 'why.exception');
  if (exception) {
    return (
      <div className={'message warning'}>
        {renderExceptionSummary(exception)}
      </div>
    );
  }

  return null;
}
renderMessage.displayName = 'whyMessage';

export default function renderWhyPaused({ pause }: { pause: Pause }) {
  const reason = getPauseReason(pause);

  if (!reason) {
    return null;
  }

  return (
    <div className={'pane why-paused'}>
      <div>
        {L10N.getStr(reason)}
      </div>
      {renderMessage(pause)}
    </div>
  );
}
renderWhyPaused.displayName = 'whyPaused';
```
That felt a little naive, but that's mostly because I didn't fully grok the necessity of the displayName when reading the ESLint rule. If that's an acceptable solution, I'll go ahead and push it up.
@wldcordeiro Looks like the `Breakpoints` component is listed twice. 
Feel free to leave the pr open :)

It's all good

## Version **3.5.1** just got published. 
[Update to this version instead 🚀](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/compare/greenkeeper%2Fwebpack-3.5.1?expand=1) 

<details>
<summary>Release Notes</summary>
<strong>v3.5.1</strong>

<h1>Bugfixes:</h1>
<ul>
<li>fix invalid syntax when using non-number ids with Scope Hoisting</li>
</ul>
</details>

<details>
<summary>Commits</summary>
<p>The new version differs by 3 commits.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/webpack/webpack/commit/5be959311a746b976a0a56625cc4372307b351ed"><code>5be9593</code></a> <code>3.5.1</code></li>
<li><a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/webpack/webpack/commit/43d877fc377921607b94442921d516918240d437"><code>43d877f</code></a> <code>Merge pull request #5460 from webpack/bugfix/stringify-concated</code></li>
<li><a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/webpack/webpack/commit/b05b49b0f07863055b09dbbf8c68756d9b275edc"><code>b05b49b</code></a> <code>fix invalid generated code with scope hoisting and non-number ids</code></li>
</ul>
<p>See the <a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/webpack/webpack/compare/75a8ffec0a8ab2f1f07a950ee965a31917af5fe9...5be959311a746b976a0a56625cc4372307b351ed">full diff</a></p>
</details>
I'm not sure the correct treatment should be. Perhaps we replace the file icon with the eye? What does chrome do?


Thanks for filing @SebastianZ. Here is a quick sketch for the solution and [docs](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/docs/local-development.md#context-menus) for context menus.

```diff
diff --git a/assets/panel/debugger.properties b/assets/panel/debugger.properties
index 73dc6aa..984975d 100644
--- a/assets/panel/debugger.properties
+++ b/assets/panel/debugger.properties
@@ -221,6 +221,10 @@ breakpointMenuItem.enableAll=Enable all breakpoints
 breakpointMenuItem.disableAll=Disable all breakpoints
 breakpointMenuItem.deleteAll=Remove all breakpoints

+# LOCALIZATION NOTE (breakpointMenuItem.deleteAll): Access key to remove
+# all of the breakpoints
+breakpointMenuItem.deleteAll.accesskey=r
+
 # LOCALIZATION NOTE (breakpoints.header): Breakpoints right sidebar pane header.
 breakpoints.header=Breakpoints

diff --git a/src/actions/breakpoints.js b/src/actions/breakpoints.js
index 4cf283d..2c6e92f 100644
--- a/src/actions/breakpoints.js
+++ b/src/actions/breakpoints.js
@@ -192,6 +192,15 @@ export function toggleAllBreakpoints(shouldDisableBreakpoints: boolean) {
   };
 }

+export function removeAllBreakpoints() {
+  return async ({ dispatch, getState }: ThunkArgs) => {
+    const breakpoints = getBreakpoints(getState());
+    for (let [, breakpoint] of breakpoints) {
+      await dispatch(removeBreakpoint(breakpoint.location));
+    }
+  };
+}
+
 export function remapBreakpoints(sourceId: string) {
   return async ({ dispatch, getState, sourceMaps }: ThunkArgs) => {
     const breakpoints = getBreakpoints(getState());
diff --git a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
index c6eb577..f0ecab6 100644
--- a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
+++ b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
@@ -73,6 +73,21 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
     }
   }

+  showContextMenu(e, breakpoint) {
+    const { removeAllBreakpoints } = this.props;
+    event.preventDefault();
+
+    const removeBreakpoints = {
+      id: "node-menu-close-tab",
+      label: L10N.getStr("breakpointMenuItem.deleteAll"),
+      accesskey: L10N.getStr("sourceTabs.removeBreakpoints.key"),
+      disabled: false,
+      click: () => removeAllBreakpoints()
+    };
+
+    // show menu is our API for creating context menus
+    showMenu(e, [{ item: removeBreakpoints }]);
+  }
+
   selectBreakpoint(breakpoint) {
     const sourceId = breakpoint.location.sourceId;
     const line = breakpoint.location.line;
@@ -102,6 +117,7 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
           "is-conditional": isConditional
         }),
         key: locationId,
+        onContextMenu: e => this.showContextMenu(e, source),
         onClick: () => this.selectBreakpoint(breakpoint)
       },
       dom.input({
```

closing as we're waiting for prettier to support this
closing as we're not going to invest in WTR
I made a quick branch w/ @wooorm here: https://github.com/jasonLaster/devtools-linters/blob/master/bin/prose.js


it's borrowed from this example: https://github.com/github/opensource.guide/blob/gh-pages/test/prose
After talking with @Ronsho, it's not clear that we want to do this.

The reason for that is that snapshots and helpers still belong in a tests directory.

Also, jest and immutable use the `__tests__` folder pattern
closing for now as we're not going to do this follow up
I think we should wait on this feature until we start the editor-style search work.

also when the debugger is paused, F5 only refreshes the browser if dev tools is focussed
Can the background colours be made much darker? 

the current low contrast theme hurts my eyes compared to Chrome's dark theme 
Or more like a 0.12.2 version. One test failing is waiting for root function `foo` to be displayed as `foo()`, where we display it as `function foo()` because we don't simplify root functions (for the console).
Maybe omitting the `function` keyword should just be for TINY mode so it behaves like expected in the debugger and in console (for top-level and then nested functions).

For the scope mutation test, it looks like we don't wait enough time: the action is done but nodes are not shown yet. I may re-use what I do on [webconsole test](http://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/client/webconsole/new-console-output/test/mochitest/browser_webconsole_object_inspector.js#43), i.e. wait for dom mutation on the tree instead of waiting for the action to end, which is implementation specific.

I'll tackle that on Monday, **I want** it to be done !

So, there is a bit in `projectSearch.css` that sets the the width of `.search-container` to `calc(100% - 1px)`. This creates an actual gap between `search-container` and adjacent divs.

This gap of 1px looks to be used so that the `splitter` div can build some sort of vertical partition. However, it also allows for text from any underlying elements to show through this 1px gap. 

Any tips on how to close this gap? Unfortunately, setting the `.search-container` width to `calc(100%)` doesn't work too well as it ruins the splitter div.
Not sure. It'd be nice to compare other panes like the sources sidebar and
editor pane.
On Mon, Aug 14, 2017 at 1:25 PM Adam Ki Jensen <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> .search-container to calc(100% - 1px). This creates an actual gap between

> sort of vertical partition. However, it also allows for text from any
> underlying elements to show through this 1px gap.

> .search-container width to calc(100%) doesn't work too well as it ruins
> the splitter div.

```diff
+      highlightItems[0] &&
+      expanded.has(this.props.getPath(highlightItems[0]))
```

@nt1m is working on this
If the `acceltext` attribute is set on the `<menuitem>` then it will print it out with native styling. For instance, `acceltext="⌘P"`. However, in order for this to happen automatically the menuitem has to  [have a `key` attribute pointing to a xul key](https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/b95b1638db48fc3d450b95b98da6bcd2f9326d2f/layout/xul/nsMenuFrame.cpp#1032).

The `acceltext` could potentially be generated explicitly via ShortcutUtils.jsm from a `<key>` element, and the old debugger does do that [for things like tooltips](https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/b95b1638db48fc3d450b95b98da6bcd2f9326d2f/devtools/client/debugger/views/toolbar-view.js#55).  If we want to avoid using `<key>` elements altogether then we could modify that module a bit to accept metadata.

How do we do keyboard shortcut handling in the debugger, again?
We use key-shortcuts via a shortcuts context: https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/components/Editor/index.js#L207
OK, and how is the menu that ultimately calls `onToggleBreakpoint` constructed?
I think I'd modify [KeyShortcuts.stringify](https://github.com/devtools-html/devtools-core/blob/2c01041a1812a3dafee3367ac3e72fd8518fecd3/packages/devtools-modules/src/key-shortcuts.js#L152) function to more closely match [ShortcutUtils.prettifyShortcut](https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/toolkit/modules/ShortcutUtils.jsm), and then manually set the `acceltext` to that value whenever the `menuitem` is created

```js
(function(a, b,c){return arguments;})(1,2,3)
```

I get the following grip : 

```json
{
  "type": "object",
  "actor": "server2.conn3.child19/obj30",
  "class": "Arguments",
  "extensible": true,
  "frozen": false,
  "sealed": false,
  "ownPropertyLength": 5,
  "preview": {
    "kind": "Object",
    "ownProperties": {
      "0": {
        "configurable": true,
        "enumerable": true,
        "writable": true,
        "value": 1
      },
      "1": {
        "configurable": true,
        "enumerable": true,
        "writable": true,
        "value": 2
      },
      "2": {
        "configurable": true,
        "enumerable": true,
        "writable": true,
        "value": 3
      }
    },
    "ownSymbols": [],
    "ownPropertiesLength": 5,
    "ownSymbolsLength": 1,
    "safeGetterValues": {}
  }
}
```


so yes, we'd need more than just the grip.
We may have a `propertiesNameMap` prop, which could look something like : 
```js
  propertiesNameMap: {
    "0": "a",
    "1": "b",
    "2": "c",
  }
```
that we could use to render node label in the ObjectInspector.

Sebastian
May I work on this?
Here's some simpler example code:

```html
<script>
function test(y) {
  let x = 2;
  return y(x);
}

let a = test(function foo(bar) {
  return bar * 4;
});
console.log(a);
</script>
```

Breaking at `return bar * 4;` won't show a preview for `bar`.

Sebastian

Ugh, spoke too soon on this; `setEmptyLines` isn't being re-run when opening a pretty-print tab.

I also noticed that opening a pretty-print tab calls `getEmptyLines` 5 times and somehow the *last* call sets our line array to `undefined` which messes everything up.  It seems like `setEmptyLines` doesn't get called for pretty-print tabs.

After stepping through each commit, it was `636024e2341a4bc7c90887b988d91949ca61cd28` that broken the pretty-print tab.

copy-paste from the issue:

User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:53.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/53.0
Build ID: 20170418123106

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open attached example.html in Firefox 53.0 or Firefox Developer Edition 54.0a2 (both affected, new and old debugger).
2. Open Developer Tools, go to Debugger.
3. Set breakpoint in line 8 (first statement in block).
4. Look at debugger Variables/Scopes view.
5. Click "step over".
6. Look at debugger Variables/Scopes view again.


Actual results:

- At step 4: letBlock/constBlock variables (bound via let/const) are shown as undefined in debugger (in Firefox 53.0 or Firefox Developer Edition 54.0a2)
- At step 6, in Firefox 53.0 (old debugger): letBlock/constBlock shown as "(uninitialized)"
- At step 6, in Firefox Developer Edition 54.0a2 (debugger.html): letBlock/constBlock shown as null


Expected results:

- Block scoped variables should not visibly change their value when an unrelated statement is executed. Should either stay at undefined or shown "(uninitialized)" all the time (until declaration statement is actually reaced).
- Firefox Developer Edition 54.0a2 / debugger.html behavior is especially confusing, since "null" indicates explicit intent by the programmer, unlike undefined which is more sensible.
I am closing this for now as we have removed the WTR
Lets pair when you have time, ping me on slack when you are ready -- @yulia is my handle on there!
@zacck would love the help!
Its looking for identity equality, the issue is with how jest/jasmine's `toBe` vs `toEqual` does comparisons. `toBe` expects identity, `toEqual` expects same value. 

this can be fixed by changing
 
`expect(getMode(source)).toBe({ name: "javascript" });`

to 

`expect(getMode(source)).toEqual({ name: "javascript" });`
Oh stupid me!
XD nah its all good. we all do it

It wasn't centered before, but now I noticed it. I think we can fix it by adding the following to the css you wrote:

```diff
diff --git a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css
index e2903f85..4e2e2fa4 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css
+++ b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css
@@ -11,9 +11,13 @@
   user-select: none;
 }

+.source-header .new-tab-btn svg {
+  display: block;
+}
+
 .source-header .new-tab-btn {
   padding: 4px;
-  margin: 4px 2px 2px 2px;
+  margin: 4px 0px 0px 3px;
   fill: var(--theme-content-color3);
   transition: 0.1s ease;
   align-self: center;
```

results in:
<img width="134" alt="screen shot 2017-08-22 at 5 32 45 pm" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26968615/29573693-f289d5f6-875f-11e7-9c32-d09777901a79.png">

a couple of notes:
- you will notice that i set the svg to display block. This is because browser display images with a small border at the bottom -- this is what was making it look a little off
- there appears to be another margin at play on the bottom, and the right margin probably isnt necessary

Can you play around with it a bit and see what looks best to you? thanks!

Issue #3259 was closed as duplicate of this one. Attaching my screenshot here, because even if both issues deal with function names being truncated, the STRs are different. 

<img width="315" alt="image" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1141550/27833520-7aa67628-60d3-11e7-89ce-c1f492020697.png">

The issue here occurs when there is not enough space to display both the function name and the script location. The function name is truncated, making it difficult to understand the call stack.

@nyrosmith thanks! you are totally right
The docker image is really tough to update.
I think we'll need to do a shortterm fix to land this. 


What I think we should do is update [codemirror] on the fly. 

```diff


diff --git a/bin/run-mochitests-docker b/bin/run-mochitests-docker
index dec6611..7d85d17 100755
--- a/bin/run-mochitests-docker
+++ b/bin/run-mochitests-docker
@@ -2,7 +2,12 @@

 node ./bin/publish-assets

+
+bundle="/devtools/client/sourceeditor/codemirror/codemirror.bundle.js"
+curl "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mozilla/gecko-dev/48ea452803907f2575d81021e8678634e8067fc2$bundle" > codemirror.js
+
 docker run -it \
+  -v "`pwd`/codemirror.js:/gecko/$bundle" \
   -v `pwd`/assets/build/debugger.js:/gecko/devtools/client/debugger/new/debugger.js \
   -v `pwd`/assets/build/pretty-print-worker.js:/gecko/devtools/client/debugger/new/pretty-print-worker.js \
   -v `pwd`/assets/build/parser-worker.js:/gecko/devtools/client/debugger/new/parser-worker.js
   ```
[codemirror]: http://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/client/sourceeditor/codemirror/codemirror.bundle.js

and a test:


```diff
--- a/src/actions/tests/breakpoints.spec.js
+++ b/src/actions/tests/breakpoints.spec.js
@@ -272,6 +272,32 @@ describe("breakpoints", () => {
     );
   });

+  it("should set the condition and enable a breakpoint", async () => {
+    const { dispatch, getState } = createStore(simpleMockThreadClient);
+
+    const loc = {
+      sourceId: "a",
+      line: 5,
+      sourceUrl: "http://localhost:8000/examples/a"
+    };
+
+    await dispatch(actions.newSource(makeSource("a")));
+    await dispatch(actions.addBreakpoint(loc));
+    await dispatch(actions.disableBreakpoint(loc));
+
+    expect(selectors.getBreakpoint(getState(), loc).condition).toBe(null);
+
+    await dispatch(
+      actions.setBreakpointCondition(loc, {
+        condition: "const foo = 0",
+        getTextForLine: () => {}
+      })
+    );
+    const breakpoint = selectors.getBreakpoint(getState(), loc);
+    expect(breakpoint.disabled).toBe(false);
+    expect(breakpoint.condition).toBe("const foo = 0");
+  });
+
   it("should remap breakpoints on pretty print", async () => {
   ```

<details>
<summary>Release Notes</summary>
<strong>v3.5.1</strong>

<h1>Bugfixes:</h1>
<ul>
<li>fix invalid syntax when using non-number ids with Scope Hoisting</li>
</ul>

<li><a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/webpack/webpack/commit/43d877fc377921607b94442921d516918240d437"><code>43d877f</code></a> <code>Merge pull request #5460 from webpack/bugfix/stringify-concated</code></li>
<li><a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/webpack/webpack/commit/b05b49b0f07863055b09dbbf8c68756d9b275edc"><code>b05b49b</code></a> <code>fix invalid generated code with scope hoisting and non-number ids</code></li>
</ul>
<p>See the <a href="https://urls.greenkeeper.io/webpack/webpack/compare/75a8ffec0a8ab2f1f07a950ee965a31917af5fe9...5be959311a746b976a0a56625cc4372307b351ed">full diff</a></p>
</details>

Yeah, that's a great point
This was fixed when we fixed #4106
Maybe related to #3597 ?
The underlying problem is not fixed. Just a small change at step 5:

1. Go to http://www.example.org/
2. Open the debugger
3. Make sure it is set to "Ignore exceptions"
4. Add a new watched expression: "foo.bar" (without quotes)
5. Set the debugger to "Pause on all exceptions"
6. The debugger pauses: "ReferenceError: foo is not defined"
7. Remove the watched expression
8. Click ▷ (Resume)
possibly related to https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/issues/3390
closing because it's a dupe #3597

@jasonLaster @codehag I would like to tackle this bug. That would be kind of you that you could feedback on some questions, thanks:
1. What is the blackboxed state?
2. I found `checkPendingTabs` doesn't exist so it looks like we have to implement it. What is the purpose of this function, checking what "pending" tabs? I could found `TabList` [1] in the state's sources, which carries js sources even beyond the todo-mvc website (or "tab") at which I am debugging, see the screenshot below. Guess that tab list is what we should check?

[1] https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/c6fe43a2870c08feb985d5e1a2af4629389ea6ad/src/reducers/sources.js#L33

<img width="1391" alt="screen shot 2017-09-14 at 1 37 52 am" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5627487/30391818-63f8ec92-98ed-11e7-8ac3-c29b2e45377b.png">


ok, thanks
This is a start on this issue:
```diff
diff --git a/src/actions/sources.js b/src/actions/sources.js
index 5e644db3..6027e169 100644
--- a/src/actions/sources.js
+++ b/src/actions/sources.js
@@ -92,6 +92,7 @@ export function newSource(source: Source) {
     }
 
     await checkSelectedSource(getState(), dispatch, source);
+    await checkPendingTabs(getState(), dispatch, source); // this should restore blackbox state for sources
     await checkPendingBreakpoints(getState(), dispatch, source);
   };
```

Sure! I was in the same place last week.

1. 'retext-equality' should be installed into the devtools-linter project
2. After that install completes, cd into the debugger.html folder, and run `yarn link devtools-linters` to make sure the devtools-linter is linked and then
3. run `yarn lint-md` If all is good, this will run through all of the debugger files, look for errors, and print to the console

Hope that helps :)
@steffiau OK, so I think I am on to what is going on... it seems to be the file routing:
1. in devtools-linters/natural-language/preset.js change the following line from:
 `path.join(__dirname, "../../../assets/", "dictionary.txt"),"utf8")`
to
  `path.join(__dirname, "dictionary.txt"),"utf8")`

2.  add `require("retext-equality"),` after `require("retext-emoji"),`
3.  `yarn link` in devtools-linters
4.  in debugger.html  run `yarn link devtools-linters`
5. and still in debugger.html, run`yarn lint-md`
6.  profit!!! hopefully, you will see the errors/typos like this:
"77:125-77:130  warning  `actor` may be insensitive, use `performer`, `star`, `artist` instead"

We can check the file routing if that works :)

```diff
     const renderItem = (item, depth, focused, _, expanded, { setExpanded }) => {

         autoExpandDepth={1}
-        focused={results[0]}
         getParent={item => null}
         getPath={getFilePath}
         renderItem={renderItem}
diff --git a/src/components/shared/ManagedTree.js b/src/components/shared/ManagedTree.js
index 2c26e95f..d40d0e66 100644
--- a/src/components/shared/ManagedTree.js
+++ b/src/components/shared/ManagedTree.js
@@ -94,14 +94,17 @@ class ManagedTree extends Component {
     const expanded = this.state.expanded;

     // This file is visible, so we highlight it.
-    if (expanded.has(this.props.getPath(highlightItems[0]))) {
+    if (
+      highlightItems[0] &&
+      expanded.has(this.props.getPath(highlightItems[0]))
+    ) {
       this.focusItem(highlightItems[0]);
     } else {
       // Look at folders starting from the top-level until finds a
       // closed folder and highlights this folder
       const index = highlightItems
         .reverse()
-        .findIndex(item => !expanded.has(this.props.getPath(item)));
+        .findIndex(item => item && !expanded.has(this.props.getPath(item)));
       this.focusItem(highlightItems[index]);
     }
   }
```
This should get us to focus on the first match, still a lil bit buggy (which we can fix) but gets us there
![](http://g.recordit.co/7Nl7mXqtHh.gif)
@jasonLaster Just reverted the err throwing behavior as you suggested

```diff
+function printCLI() {
+  console.log(`Press r to re-run`)
+  console.log(`Press q to quit`)
+  const r = process.prompt()
+  console.log(r)
+
+  if (r == "r") {
+    runMochitests()
+  } else {
+    shell.exit()
+  }
 ```

@hughugsy it's yours!
Removing breakpoint is fairly straightforward. Here is a sample patch to get started.

````patch
diff --git a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
index 4b7d40bc..294fca49 100644
--- a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
+++ b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
@@ -42,7 +42,8 @@ type Props = {
   removeBreakpoints: BreakpointsMap => void,
   toggleBreakpoints: (boolean, BreakpointsMap) => void,
   toggleAllBreakpoints: boolean => void,
-  toggleDisabledBreakpoint: number => void
+  toggleDisabledBreakpoint: number => void,
+  setBreakpointCondition: Location => void
 };
 
 function isCurrentlyPausedAtBreakpoint(pause, breakpoint) {
@@ -100,6 +101,7 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
       toggleBreakpoints,
       toggleAllBreakpoints,
       toggleDisabledBreakpoint,
+      setBreakpointCondition,
       breakpoints
     } = this.props;
 
@@ -114,6 +116,9 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
     const disableSelfLabel = L10N.getStr("breakpointMenuItem.disableSelf");
     const disableAllLabel = L10N.getStr("breakpointMenuItem.disableAll");
     const disableOthersLabel = L10N.getStr("breakpointMenuItem.disableOthers");
+    const removeConditionLabel = L10N.getStr(
+      "breakpointMenuItem.removeCondition"
+    );
 
     const deleteSelfKey = L10N.getStr(
       "breakpointMenuItem.deleteSelf.accesskey"
@@ -138,6 +143,9 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
     const disableOthersKey = L10N.getStr(
       "breakpointMenuItem.disableOthers.accesskey"
     );
+    const removeConditionKey = L10N.getStr(
+      "breakpointMenuItem.removeCondition.accesskey"
+    );
 
     const otherBreakpoints = breakpoints.filter(b => b !== breakpoint);
     const enabledBreakpoints = breakpoints.filter(b => !b.disabled);
@@ -220,6 +228,14 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
       click: () => toggleBreakpoints(true, otherEnabledBreakpoints)
     };
 
+    const removeCondition = {
+      id: "node-menu-remove-condition",
+      label: removeConditionLabel,
+      accesskey: removeConditionKey,
+      disabled: false,
+      click: () => setBreakpointCondition(breakpoint.location, "")
+    };
+
     const items = [
       { item: enableSelf, hidden: () => !breakpoint.disabled },
       { item: disableSelf, hidden: () => breakpoint.disabled },
@@ -241,6 +257,10 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
       {
         item: disableOthers,
         hidden: () => otherEnabledBreakpoints.size === 0
+      },
+      {
+        item: removeCondition,
+        hidden: () => !breakpoint.condition
       }
     ];
 

````
For the edit condition, we want to do some more work. We want to move out the state logic from the Editor component to the redux store. We have a ui specific reducer which can maintain it.

Here's a patch which should start that work.

If the `acceltext` attribute is set on the `<menuitem>` then it will print it out with native styling. For instance, `acceltext="⌘P"`. However, in order for this to happen automatically the menuitem has to  [have a `key` attribute pointing to a xul key](https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/b95b1638db48fc3d450b95b98da6bcd2f9326d2f/layout/xul/nsMenuFrame.cpp#1032).

The `acceltext` could potentially be generated explicitly via ShortcutUtils.jsm from a `<key>` element, and the old debugger does do that [for things like tooltips](https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/b95b1638db48fc3d450b95b98da6bcd2f9326d2f/devtools/client/debugger/views/toolbar-view.js#55).  If we want to avoid using `<key>` elements altogether then we could modify that module a bit to accept metadata.

How do we do keyboard shortcut handling in the debugger, again?
OK, and how is the menu that ultimately calls `onToggleBreakpoint` constructed?
I think I'd modify [KeyShortcuts.stringify](https://github.com/devtools-html/devtools-core/blob/2c01041a1812a3dafee3367ac3e72fd8518fecd3/packages/devtools-modules/src/key-shortcuts.js#L152) function to more closely match [ShortcutUtils.prettifyShortcut](https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/toolkit/modules/ShortcutUtils.jsm), and then manually set the `acceltext` to that value whenever the `menuitem` is created
We use key-shortcuts via a shortcuts context: https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/components/Editor/index.js#L207
that was me messing around on the circle VM :) sorry

@eoger mind sharing the STR? I'd like to see if i can reproduce this and see what's going on
I believe this bug is coming the fact that we "move" breakpoints to keep them in the same original location when the user reloads.

Scenario: 
1. the app is using sourcemaps to bundle three files (a,b,c). 
2. The user adds a breakpoint to file b, line 10
3. the user changes file a
4. the user reloads the page
5. the debugger sees that the file b, line 10 breakpoint points to the wrong generated location
6. the debugger "moves" the breakpoint to the new location, which means 
  6.a it updates the original locations in the UI
  6.b it creates a new breakpoint on the server
  6.c it forgets to remove the old breakpoint on the server
  
This diff is a sketch of what i think the solution should look like. When we see the new and old generated location is different, we remember to clean up after ourselves and remove the breakpoint.

```diff

diff --git a/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js b/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js
index ee220b4..4237afb 100644
--- a/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js
+++ b/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js
@@ -64,6 +64,10 @@ export async function syncClientBreakpoint(
       newGeneratedLocation
     );

+    if (locationMoved(generatedLocation, newGeneratedLocation)) {
+      await client.removeBreakpoint(generatedLocation);
+    }
+
     const breakpoint = {
       ...pendingBreakpoint,
       id: makeLocationId(newLocation),
diff --git a/src/client/firefox/commands.js b/src/client/firefox/commands.js
index 40f2232..e405e9d 100644
--- a/src/client/firefox/commands.js
+++ b/src/client/firefox/commands.js
@@ -125,9 +125,9 @@ function setBreakpoint(
     });
 }

-function removeBreakpoint(breakpoint: Breakpoint) {
+function removeBreakpoint(generatedLocation) {
   try {
-    const id = makeLocationId(breakpoint.generatedLocation);
+    const id = makeLocationId(generatedLocation);
     const bpClient = bpClients[id];
     if (!bpClient) {
       console.warn("No breakpoint to delete on server");
```
This is fixed here:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1394495

Awesome stuff @nyrosmith!  To avoid lint warnings in your stories, check out what I did here:

https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3825/files

Essentially you import `PropTypes` and then add:

```js
MyFactory.propTypes = {
   dir: PropTypes.string,
   theme: PropTypes.string
 };
```

Removing breakpoint is fairly straightforward. Here is a sample patch to get started.

````patch
diff --git a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js

--- a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
+++ b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js

   toggleAllBreakpoints: boolean => void,
-  toggleDisabledBreakpoint: number => void
+  toggleDisabledBreakpoint: number => void,
+  setBreakpointCondition: Location => void
 };
 
 function isCurrentlyPausedAtBreakpoint(pause, breakpoint) {
@@ -100,6 +101,7 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
       toggleBreakpoints,
       toggleAllBreakpoints,
       toggleDisabledBreakpoint,
+      setBreakpointCondition,
       breakpoints
     } = this.props;
 
@@ -114,6 +116,9 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
     const disableSelfLabel = L10N.getStr("breakpointMenuItem.disableSelf");
     const disableAllLabel = L10N.getStr("breakpointMenuItem.disableAll");
     const disableOthersLabel = L10N.getStr("breakpointMenuItem.disableOthers");
+    const removeConditionLabel = L10N.getStr(
+      "breakpointMenuItem.removeCondition"
+    );
 
     const deleteSelfKey = L10N.getStr(
       "breakpointMenuItem.deleteSelf.accesskey"
@@ -138,6 +143,9 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
     const disableOthersKey = L10N.getStr(
       "breakpointMenuItem.disableOthers.accesskey"
     );
+    const removeConditionKey = L10N.getStr(
+      "breakpointMenuItem.removeCondition.accesskey"
+    );
 
     const otherBreakpoints = breakpoints.filter(b => b !== breakpoint);
     const enabledBreakpoints = breakpoints.filter(b => !b.disabled);
@@ -220,6 +228,14 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
       click: () => toggleBreakpoints(true, otherEnabledBreakpoints)
     };
 
+    const removeCondition = {
+      id: "node-menu-remove-condition",
+      label: removeConditionLabel,
+      accesskey: removeConditionKey,
+      disabled: false,
+      click: () => setBreakpointCondition(breakpoint.location, "")
+    };
+
     const items = [
       { item: enableSelf, hidden: () => !breakpoint.disabled },
       { item: disableSelf, hidden: () => breakpoint.disabled },
@@ -241,6 +257,10 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {

         item: disableOthers,
         hidden: () => otherEnabledBreakpoints.size === 0
+      },
+      {

       }
     ];
````

```diff
  */
-function updateTabList(state: OuterState, url: ?string, tabIndex?: number) {
+function updateTabList(state: OuterState, source: ?Object, tabIndex?: number) {
   let tabs = state.sources.get("tabs");
 
-  const urlIndex = tabs.indexOf(url);
-  const includesUrl = !!tabs.find(tab => tab == url);
+  const urlIndex = tabs.indexOf(source.url);
+  const includesUrl = !!tabs.find(tab => tab.url == source.url);
+  const { url, isBlackboxed } = source;
+  const tab = { url, isBlackboxed }
 
   if (includesUrl) {
     if (tabIndex != undefined) {
-      tabs = tabs.delete(urlIndex).insert(tabIndex, url);
+      tabs = tabs.delete(urlIndex).insert(tabIndex, tab);
     }
   } else {
-    tabs = tabs.insert(0, url);
+    tabs = tabs.insert(0, tab);
   }
 
   prefs.tabs = tabs.toJS();
```
