   getSources,
   (tabs: TabList, sources: SourcesMap) => {
     return tabs
-      .map(tab => getSourceByUrlInSources(sources, tab))
+      .map(tab => getSourceByUrlInSources(sources, tab.url))
       .filter(source => source);
   }
 );

```
It would be cool if could inline the files regardless of wasm blob scheme and show the wasm and blob schemes in the icon on the left. Here is a small test that we can make green.

Step one - get the folder structure working
Step two - show the icons in the tree

```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js b/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js
index 74df6a5..1be684c 100644
--- a/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js
+++ b/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js
@@ -66,6 +66,33 @@ describe("sources-tree", () => {
       expect(source1Node.name).toBe("source1.js");
     });

+    it("supports wasm and blobs", () => {
+      const sourcesList = [
+        "http://webassembly.org/demo/Tanks/Build/UnityLoader.js",
+        "http://webassembly.org/demo/Tanks/TemplateData/UnityProgress.js",
+        "blob:http://webassembly.org/5a1e6d45-c42c-c947-b420-7cc7ee7a94f5",
+        "http://webassembly.org/demo/Tanks/",
+        "wasm:http://webassembly.org/demo/Tanks/Build/UnityLoader.js:da39a3ee5e6b4b0d",
+        "wasm:blob:http://webassembly.org/5a1e6d45-c42c-c947-b420-7cc7ee7a94f5:1d94844895c5ea0e"
+      ];
+      const sources = sourcesList.map((url, index) => ({
+        url,
+        id: index
+      }));
+
+      /*
+      - http://webassembly.org
+        - demo/Tanks
+          - 5a1e6d45-c42c-c947-b420-7cc7ee7a94f5
+          - (index)
+          - Build
+            - UnityLoader.js:da39a3ee5e6b4b0d
+        -TemplateData
+          - UnityProgress.js
+          - 5a1e6d45-c42c-c947-b420-7cc7ee7a94f5:1d94844895c5ea0e
+      */
+    });
+
```
For the edit condition, we want to do some more work. We want to move out the state logic from the Editor component to the redux store. We have a ui specific reducer which can maintain it.

Here's a patch which should start that work.

````patch

         expanded: expanded,

       onClick: e => {

+        clearShownSource();

     });

The profiles @bwhitty gave are really actionnable.
Did you tried looking at the first one related to debugger?
https://perfht.ml/2vSYpDo
 - Select "Main thread", i.e. the first timeline (that's where the debugger UI lives)
 - In the call tree, see the first line? i.e. `exports.makeInfaillible`
    expand this 4 or 5 times, you will see `newSource` from `debugger.js`
 - Now expand this a lot, you will go through a lot of React stacks, but will also find debugger frames

Hopefully this will help you understanding what is slow.

This slowness is very easily reproducible on slack, just reload it and see your browser freeze if you have the debugger opened.
> In the call tree, see the first line? i.e. exports.makeInfaillible expand this 4 or 5 times, you will see newSource from debugger.js

From this you could see that `SourcesTree.componentWillReceiveProps` is slow.
Mostly because of immutable.js. It see a 3x win if I replace it with a naive manual check.

See this patch (sorry, it is against the webpack bundle):
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/page.cgi?id=splinter.html&bug=1399242&attachment=8909337

Also, we call a url module helper too many times. We shoud avoid calling it especially in the hot codepaths. Note that we should be using web "URL" constructor instead of this.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/URL
@bwhitty i'm going to close this as it is not something that we can "fix" per-se. We take perf seriously though and are always looking at improving our start up time. Thanks for sharing
Here's a bug that discusses it: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1392869

Steps to reproduce:

Open the debugger pane in the developer tools, and load a page that asynchronously loads many scripts. This is common behavior when developing with requirejs and running unoptimized, since in this case, requirejs dynamically creates new script tags to load dependencies.

I have created a benchmark to demonstrate this issue:

https://github.com/jwmerrill/async-script-load-benchmark


Actual results:

Having the debugger pane open makes asynchronously loading additional scripts much slower. Note that the problem also appears if you have the dev tools open and you have ever visited the debugger panel. It does not need to be the currently active panel, you just need to have activated it at some point during your session.

In Firefox 57 (currently nightly), loading 1000 files in this tool takes 1 second with dev tools closed, and 11 seconds with dev tools open to the debugger pane. Loading 2000 files takes 2 seconds with dev tools closed, and 30 seconds with the debugger open. Loading 5000 files takes 6 seconds with dev tools closed, and 2.5 minutes with the debugger open. In all cases, the branching factor was set to 2.

The problem seems to be worse in Firefox 55 and Firefox 56.


Expected results:

Loading scripts with the debugger open should be fast, and the amount of time that it takes to load each new script should not increase with the number of scripts you have already loaded (the benchmark shows superlinear scaling with the number of scripts you attempt to load).

Chrome takes a similar amount of time to run the benchmark with dev tools closed, but opening dev tools only slows things down by 20-40% instead of a factor of 10 or more.

--------

1. When the debugger tab is open in Dev tools, the page doesn't reload at all, and the whole browser starts slowing down and doesn't even respond to clicking the close button. But, if I press F12, the Dev tools window does get closed and suddenly the whole browser starts running smoothly.
2. This behaviour doesn't happen if some other tab in Dev Tools is open, only with the Debugger tab.
3. Setting breakpoints in Dev Tools further slows down JS execution and starts hanging the browser.

Correct, this is happening for FF 56. Perf is decidedly different based on which devtool panel is open, with the debugger grinding the entire browser to a halt. Unfortunately this is an internal application I can't share. I'm not entirely sure how to create a replication with the same size as the main bundles of this app. I am presuming that to be causing the issues.
Thanks @jasonLaster. Could I possibly get some more information on what the root cause was and why it's a wontfix? I had to switch to Chrome to work on this product, and it handles everything gracefully. Don't take that as a dig, as it isn't, it's just more information that this isn't, for instance, some insane anomaly of a project.
@codehag Awesome! It's quite possible it's a large file issue as the bundle and source map could be enormous. I will check again with Nightly once #3885 gets released. Would that fix be integrated tonight? (sorry, not sure what Nightly build/release process is like)
Thanks for the report! If I got it right, this is happening in the panel for 56, do you have a test case we can try out?
ok, thanks for the info. We will investigate and get back to you :)

     const validSources = sources
       .valueSeq()
-      .filter(source => source.has("text"))

       await dispatch(searchSource(source, query));

         matches

results in:
<img width="134" alt="screen shot 2017-08-22 at 5 32 45 pm" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26968615/29573693-f289d5f6-875f-11e7-9c32-d09777901a79.png">

a couple of notes:
- you will notice that i set the svg to display block. This is because browser display images with a small border at the bottom -- this is what was making it look a little off
- there appears to be another margin at play on the bottom, and the right margin probably isnt necessary

Can you play around with it a bit and see what looks best to you? thanks!
hmm i quite like the curved shape... but for now lets leave it sharp (since everything else has sharp edges). we can revisit this later. Thanks for the work!

I believe this is a duplicate of #3479
I can't reproduce it with either of the apps. I think it's a source-mapping issue. Is there any way I can check if there is anything wrong with our source-maps? 

When I set the breakpoints in the generated source, the debugger jumps to the correct mapped line. but when I set a break point in a mapped source mostly the debugger does not halt there. So some part of the debugger is not happy with our source map. 

Also as I said, when stepping though the lines it constantly jumps between the mapped and the generated source.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3940?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [b8445ff...55eda16](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3940?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

I can confirm I am getting this regularly while debugging. It doesn't happen when I open the debugger, but when I'm stepping the debugger will sometimes simply open this "eval code" tab and keep reloading it.  

In my case the pattern seems to be:
- hit a breakpoint anywhere
- step in as much as you can
- debugger end up loading the eval code tab

At this point the debugger thinks it is stopped in this eval code:
<img width="608" alt="image" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1141550/30198946-ba0f89fa-9470-11e7-8322-b621c0bba31a.png">

I think the call stack shown in the tab can help here:

```
Could not load the source for debugger eval called from moz-extension://4ade278d-b4ba-1c45-9398-7d33741c5aa6/ - eval code.
Error: Failed to fetch debugger eval called from moz-extension://4ade278d-b4ba-1c45-9398-7d33741c5aa6/ - eval code. Code 2152857618.
Stack: onResponse@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/shared/DevToolsUtils.js:471:23
onStopRequest@resource://gre/modules/NetUtil.jsm:131:17
enter@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:356:5
_pushThreadPause@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:539:5
_pauseAndRespond@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:754:7
pauseAndRespond@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:895:16
_makeOnEnterFrame/<@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:774:11
@debugger eval called from moz-extension://4ade278d-b4ba-1c45-9398-7d33741c5aa6/ - eval code:2:1
eval@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/webextension-inspected-window.js:465:22
handler@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/shared/protocol.js:1079:19
onPacket@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/main.js:1797:15
receiveMessage@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/shared/transport/transport.js:761:7
enter@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:356:5
unsafeSynchronize@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:1095:7
_makeOnStep/<@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/server/actors/script.js:848:27
startAnimationTimer@http://www.piskelapp.com/static/js/piskel-animated-preview.js?20170502:46:1
startAnimationTimer/imageInfo.timer<@http://www.piskelapp.com/static/js/piskel-animated-preview.js?20170502:56:7
setTimeout handler*startAnimationTimer@http://www.piskelapp.com/static/js/piskel-animated-preview.js?20170502:50:23
```
I think I have some ideas about this.

First of all the react extension is calling inspectedWindow.eval every 1s if React is not defined on the page: https://github.com/facebook/react-devtools/blob/2c1789627caa6d2fff3790564658a61cdf326b4b/shells/webextension/src/main.js#L21

So I think this issue should mostly happen on sites which do not use React.

Now, looking at the stack trace, it seems like the request to perform an eval was received while debugging. And then instead of exiting the current frame (?) and resuming the execution we somehow enter the frame where the eval code from the extension is evaluated. But we can't load the source from the moz-extension protocol. Not sure why we keep reloading though.

I am not used to the debugger server terminology so this might be half wrong, but I think it's the right track.

+export function highlightMatches(lineMatch) {
+  const { value, column, match } = lineMatch;
+  const len = match.length;
+
+  return (
+    <span className="line-value">
+      <span className="line-match" key={0}>
+        {value.slice(0, column)}
+      </span>

+        {value.substr(column, len)}
+      </span>

+        {value.slice(column + len, value.length)}
+      </span>
+    </span>

if you clear the debugger’s tabs  and pause on exception prefs, you’ll see this:

1. nothing happens 
2. when you select pause on exceptions it tries to load the source of the debuggee eval, it fails to, it shows the error…
3. even if you turn off poe, it will still try loading it because we save the tab url, it is an endless loop of trying because every time rdt evals, it gets a new source, sees its the tab, and tries to load it again

![](http://g.recordit.co/qOadNPSCV1.gif)
ok will do .
thx for the diff
# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3945?src=pr&el=h1) Report

# [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/devtools-html/debugger.html/pull/3967?src=pr&el=h1) Report

@amitzur I tried to come up with a better example: [here](https://salty-dawn.glitch.me/). Unfortunately, this didn't show the scopes...

```js

function stuff() {

  const obj = {
    foo: function() {
      [1,2,3].forEach(function(item) {
        (function yay() {
          console.log("yo")
        })()
      })
    }
  }
  
  obj.foo();
  
}
```

![Screen Shot 2017-09-13 at 4.09.02 PM.png](https://shipusercontent.com/7a0bd02b9f08bed1aaf76f858d3cdf45/Screen%20Shot%202017-09-13%20at%204.09.02%20PM.png)

I think the only solution here is to wrap the text node with a span and give that span the same styling. It's the only element that reaches the right edge.

I made a simplified case here:
The problem:
https://jsfiddle.net/wLsc4unm/1/
The solution:
https://jsfiddle.net/usLszhuL/3/
there are two sources - a bundled and original. See the files in (no domain)
Yeah, this is similar to what @NettaB and Noga came up with. Does this have to do with source maps? I thought the "<" character is added when the function is wrapped in a closure
yeah, it comes from this algorithm: 
https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/src/utils/frame.js#L203
http://johnjbarton.github.io/nonymous/index.html
Good call! Updated the example:
https://cray-scopes.glitch.me/

I'm investigating this ..
@jasonLaster I've changed to error font to style normal.

![after-normal](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17731302/30424688-5cda5f06-994f-11e7-8208-82c43934aa91.png)

So we have a couple of issues with our heuristics for determining what should be pretty printed.
Specifically the utilty `shouldPrettyPrint`.
1) For @clarkbw  case, it was ignored because it had a source map file.
2) For @digitarald case, it is ignored because we determine javascript files by the file extensions in url and these files have no extensions
Too late, but it would be probably useful to keep "errors" text as a comments, so function bailout condition is informed to the reader of the code.
I just wanted note cases we need to handle

- minified js files without sourcemaps
- minified js files with sourcemaps which have 404'd => no sourcemaps
- minified js files without `.js` or any javascript file extension

@tromey this was by design, we felt that inline scripts and evals should be shown when you pause and given a tab, but not shown in the tree. The one caveat is if there is a sourceUrl stanza.

I'd be open to suggestions though. We have all the data client-side so it's just a question of UX.

Likely yes, but we need to make it clear this is missing from previous frontend, and so is a regression and needs to be fixed quicker.
testcase:
```html
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset='utf-8'>
    <meta name='viewport' content='initial-scale=1'>
  </head>
  <body>
    <button type="button">eval something!</button>
    <script>
const script = `console.log('hello world')`;
document.querySelector('button').addEventListener('click', () => eval(script));
    </script>
  </body>
</html>
```

Note this doesn't work in Chrome either.

I'm tending to think this is a bug somewhere other than the debugger.
> In the call tree, see the first line? i.e. exports.makeInfaillible expand this 4 or 5 times, you will see newSource from debugger.js

From this you could see that `SourcesTree.componentWillReceiveProps` is slow.
Mostly because of immutable.js. It see a 3x win if I replace it with a naive manual check.

See this patch (sorry, it is against the webpack bundle):
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/page.cgi?id=splinter.html&bug=1399242&attachment=8909337

Also, we call a url module helper too many times. We shoud avoid calling it especially in the hot codepaths. Note that we should be using web "URL" constructor instead of this.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/URL

A few thoughts @nyrosmith:

1.  The "selected" tab background color for the Sources/Outline tabs are opposite in color to the source tabs:

<img width="432" alt="selectedstate" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46655/30552976-5eed6e0a-9c65-11e7-8fae-6d5b2642361a.png">

We should make those colors consistent.

2.  I'm seeing a scrollbar whenever I open a tree item:

![scrollbars](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46655/30553065-a10af000-9c65-11e7-88d7-37ac685883a1.gif)

3.  The tabs and their content are separated by the [Search] block which I find a bit confusing; IMO we should restore that [Search] blocks to the top.

4.  One side-effect is that if I open a bunch of tree items, swap to the outline tab, then back to the sources tab, the entire tree closes.  We should avoid that for the sake of usability.

what do you mean by container?

> Headers/Panels should at least have list/listitem semantics?

Is this defined somewhere?

Good shout; updates.
Looks like the tree component mentioned above is up to date enough and implements many accessibility improvements from mozilla-central's devtools. 
If local tree component could be updated to the one in devtools-core it would pretty much resolve this bug. 
One serious blocked for just doing that, however, is an issue I just filed https://github.com/devtools-html/devtools-core/issues/695. Ideally it should be handled first before syncing the component.
The same solution as #4067 should do the trick. Updating to the latest devtools-core tree component should fix all keyboard issues.
For anyone planning to resurrect this patch - I am not sure that changing the source map worker in this way is best.  This behavior is relied on by the toolbox to avoid reporting the same source map error multiple times.

Instead, if `fetchSourceMap` fails, then `getOriginalURLs` will report an error.  This can be caught and used.  *However*, the toolbox installs a proxy that reports these errors and returns a non-rejected promise; so an M-C change would be needed as well.
### Magnifying glass icon should have an ARIA role of "presentation" as it doesn't carry any meaningful semantics.
This is an example of how to add an appropriate role to an element. In this case role "presentation" (https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/roles#presentation) to an icon.
```diff
diff --git a/assets/images/Svg.js b/assets/images/Svg.js
index 956fe45b..ab67d81e 100644
--- a/assets/images/Svg.js
+++ b/assets/images/Svg.js
@@ -58,10 +58,11 @@ type SvgType = {
   name: string,
   clasName?: string,
   onClick?: () => void,
-  "aria-label"?: string
+  "aria-label"?: string,
+  role?: string,
 };
 
-function Svg({ name, className, onClick, "aria-label": ariaLabel }) {
+function Svg({ name, className, onClick, "aria-label": ariaLabel, role }) {
   if (!svg[name]) {
     const error = `Unknown SVG: ${name}`;
     if (isDevelopment()) {
@@ -80,6 +81,7 @@ function Svg({ name, className, onClick, "aria-label": ariaLabel }) {
     className,
     onClick,
     ["aria-label"]: ariaLabel,
+    role,
     src: svg[name]
   };
   return <InlineSVG {...props} />;
diff --git a/src/components/shared/SearchInput.js b/src/components/shared/SearchInput.js
index b8966fa1..2359ce6f 100644
--- a/src/components/shared/SearchInput.js
+++ b/src/components/shared/SearchInput.js
@@ -55,10 +55,10 @@ class SearchInput extends Component {
 
   renderSvg() {
     if (this.shouldShowErrorEmoji()) {
-      return <Svg name="sad-face" />;
+      return <Svg name="sad-face" role="presentation" />;
     }
 
-    return <Svg name="magnifying-glass" />;
+    return <Svg name="magnifying-glass" role="presentation" />;
   }
 
   renderArrowButtons() {
```

### A's
Nothing else needs to be done. Button will be in tab order, in fact, no need for special key press handling stuff. <BUTTON> will trigger "click" event when Enter/Space are pressed for free.

I think in for these sort of buttons, switching the drawing color to "focused" one (e.g. blue) would be best. Outline in this case could be avoided. For example, Firefox devtools toolbox tab that is selected changes icon color and text to blue.

You might also want to avoid and unset -moz-appearance for these buttons.

### Ideally, for each result item the labeling should be as follows: aria-labelledby should be pointing to ".title" child and aria-describedby should be pointing to ".subttitle". This will require assigning ID's to each one of them. This will help with the unnecessary verbosity of each result item where the screen reader would not have to utter a complete path for each one of them.

```diff
diff --git a/src/components/shared/ResultList.js b/src/components/shared/ResultList.js
index f50bb20e..4edc3d64 100644
--- a/src/components/shared/ResultList.js
+++ b/src/components/shared/ResultList.js
@@ -40,6 +40,8 @@ export default class ResultList extends Component {
       key: `${item.id}${item.value}${index}`,
       ref: index,
       title: item.value,
+      "aria-labelledby": `${item.id}-title`,
+      "aria-describedby": `${item.id}-subtitle`,
       className: classnames("result-item", {
         selected: index === selected
       })
@@ -47,8 +49,8 @@ export default class ResultList extends Component {
 
     return (
       <li {...props}>
-        <div className="title">{item.title}</div>
-        <div className="subtitle">{item.subtitle}</div>
+        <div id={item.id + "-title"} className="title">{item.title}</div>
+        <div id={item.id + "-subtitle"} className="subtitle">{item.subtitle}</div>
       </li>
     );
   }
```

Here is a gist for how i would do it:

```diff
diff --git a/src/actions/tests/pending-breakpoints.spec.js b/src/actions/tests/pending-breakpoints.spec.js

+    it("hidden breakponts do not create pending bps", async () => {
+      const { dispatch, getState } = createStore(simpleMockThreadClient);
+
+      await dispatch(actions.newSource(makeSource("foo")));
+      await dispatch(
+        actions.addBreakpoint(breakpoint1.location, { hidden: true })
+      );
+      const pendingBps = selectors.getPendingBreakpoints(getState());
+
+      // should be null
+      expect(pendingBps.get(breakpointLocationId1)).toBe(null);
+    });
+
     it("remove a corresponding pending breakpoint when deleting", async () => {
       const { dispatch, getState } = createStore(simpleMockThreadClient);
       await dispatch(actions.newSource(makeSource("foo")));
diff --git a/src/reducers/pending-breakpoints.js b/src/reducers/pending-breakpoints.js

+        return;

+// this is where we load the pending breakpoints when the debugger opens

CI is showing failure:
```
failed test:  devtools/client/debugger/new/test/mochitest/browser_dbg_keyboard_navigation.js 
failed test:  devtools/client/debugger/new/test/mochitest/browser_dbg-wasm-sourcemaps.js

but I don't think there relevant to this PR ?
This is indeed a duplicate of both the previously mentioned issues. IMO best to close this out to focus on the issues with direction resolution actions instead of using the open space for a filler issue.
Also, escape is problematic if say a tooltip is open. As escape should close the tooltips in the editor without removing focus. Escaping within CM is not a clear-cut thing as to what expected results should be.

<kbd><kbd>Shift</kbd>+<kbd>Tab</kbd></kbd> currently has no context in CodeMirror. So we could hijack this as our escape hatch. But, I'd much prefer we try to collaborate with this with the Chrome DevTools and Edge teams as well. This affects all of us from what I can tell and we should all find a consistent way for everyone to implement so this is stable across toolsets. If we do one key combo and another toolset decides `esc` is in fact the proper solution, then we're making a space complex for users that really need these that shouldn't be.
> what do you mean by enabled state? Is this something we do we/ css or JS?

So this is more for the "Pause on Exceptions" multi-state button. In the JS on activation/mod if any of it is "on" we'd have the `aria-pressed` attribute set. When it is turned off, remove the attribute. The rest of the buttons are completely transactional, so the attribute on those isn't needed as I understand things.

>  Improve focus styling. Right now dotted outline does not line up well with icons.

I completely agree. Styling needs to be improved in a few places for accessibility needs. However, this should be well thought through with a designer about the overall look and feel across the toolset. Making something up ad-hoc each time will lead to an inconsistent experience across the tools which isn't good. For now, the focus ring is the best we have until the DevTools design as a whole is thought over in detail.
Styling would be handled the same as buttons in most cases. As that is essentially what tabs are at the end of it all.

The specific problem in carrying this out with tabs though, is the close trigger. Those should be nested within the tab node, and buttons can't be nested in buttons. That's not nice. One solution to this though is borrowing from the linked tutorial. Have the list items, with anchors for the triggers and the close buttons as a button beside the anchor in the markup. This would allow for the anchor to be properly accessible and stylable, while allowing a button node to handle the close trigger which is what makes the most sense there. Win-Win on both sides. All the triggers are fully accessible and easily stylable.

<figure>

```html
<ul> <!-- Because tabs are lists -->
  <li>
    <a href>app-view.js</a><button>close</button>
  <li>
    <a href>app.js</a><button>close</button>
</ul>
```

<figcaption>
  Example markup structure for accessible tabs without all of the accessibility specific attributes.
</figcaption>

</figure>
Literally, just making these nodes `button` elements and fixing the main styling to be right resolves all of these issues. The styling of focus state can happen once button styling is figured out.

that's okay, because we haven't finished "add condition". Once that's in there will always be a conditional item
we can create a batch expressions wrapper like this:

```js
import { zipObject, zip } from "lodash";

export function wrapBatchExpressions(expressions) {
  const inputs = expressions.map(e => e.input);
  const wrappedExpressions = inputs.map(wrapExpression);
  return zipObject(inputs, wrappedExpressions);
}

  it("creates batch object", () => {
    console.log(wrapBatchExpressions([{ input: "foo" }, { input: 'foo"\\' }]));
  });
```


Hey, 
first contributer here.
I've had a go at this issue.

The mentioned `highlightLineRange` seems to do something different.
`selectSource` seems to be used to do the highlight effect.
![peek 2017-09-20 22-05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1525694/30665218-8e10edc8-9e50-11e7-97da-1f1180f7eec7.gif)

The [`selectSource`](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/f048741f3c194ff93aa67d573278ea8a38433ac5/src/actions/sources.js#L191) function can only highlight one line.


When you use the **copy Function** action, I would expect it to highlight the line with the function definition or the whole function. For both, *EditorMenu.js* does not have enough context.   
The [`findFunctionText`](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/37365ddd8d7bebadda096dd814a3a63eaaa8449c/src/utils/function.js#L19) has the necessary context but does not expose it.  

So maybe `findFunctionText` could be extended to return an object with the function text and all available context (firstLine, lastLine).

But I wanted some feedback before I go further.

This was fixed when we fixed #4106
#### should be keyboard navigable

* left and right arrow should change the focused tab
* space or enter should select a source
* tab/shift tab should jump to the command bar or source tree

We'll listen for arrows and space bar events and set the `ariaActiveDescendent` state

```diff
--- a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
@@ -325,6 +325,17 @@ class SourceTabs extends PureComponent {
     );
   }

+  onKeyDown() {
+    if (arrow) {
+      return this.setState({ariaActiveDescendent: tabIndes})
+    }
+
+    if (spaceBar) {
+      const source = getSource(tabIndex)
+      this.props.selectSource(source);
+    }
+  }
```

#### Style the tabs

We'll style the tabs w/ ariaActiveDescendent. This strategy will let us higlight the "active" tab when the tab list is in focus. 

```diff
   renderTabs() {
     const { sourceTabs } = this.props;
     if (!sourceTabs) {
@@ -332,7 +343,12 @@ class SourceTabs extends PureComponent {
     }

     return (
-      <div className="source-tabs" ref="sourceTabs">
+      <div
+        className="source-tabs"
+        ref="sourceTabs"
+        tabIndex="0"

        // wee'll need to figure out how to do this correctly. 
+        {/* ariaActiveDescendent="tab-1" */}
+      >
         {sourceTabs.map(this.renderSourceTab)}
       </div>
     );
@@ -404,6 +420,7 @@ class SourceTabs extends PureComponent {
       <div
         className={className}
         key={source.get("id")}
         // each tab now needs an id
+        id={`tab-1`}
```

@amitzur I tried to come up with a better example: [here](https://salty-dawn.glitch.me/). Unfortunately, this didn't show the scopes...

```js

function stuff() {

  const obj = {
    foo: function() {
      [1,2,3].forEach(function(item) {
        (function yay() {
          console.log("yo")
        })()
      })
    }
  }
  
  obj.foo();
  
}
```

Just a FYI for debugging perf, if you wrap the code that calls into codemirror with `performance.mark` and `performance.measure` it would show them in the marker view.
This is a duplicate of issue #3736, where you can find similar stacks in the profiler.
\o/ I'm so glad to see you use the profiler! Hopefully you will start a new trend in the team :-)

> CodeMirror is the big offender

I completely missed the impact of codemirror in the profile, good catch.
It looks like showMessage method is called a lot of times `showMessage(Loading…)` when you reload and have a source already selected. I think there is also unexpected number of `newSource` events coming from the actors. But the client should not be so slow by updating this "loading..." message, which is always identical. It looks like you can see all these calls to `showMessage(Loading…)` by filtering with "codemirror" in the profiler, you will see a bunch of spikes when reloading slack.

Are you able to push to try a given debugger PR? (to have talos/DAMP test)
(if yes, the try syntax to execute DAMP is this one `try: -b o -p linux64 -u none -t g2-e10s --rebuild-talos 6`)
I looked into the perf profile this weekend and found two issues, codemirror and the source tree. Here are three profiles:

1. [no debugger](https://perfht.ml/2xAckz9)
2. [debugger open w/o the editor](https://perfht.ml/2xA3VLT)
3. [debugger open](https://perfht.ml/2xAtRqG)



### CodeMirror is the big offender

The first 30 seconds is spent responding to two significant events: `newSource` and `loadSourceText`. 

* `newSource` is the long spikey period from 6s to 19s
* `loadSorceText` is the steady period from 19s to 23s.

![Screen Shot 2017-09-25 at 9.56.00 AM.png](https://shipusercontent.com/d2e204615f72844001905ea3a57a003e/Screen%20Shot%202017-09-25%20at%209.56.00%20AM.png)

If we were to disable the editor, then we'll see that the `newSource` events are handled much faster. It now takes 3s instead of 13s.

<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/2a240298642b3a690b7f08409891c591/Screen%20Shot%202017-09-25%20at%209.59.33%20AM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-09-25 at 9.59.33 AM.png' width=722>

### The source tree is slow


We can definitely speed up the tree if we do a couple small optimizations so we memoize parsed URLs and improve the Immutable Source Record perf. We can also ofcourse improve the tree data structure as well. 

### A GIF of slow codemirror methods

![](http://g.recordit.co/Kphfj3mnEc.gif)

Here is @ochameau's patch: 

> In the call tree, see the first line? i.e. exports.makeInfaillible expand this 4 or 5 times, you will see newSource from debugger.js

From this you could see that `SourcesTree.componentWillReceiveProps` is slow.
Mostly because of immutable.js. It see a 3x win if I replace it with a naive manual check.

See this patch (sorry, it is against the webpack bundle):
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/page.cgi?id=splinter.html&bug=1399242&attachment=8909337

Also, we call a url module helper too many times. We shoud avoid calling it especially in the hot codepaths. Note that we should be using web "URL" constructor instead of this.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/URL

```diff

--

When stepping in some code, the "step out" button allows to wait at the end of the current function, so that we can inspect the final state of the function's variables before actually stepping out. This is useful.

However we can't inspect the return value itself. This would be a very useful addition.

Note: this was possible in the old debugger so we should have the data already: 
![capture d ecran de 2017-09-18 15-50-59](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/454175/30545261-652c1400-9c89-11e7-9172-161e49336b38.png)


Tohm is working on small strings
dupe of #4183
There is an `isMinified` function which the old debugger uses as heuristics  to decide, we could use that ..
https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/devtools/client/debugger/utils.js#74
lets steal it:

```js
 function (key, text) {
    if (this._minifiedCache.has(key)) {
      return this._minifiedCache.get(key);
    }

    let isMinified;
    let lineEndIndex = 0;
    let lineStartIndex = 0;
    let lines = 0;
    let indentCount = 0;
    let overCharLimit = false;

    // Strip comments.
    text = text.replace(/\/\*[\S\s]*?\*\/|\/\/(.+|\n)/g, "");

    while (lines++ < SAMPLE_SIZE) {
      lineEndIndex = text.indexOf("\n", lineStartIndex);
      if (lineEndIndex == -1) {
        break;
      }
      if (/^\s+/.test(text.slice(lineStartIndex, lineEndIndex))) {
        indentCount++;
      }
      // For files with no indents but are not minified.
      if ((lineEndIndex - lineStartIndex) > CHARACTER_LIMIT) {
        overCharLimit = true;
        break;
      }
      lineStartIndex = lineEndIndex + 1;
    }

    isMinified =
      ((indentCount / lines) * 100) < INDENT_COUNT_THRESHOLD || overCharLimit;

    this._minifiedCache.set(key, isMinified);
    return isMinified;
  }
  ```

For the "?" found in https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/issues/3583#issuecomment-332556608, it turns out that that is what exactly the source map provides. Log the returned sources for search by `searchResult` in SourceSearch.js [1], could get the source item of "piskel-animated-preview.js?20170502"[2]. In fact, that filename is given by the website on purpose (seems that is timestamp) [3]. However, in the left source list, it seems stripping out the "?20170502" [4].

@jasonLaster 
For developers of that website, seeing "?20170502" in the search results or breakpoint probably would make more sense to them. As for the source list case, not really a problem, maybe acceptable (Chrome respects the website, displaying "?20170502" in all cases).
I would suggest this is not really an issue. How do you think?

[1] https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/b581b67336508b80a0af75eea8f2fc0503c84a4c/src/components/ProjectSearch/SourceSearch.js#L23

[2] { value: "/static/js/piskel-animated-preview.js?20170502", title: "piskel-animated-preview.js?20170502", subtitle: "/static/js/piskel-animated-preview.js?20170502", id: "server1.conn12.child2/source29" }

I think it should actually be styled like the Outline panel for consistency with the rest of the developer tools. We currently follow how the Accordion style messages when there is no content in them. We should simply do the same for these sidebar components in the debugger because that is also how we style empty sidebar panels in the Inspector.

Agreed, lets find a good UI for this. Chrome uses `ctrl+g` which is the standard shortcut. They also use their modal, which is a good pattern here. I think they had an alert box until recently :)

<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/b39405c0a8f5e50717844c634f1f0fe6/Screen%20Shot%202017-09-29%20at%209.32.22%20AM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-09-29 at 9.32.22 AM.png' width=978>

Another argument for using the modal is that when we do the editor UX we can implement our unified modal vision, where the prefix ":" triggers line mode, "@" triggers function mode, ...


![](http://g.recordit.co/YS2N80jkek.gif)


Here's a bug that discusses it: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1392869

Steps to reproduce:

Open the debugger pane in the developer tools, and load a page that asynchronously loads many scripts. This is common behavior when developing with requirejs and running unoptimized, since in this case, requirejs dynamically creates new script tags to load dependencies.

I have created a benchmark to demonstrate this issue:

https://github.com/jwmerrill/async-script-load-benchmark


Actual results:

Having the debugger pane open makes asynchronously loading additional scripts much slower. Note that the problem also appears if you have the dev tools open and you have ever visited the debugger panel. It does not need to be the currently active panel, you just need to have activated it at some point during your session.

In Firefox 57 (currently nightly), loading 1000 files in this tool takes 1 second with dev tools closed, and 11 seconds with dev tools open to the debugger pane. Loading 2000 files takes 2 seconds with dev tools closed, and 30 seconds with the debugger open. Loading 5000 files takes 6 seconds with dev tools closed, and 2.5 minutes with the debugger open. In all cases, the branching factor was set to 2.

The problem seems to be worse in Firefox 55 and Firefox 56.


Expected results:

Loading scripts with the debugger open should be fast, and the amount of time that it takes to load each new script should not increase with the number of scripts you have already loaded (the benchmark shows superlinear scaling with the number of scripts you attempt to load).

Chrome takes a similar amount of time to run the benchmark with dev tools closed, but opening dev tools only slows things down by 20-40% instead of a factor of 10 or more.

--------

1. When the debugger tab is open in Dev tools, the page doesn't reload at all, and the whole browser starts slowing down and doesn't even respond to clicking the close button. But, if I press F12, the Dev tools window does get closed and suddenly the whole browser starts running smoothly.
2. This behaviour doesn't happen if some other tab in Dev Tools is open, only with the Debugger tab.
3. Setting breakpoints in Dev Tools further slows down JS execution and starts hanging the browser.

Looks great! thanks
Here is another example: [profile](https://perfht.ml/2yw0hjS)

STR:
- Go to netflix.com
- Open devtools debugger
- Find script codex.nflxext.com -> 2.0.0/truthbundle -> akira -> common/bootstrap.js
- Ctrl+F to search source code
- Type 's' 't'

Expected: Able to find strings in source
Actual: After first letter, the browser hangs until a slow script dialog pops up.

I see a lot of time in JS, but we should make sure we aren't doing something silly in debugger too.

BONUS: When the slow-script dialog appears, pressing the debug button will break your browser by leaving you in a nested modal state. Everything reflows correctly, but can't interact with the UI at all.

I've tested this thuroughly and while there are other issues with the command bar being sticky, i think removing 100vw is a step in the right direction.
```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/sources-tree/createTree.js b/src/utils/sources-tree/createTree.js
index de18287..fd007f6 100644
--- a/src/utils/sources-tree/createTree.js
+++ b/src/utils/sources-tree/createTree.js
@@ -7,10 +7,25 @@ import { addToTree } from "./addToTree";

 import type { SourcesMap } from "../../reducers/types";

+function addSources(sources, uncollapsedTree) {
+  for (const source of sources) {
+    addToTree(uncollapsedTree, source);
+  }
+}
+
 export function createTree(sources: SourcesMap, debuggeeUrl: string) {
   const uncollapsedTree = createNode("root", "", []);
-  for (const source of sources.valueSeq()) {
-    addToTree(uncollapsedTree, source, debuggeeUrl);
+
+  const sourceList = sources.valueSeq();
+
+  if (huge) {
+    // 30K
+    // batches of 1000
+    sourceListPartitions.forEach(
+      requestIdleCallback(() => addSources(sources, uncollapsedTree))
+    );
+  } else {
+    addSources(sources, uncollapsedTree);
   }

   const sourceTree = sortEntireTree(collapseTree(uncollapsedTree), debuggeeUrl);
(END)

```
I measured performance of source tree with [3,000 files](https://yurydelendik.github.io/old-man-sandbox/create-30k/f3k.html) (10x less of the target), and found following pain points:

* addTree operation ~470ms
* tree sort ~160ms
* tree batch component update ~5900ms

I was able to reduce time to 30%, by:

1. Removing SVG {icon} and remove {arrow} when hidden (improvement)-> tree batch component update ~1430ms
2. Having an name index for nodes -> addTree operation ~205ms
3. Not parsing debuggee domain all the time -> tree sort ~5ms

See blueprint at https://gist.github.com/yurydelendik/0b10038753f4facf750f727a9db49844
>I was able to reduce time to 30%, by ... Removing SVG {icon}

If the debugger is putting zillions of copies of the same SVG content into the DOM for this use-case,  it's possible you'd get a benefit from replacing this duplicated SVG content with an `<img> (or` an element with "background-image") which points at some single local SVG helper file (or a resource:// URI or somesuch). That way, we'd only have to parse, store, and rasterize the SVG content once (in imagelib), and the duplicated part would be an `<img>` which is probably lighter-weight.
Yeah, looks like the "document" icon here is the following (whitespace tweaked for readability / to avoid overflow off the right side of this github comment):
````svg
<!-- This Source Code Form is subject to the terms of the Mozilla Public
   - License, v. 2.0. If a copy of the MPL was not distributed with this
   - file, You can obtain one at http://mozilla.org/MPL/2.0/. -->
<svg viewBox="0 0 16 16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
  <path d="M4 2v12h9V4.775L9.888 2H4zm0-1h5.888c.246 0
.483.09.666.254l3.112 2.774c.212.19.334.462.334.747V14c0 .552-.448
1-1 1H4c-.552 0-1-.448-1-1V2c0-.552.448-1 1-1z">
  </path>
  <path d="M9 1.5v4c0
.325.306.564.62.485l4-1c.27-.067.432-.338.365-.606-.067-.27-.338-.432-.606-.365l-4
1L10 5.5v-4c0-.276-.224-.5-.5-.5s-.5.224-.5.5z">
  </path>
</svg>
````

This seems to come from https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/0ab605e797178aac92e9fd5480b63844ca4be15b/assets/images/file.svg -- which is already represented as a standalone file in the repository here.  But it seems debugger.html is extracting its SVG DOM and directly appending that to the document for each entry in the source-list pane.

Anyway -- if we're running some operation that synchronously appends a zillion of these icons to the document (for a zillion JS source files), I'd bet we could get a speedup by appending a zillion `<img>` elements instead, all pointing to file.svg.

I think the `eval` is not needed. and actually quite scary

```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/expressions.js b/src/utils/expressions.js
index ec27dac..05e40e1 100644
--- a/src/utils/expressions.js
+++ b/src/utils/expressions.js
@@ -14,13 +14,13 @@ export function sanitizeInput(input: string) {
  * NOTE: we add line after the expression to protect against comments.
 */
 export function wrapExpression(input: string) {
-  return `eval(\`
+  return `
     try {
       ${sanitizeInput(input)}
     } catch (e) {
       e
     }
-  \`)`.trim();
+  `.trim();
 }
```

Hi, wonder if I can get some help or pointers?
I've yarn linked debugger and devtools-linter together. Should I install 'retext-equality' in debugger.html or devtools-linter? I haven't used yarn link before so I'm not sure what the next steps are



Sure! I was in the same place last week.

1. 'retext-equality' should be installed into the devtools-linter project
2. After that install completes, cd into the debugger.html folder, and run `yarn link devtools-linters` to make sure the devtools-linter is linked and then
3. run `yarn lint-md` If all is good, this will run through all of the debugger files, look for errors, and print to the console

Hope that helps :)

I wonder why that isn't the default for SVG icon use, like here on Github. Regardless for devtools it seems to be the best solution though.
I am not sure we should really strip off the strings behind "?". The string behind "?" is query string which is also a part of URL. Theoretically we could have "account.js?student" and "account.js?teacher", which have different content. Another thing about this is that if I put a timestamp behind my script filename for some purpose, I would feel a bit uncertain when debugging without seeing the timestamp.

p.s looks like there are some people appending query string to js files for some reason: [1][2]
[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41487313/create-script-tag-with-query-string
[2] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4716612/how-do-i-get-query-string-value-from-script-path

We're landing this first
Hi there! The reason this is behaving strangely is because we are dealing with a flex item, not a regular div. By making it a table, you are overriding it's flexbox item status which can lead to problems. There are also some other inconsistencies with how flexbox is being used, which is what is leading to the original issue of this being full height and strangely positioned, and `fit-content` not working in firefox. The issue in the end is not `fit-content`, but flexbox inconsistencies between browsers. Here is an example of how we can solve this:

```diff
diff --git a/src/components/shared/Modal.css b/src/components/shared/Modal.css
index 35761cf1..b1f9d336 100644
--- a/src/components/shared/Modal.css
+++ b/src/components/shared/Modal.css
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 .modal-wrapper {
   position: fixed;
   display: flex;
-  justify-content: center;
+  align-items: center;
   width: 100%;
   height: 100%;
   top: 0;
@@ -12,7 +12,7 @@

 .modal {
   top: 0;
-  height: 230px;
+  margin: auto;
   width: 500px;
   background-color: var(--theme-codemirror-gutter-background);
   transform: translateY(-250px);
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@

 .modal.entered,
 .modal.exiting {
-  transform: translateY(30px);
+  transform: translateY(0px);
 }

 @media (max-width: 520px) {
```

it looks like there are some problems how the DOM is organized. We are using flex box where it isnt necessary and the shortcut lists are all width 40% without being displayed side by side. Also, the modals are overwriting themselves, which will lead to problems later on. I am wondering if we should make an issue to clean this up?

Here is a quick sketch of how we can extend our await stepping to also support yields.

```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/parser/steps.js b/src/utils/parser/steps.js
index 29af7f4..335531f 100644
--- a/src/utils/parser/steps.js
+++ b/src/utils/parser/steps.js
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ import { isAwaitExpression } from "./utils/helpers";
 import type { NodePath } from "babel-traverse";

 export function getNextStep(source: Source, pausedPosition: AstPosition) {
-  const awaitExpression = getAwaitExpression(source, pausedPosition);
+  const awaitExpression = getAsyncExpression(source, pausedPosition);
   if (!awaitExpression) {
     return null;
   }
@@ -13,18 +13,18 @@ export function getNextStep(source: Source, pausedPosition: AstPosition) {
   return getLocationAfterAwaitExpression(awaitStatement, pausedPosition);
 }

-function getAwaitExpression(source: Source, pausedPosition: AstPosition) {
+function getAsyncExpression(source: Source, pausedPosition: AstPosition) {
   const closestPath = getClosestPath(source, pausedPosition);

   if (!closestPath) {
     return null;
   }

-  if (isAwaitExpression(closestPath)) {
+  if (isAwaitExpression(closestPath) || isYieldExpression(closestPath)) {
     return closestPath;
   }

-  return closestPath.find(p => p.isAwaitExpression());
+  return closestPath.find(p => p.isAwaitExpression() || p.isYieldExpression());
 }
```

```diff

-      ...pausePosition,

+        ...pausePosition,
+        line: 9,
+        column: 2
+      });
     });
-  });

-  it("second await call", () => {
-    const source = getSource("async");
-    const pausePosition = { line: 9, column: 2, sourceId: "async" };
-    expect(getNextStep(source, pausePosition)).toEqual(null);
+    it("second await call", () => {
+      const source = getSource("async");
+      const pausePosition = { line: 9, column: 2, sourceId: "async" };
+      expect(getNextStep(source, pausePosition)).toEqual(null);
+    });
+
+    it("second call expression", () => {
+      const source = getSource("async");
+      const pausePosition = { line: 9, column: 9, sourceId: "async" };
+      expect(getNextStep(source, pausePosition)).toEqual(null);
-  it("second call expression", () => {
-    const source = getSource("async");
-    const pausePosition = { line: 9, column: 9, sourceId: "async" };
-    expect(getNextStep(source, pausePosition)).toEqual(null);
+  describe("yield", () => {
+    // perhaps the same tests here...
   });
 });
```

```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/parser/utils/helpers.js b/src/utils/parser/utils/helpers.js
index 03e8982..6e4f860 100644
--- a/src/utils/parser/utils/helpers.js
+++ b/src/utils/parser/utils/helpers.js
@@ -24,6 +24,14 @@ export function isAwaitExpression(path: NodePath) {
   );
 }

+export function isYieldExpression(path: NodePath) {
+  return (
+    t.isYieldExpression(path) ||
+    t.isYieldExpression(path.container.init) ||
+    t.isYieldExpression(path.parentPath)
+  );
+}
+
```

I just looked into it and I think the problem that we can solve is that it is not clear that we are pretty printing. I think the best thing to do is to optimistically create the pretty printed source w/ the loading field set to true.

This way, we can immediately show the pretty printed source and when the text comes in we can show it. Here is a [gist][g], that shows how we can do that.

[g]:https://gist.github.com/jasonLaster/302812e14dbaf3c8ef053210df38d091
I prefer that suggestion @codehag! For reference that `dom.div` stuff looks like this in JSX @James300 

```jsx
<div className="secondary-panes-wrapper">
  <CommandBar />
  <div className="secondary-panes">
    {this.props.horizontal === true && this.renderHorizontalLayout()}
    {this.props.horizontal !== true && this.renderVerticalLayout()}
  </div>
</div>

```diff
diff --git a/src/components/Editor/DebugLine.js b/src/components/Editor/DebugLine.js
index f92c616..7eab45f 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/DebugLine.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/DebugLine.js
@@ -17,6 +17,8 @@ export default class DebugLine extends Component {
     }
   };

+  debugExpression: Object;
+
   constructor() {
     super();
     this.state = { debugExpression: { clear: () => {} } };
@@ -57,19 +59,19 @@ export default class DebugLine extends Component {
     }

     doc.addLineClass(line, "line", "new-debug-line");
-    const debugExpression = markText(editor, "debug-expression", {
-      start: { line, column },
-      end: { line, column: null }
-    });
-    this.setState({ debugExpression });
+    // const debugExpression = markText(editor, "debug-expression", {
+    //   start: { line, column },
+    //   end: { line, column: null }
+    // });

   }

   clearDebugLine(selectedFrame: Object, editor: Object) {
     const { line, sourceId } = selectedFrame.location;
-    const { debugExpression } = this.state;
-    if (debugExpression) {
-      debugExpression.clear();
-    }
+    // const { debugExpression } = this;

+    //   debugExpression.clear();
+    // }

     const editorLine = line - 1;
     const doc = getDocument(sourceId);
```

Hi, we tried debugging this today at ReactNYC:

We initially thought the issue was about clicking and unclicking the debug gutter line, but Jason clarified in person that the problem is actually the time it takes to arrive in the editor context relevant to a breakpoint. We were not able to replicate the long delay in a reasonable-sized react app but clarifying the issue here for future people tackling this

if i got this right, we should merge webpack scripts in with the main domain?
> The inconsistent behavior is that webpacked source are show in their own Webpack domain while rollupjs shows source mapped files correctly in the current domain (tested on rollupjs.org).

FWIW this happens because webpack generally puts all the source text into the source map, and then it uses `webpack://` URLs there.  So it's an explicit decision by webpack.

If you want to just display the webpack URLs somewhere associated with the corresponding generated source, then that's up to the debugger display (I don't know anything about that).  But if you want to change the displayed URL; first, you have to take care not to introduce clashes, which would be confusing in a different way; and second, you'd probably want to do it in devtools-source-map, because that way the console will continue to agree with the debugger about the names of sources (this is important so that clicking the links works).
@codehag lets see what our perf is like after the source tree work lands.

@jasonLaster  
Just thought I should make a note about this: I've been checking out the conversion to flow types issue in this project. Some components listed in that issue use the `Context` API for the `shortcuts` component. I've done some research into it - and it seems like a runtime type library is required to convert from `contextTypes` to flow types: https://github.com/codemix/flow-runtime. I think its something that should be noted in the issue when people make PRs that use that component.

Thanks @satiewaltz, I'd be open to using `flow-runtime` as well. Thanks for the update. Also, it's okay not to type context :) we use it very sparingly.

@codehag left this comment:

I see two issues here:

ensureParserText is potentially.. doing a lot of things, and it is being used a lot. if a loadSource is in flight (for example, someone forgets an await somewhere), we may be retriggering it here, with no way of cancelling the original and as a result -- doubling the work.

second issue: "ensure" doesn't tell us that it is going to load the source text and then set the parser, so unless everyone who uses this function checks the definition, they will not see that it is not checking for a source (ensure suggests that "lets check if it is there, if not throw an error", similar to assert).

I think this needs to be renamed / possibly removed and the core problem addressed instead (better state management) -- what do you think?

Thanks for filing @darkwing, i see this as part of the larger Breakpoints pane UX work we can do this quarter. I definitely agree we should show users the line the breakpoint is on.

In the past we've talked about grouping breakpoints by file as well. This might be a good time to bring this conversation back.


<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/dbf673127a6bb6ba8b58fb578a1f533f/Screen%20Shot%202017-10-08%20at%2011.03.04%20AM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-10-08 at 11.03.04 AM.png' width=521>

With that said, we probably shouldn't block showing breakpoint lines on a decision over grouping by file. We should probably go ahead and land breakpoint lines first regardless as there is a decent amount of technical work there too.

here is a gist to help get the ball rolling:

```diff
diff --git a/src/actions/breakpoints/addBreakpoint.js b/src/actions/breakpoints/addBreakpoint.js
index 2dfbb5c..5e19e30 100644
--- a/src/actions/breakpoints/addBreakpoint.js
+++ b/src/actions/breakpoints/addBreakpoint.js
@@ -7,6 +7,7 @@ import {
 } from "../../utils/breakpoint";
 import { getSource } from "../../selectors";
 import { getGeneratedLocation } from "../../utils/source-maps";
+import { getSourceLine } from "../../utils/source";
 
 export default async function addBreakpoint(
   getState,
@@ -26,6 +27,8 @@ export default async function addBreakpoint(
     sourceMaps
   );
 
+  const lineText = getSourceLine(source, location);
+
   assertLocation(location);
   assertLocation(generatedLocation);
 
@@ -57,7 +60,8 @@ export default async function addBreakpoint(
     location: newLocation,
     astLocation,
     hitCount,
-    generatedLocation: newGeneratedLocation
+    generatedLocation: newGeneratedLocation,
+    text: lineText
   };
 
   assertBreakpoint(newBreakpoint);
diff --git a/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js b/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js
index b00fc77..d1475ed 100644
--- a/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js
+++ b/src/actions/breakpoints/syncBreakpoint.js
@@ -33,6 +33,9 @@ function createSyncData(
   const overrides = { ...pendingBreakpoint, generatedLocation };
   const breakpoint = createBreakpoint(location, overrides);
 
+  // we'll have to pass source in here
+  const lineText = getSourceLine(source, scopedLocation);
+
   assertBreakpoint(breakpoint);
   return { breakpoint, previousLocation };
 }
diff --git a/src/utils/source.js b/src/utils/source.js
index 97ee400..689b431 100644
--- a/src/utils/source.js
+++ b/src/utils/source.js
@@ -246,6 +246,10 @@ function isLoaded(source: Source) {
   return source.loadedState === "loaded";
 }
 
+function getSourceLine(source, location) {
+  return source.text.split("\n")[location.line - 1];
+}
+
 export {
   isJavaScript,
   isPretty,
```

@amelzer  Note: `CommandBar`'s `contextTypes` can only be switched out if a runtime type library is used like `flow-runtime` as noted earlier from when I was looking at it. Fortunately, only several components have `contextTypes` defined in them: it's all places that inherits context from the shortcuts component. 

Maybe that component can be marked done unless there's an alternative way to convert it that I've missed?

Quick comment: 
Was not able to get debugger.html running locally due to an issue with my `~/.babel` file. Although I did not know that this file was the root of the problem, `yarn install` and `yarn run` were giving me command prompt error messages. **Discovered the issue was the** `~/.bable` **file being hidden**. Once I unchecked the 'hidden' checkbox, everything worked. After a `yarn install` and `yarn start`, I could even re-hide the file and it would still work. 

Windows 10
node: v6.11.4
yarn: 1.2.0
error: `Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, open 'C:\Users\<username>\.babel.json'`



we should also mention:

* global NPM caches
* webpack loading 
* installed firefox plugins

A debugger / console test is pretty straight forward

```js
add_task(async function() {
  Services.prefs.setBoolPref("devtools.toolbox.splitconsoleEnabled", true);
  const dbg = await initDebugger("doc-script-switching.html");

  await selectSource(dbg, "switching-01");

  // open the console
  await getSplitConsole(dbg);
  ok(dbg.toolbox.splitConsole, "Split console is shown.");

  // close the console
  await clickElement(dbg, "codeMirror");
  // First time to focus out of text area
  pressKey(dbg, "Escape");

  // Second time to hide console
  pressKey(dbg, "Escape");
  ok(!dbg.toolbox.splitConsole, "Split console is hidden.");
});

```

And the helper function does not do anything too magical


```js
function getSplitConsole(dbg) {
  const { toolbox, win } = dbg;

  registerCleanupFunction(() => {
    Services.prefs.clearUserPref("devtools.toolbox.splitconsoleEnabled");
  });

  if (!win) {
    win = toolbox.win;
  }

  if (!toolbox.splitConsole) {
    pressKey(dbg, "Escape");
  }

  return new Promise(resolve => {
    toolbox.getPanelWhenReady("webconsole").then(() => {
      ok(toolbox.splitConsole, "Split console is shown.");
      let jsterm = toolbox.getPanel("webconsole").hud.jsterm;
      resolve(jsterm);
    });
  });
}
```

The stack trace when using the bundle is:

```
console.error: 
  Message: TypeError: Parameter 'url' must be a string, not undefined
  Stack:
    Url.prototype.parse@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/client/debugger/new/debugger.js:21007:11
urlParse@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/client/debugger/new/debugger.js:21001:3
getDomain@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/client/debugger/new/debugger.js:46629:17
addToTree@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/client/debugger/new/debugger.js:1654:23
createTree@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/client/debugger/new/debugger.js:19107:6
SourcesTree@resource://devtools/shared/base-loader.js -> resource://devtools/client/debugger/new/debugger.js:42067:19
```

The issue seems to come from this call to parse():
https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/9238da74bd85bcb8960f1bf6bc65cd8db642342f/src/utils/sources-tree/treeOrder.js#L13

which will throw if url is undefined. Not exactly sure why, but this is the case when using the Browser Content Toolbox. We should probably try/catch around that.

### Gist for Pretty Print / Blackbox

```diff
diff --git a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css
index 4d85385..4738b13 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css
+++ b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.css
@@ -71,7 +71,15 @@
   line-height: 0;
 }

-.source-tab .prettyPrint svg {
+.source-tab img.prettyPrint {
+  mask: url(/images/prettyPrint.svg);
+}
+.source-tab img.blackBox {
+  mask: url(/images/prettyPrint.svg);
+}
+
+.source-tab img.prettyPrint,
+.source-tab img.blackBox {
   height: 12px;
   width: 12px;
 }
@@ -86,11 +94,6 @@
   align-self: center;
 }

-  height: 12px;

-}

   fill: var(--theme-textbox-box-shadow);

 diff --git a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
index d78d4e7..026fcf4 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/Tabs.js
@@ -482,10 +482,10 @@ class SourceTabs extends PureComponent {
     const sourceObj = source.toJS();

     if (isPretty(sourceObj)) {
-      return <Svg name="prettyPrint" />;
+      return <img className="prettyPrint" />;
     }
     if (sourceObj.isBlackBoxed) {
-      return <Svg name="blackBox" />;
+      return <img className="blackBox" />;
     }
   }

[slack]:https://devtools-html-slack.herokuapp.com
[dev]:https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/docs/local-development.md
[contributing]:https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

@codehag Not every dep in our package.json is pinned to an exact version. 
Deleting yarn.lock and running install afterwards may result in installed versions of dependencies that may have breaking changes.
Unfortunately not every author respects SemVer and sometimes a fix for a lib can result in a breaking change if the consumer has already implemented a workaround or relies on that behavior.

I see two possible fixes:

1. Stop swiping the yarn.lock file on `nom`
2. Pin every dep to an exact version
/claim

aight, now we solve the tree: this test can be run with `jest --watch src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js`

```diff
diff --git a/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js b/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js
index 851410d..38aabf3 100644
--- a/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js
+++ b/src/utils/sources-tree/tests/addToTree.spec.js
@@ -225,5 +225,46 @@ describe("sources-tree", () => {
       sources.forEach(source => addToTree(tree, source, domain));
       expect(formatTree(tree)).toMatchSnapshot();
     });
+
+    it("uses projectRoot to filter the list", () => {
+      const testData = [
+        {
+          url: "components/TodoTextInput.js"
+        },
+        {
+          url: "components/Header.js"
+        },
+        {
+          url: "reducers/index.js"
+        },
+        {
+          url: "components/TodoItem.js"
+        },
+        {
+          url: "resource://gre/modules/ExtensionContent.jsm"
+        },
+        {
+          url:
+            "https://voz37vlg5.codesandbox.io/static/js/components/TodoItem.js"
+        },
+        {
+          url: "index.js"
+        }
+      ];
+
+      const domain = "http://localhost:4242";
+      const sources = createSourcesList(testData);
+      const root = "components";
+      const tree = createNode("root", "", []);
+      sources.forEach(source => addToTree(tree, source, domain, root));
+
+      /*
+          - components
+            - TodoTextInput.js
+            - Header.js
+      */
+      console.log(formatTree(tree))
+      expect(formatTree(tree)).toMatchSnapshot();
+    });
   });
 });
```

This should just be adding "devtools-button" as the class. This class can be found in common.css

Is it a matter of changing `const` lo `let` on line 241 of SourcesTree.js?
@jasonLaster Do you want to take a second look here?
This looks good to me, thanks @lukaszsobek & @flodolo !
since the record is immutable, the state saved on like 241 becomes stale, so changing it to let or const will not make a difference. The contents are set in addToTree, I suspect that what we need is a getter function rather than storing the state when the file is initially loaded. what do you think @jasonLaster? 

maybe something like this:

```javascript
// line 122 in addToTree.js
if (childNode) {
  const existingNode = node.contents[childIndex];
  const sourceId = source.get("id");
  existingNode.contents = { 
    getSource: () => getSource(sourceId), // in case we need the full source (probably not often)
    getSourceProperty: (prop) => getSource(sourceId).get(prop) // short hand so we dont have to write everything out
  };
}

// all future instances such as in SourcesTree.js will need to updated like so
const source = item.contents.getSourceProperty("url");
```

@codehag that could work. I was thinking we could also just keep the source path and url in contents and get the source at render time... the advantage of this approach is then our tree becomes agnostic to what is stored in it... it doesn't have to be a source just an object w/ path and ID. 

but i'm good w/ anything here


Thanks!

removing from our milestone as Sam, from ucosp can work on it
Feels like this can be automated with GitHub's API.
Also, notice it's "good first issue", not bug.

I agree that no newcomer is interested in the difference between difficulty medium and hard. If it also doesn't interest the veterans I'd remove it.

> As a follow up or on this, should we generally convert the label scheme to Camel Case Text (like Code Health ;) )?

well, according to https://help.github.com/articles/about-labels/ they use only lowercase in labels.
is this the same work as #4350 ?
A profile of the hanging (reproduced on this issue page, resulting in a [crash](https://crash-stats.mozilla.com/report/index/06ab93ff-033f-45b6-8535-0bf170171016) 😈, not the debuggers fault): https://perfht.ml/2kUbUix

- time spend in `findBestMatch`
- Overhead of protocol messages being passed
- Significant GC (not sure who to blame, protocol or `findBestMatch`)

Brainstorming a bit on a better heuristic, splitting the match finding and data requesting:

- Show yellow highlight ASAP (could a light version even use CSS?)
- Debounce the tooltip by 100ms (to be tested)
> is this the same work as #4350 ?

Yes, #4350 will help with this issue a lot.
> well, according to https://help.github.com/articles/about-labels/ they use only lowercase in labels.

Good catch (I also prefer find them more readable).

I am torn on how to manage well specified issues for the more advanced community vs marking things available for "beginners". We don't have too many bugs that are `available` and `medium/hard`; and the ones that are are not really well specified. `/claim` seems to solve these cases, to track assigning & progress. So maybe `good first bug` is all we need to replace `available`.
/claim

## Version **0.0.106** just got published. 
[Update to this version instead 🚀](https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/compare/greenkeeper%2Fdevtools-launchpad-0.0.106?expand=1) 

Tried to investigate this a little bit, it seems like we don't even get any of those from the server
Odd, traversing results doesn't seem to work because the sources tree is stealing focus. 🤔 
Looks like one of the integration tests broke, I didn't think my work would have an effect on anything that covers yet so I didn't run the mochi test locally. I'll fix that tonight.
The new test passed successfully on travis.
I think this is probably the problem where `sourceURL` doesn't really work correctly for inline `<script>`.  It's part of the last remaining "big" source map bug.  One approach to fixing it is described in the [source map status document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/19TKnMJD3CMBzwByNE4aBBVWnl-AEan8Sf4hxi6J-eps/edit#heading=h.lyqktbjlcoi6) -- there is at least one outright bug (see [this comment](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1192882#c3)), but I think there are also some debugger server changes that would have to happen.

Moving the `ensureText` #4413

@lukaszsobek 
```diff
diff --git a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
index a065aff..c6c5681 100644
--- a/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
+++ b/src/components/SecondaryPanes/Breakpoints.js
@@ -270,7 +270,7 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
       accesskey: addConditionKey,
       click: () => {
         this.selectBreakpoint(breakpoint);
-        toggleConditionalBreakpointPanel(breakpoint.location.line);
+        this.toggleConditionalBreakpointPanel(breakpoint.location.line);
       }
     };
 
@@ -280,7 +280,7 @@ class Breakpoints extends PureComponent {
       accesskey: editConditionKey,
       click: () => {
         this.selectBreakpoint(breakpoint);
-        toggleConditionalBreakpointPanel(breakpoint.location.line);
+        this.toggleConditionalBreakpointPanel(breakpoint.location.line);
       }
     };
 
```

Resources for implementing `GoToAnythingModal`

* http://docs.sublimetext.info/en/latest/file_management/file_navigation.html#goto-anything
* http://flight-manual.atom.io/using-atom/sections/moving-in-atom/

Overview.

* `@` prefix does symbol search
* `#` does term search
* `:<line>:<column` goes to line in current file
* *maybe* `model:30:20` first search for a file whose path matches models, and then to go to line 30 in said file.

Just looked into it again and I think it's an issue with how the source url is represented in the server:

take a look at this [example](https://bad-eval.glitch.me/)

```js
function stuff() {
  console.log("why, hello there!")
  var script = "if(true) {\nundefined()\n}";
  eval(script);
}
```

The log URL is fine, but the eval is not. Notice `%20`... 

<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/7bb0e1822c91dd07e6f275669d58a364/Screen%20Shot%202017-10-17%20at%206.49.59%20PM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-10-17 at 6.49.59 PM.png' width=426>

moving to bugzilla so it can be tracked by the console component:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1409571

Okay... I investigated a bit and found that common.css is loaded but found that the css doesnt hit

```css
:root.html [platform="mac"] {
  --monospace-font-family: Menlo, monospace;
}

:root.html [platform="win"] {
  --monospace-font-family: Consolas, monospace;
}
```

I think we'll want to do something in the launchpad to add this property to the root:

```diff
diff --git a/packages/devtools-launchpad/src/index.js b/packages/devtools-launchpad/src/index.js
index 26e87ed..fb94e54 100644
--- a/packages/devtools-launchpad/src/index.js
+++ b/packages/devtools-launchpad/src/index.js
@@ -45,6 +45,16 @@ function updateTheme(className) {
   }
 }

+function updatePlatform(className) {
+  if (process.env.TARGET !== "firefox-panel") {
+    const root = document.body.parentNode;
+    const appRoot = document.querySelector(".launchpad-root");
+
+    root.platform = // useragent rubbage;
+    appRoot.platform = // useragent stuff
+  }
+}
+
 function updateDir() {
   const dir = getValue("dir");
   const root = document.body.parentNode;
@@ -103,6 +113,7 @@ function renderRoot(_React, _ReactDOM, component, _store, props) {
   if (isDevelopment()) {
     updateConfig();
     updateTheme(className);
+    updatePlatform();
   }

```

Here's a quick summary of how to pick up this work:

1. re-add the mochitest which exercised this behavior: #4188. You should be able to re-run the test [docs][d] and see the test fail

2. reproduce the bug locally by going to the test [example][e] and pausing in `returnSomething`. See the screenshots from the launchpad and nightly below

3. observe the pause data in the pause [reducer][p] and how it is used in the scopes [util][s]. Hint, the client HAS the correct data on step out.

NOTE: there is a weird double step when stepping out that is distracting... and is in a server-side bug :)

Yes, thank you, fixed by #4378 
An interesting thing is that flow-upgrade doesn't seem to be able to actually change anything:

```
Running 3 codemods...

Processing 139 files...
Spawning 3 workers...
Sending 47 files to free worker...
Sending 47 files to free worker...
Sending 45 files to free worker...
All done.
Results:
0 errors
62 unmodified
0 skipped
0 ok
Time elapsed: 42.583seconds
✨  Done in 137.17s.
```

Doing the upgrade by hand is partially done, but was hoping that the codemods could make it a bit easier.
It shows the memory use of the debugger when loaded onto http://aws-sensorweb-static-site.s3-website-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/ (precisely speaking: main.js)

**Total** shows the total memory used per opening of the editor tab, from that we subtract the browser **objects** which gives us the **memory debugger used**. The additional column marked **increase** shows how much more memory was used as compared to the previous opening and closing of the tab. 

Testing each section (old, new, new) was preceded by a ctrl+f5 reload + a test of the debugger without having loaded the main.js into the editor.
Each Section was tested 5 times - opening the tab - taking a memory snapshot of the heap - closing tab. the results are noted in rows.

Old - is the version before removing the listeners on unmount. New - are two versions of changes with implemented listener removal. There seems to be insignificant difference between the two new versions, but it was worth testing to see if there was one.

The interesting thing seems to be that on the second loading of the tab the memory footprint is higher than on the first one, but then it suddenly drops on the consecutive loads.

Conclusion:
While the change removed about 200kb overhead per opening of an editor tab there seems to be something much more serious going on between when the tab is opened for the first time (row: first load) and the second time (row: 2nd load). The memory footprint more than doubles - which means that we somehow create 26 additional megabytes of memory content that persists while the debugger is loaded ONLY when we open an editor tab for the second time.
heh - yeah... weird

Hey! I just took a look and it seems like you pulled in my previous PR pretty literally...

So, this is a tempting thing to do... but I actually think it gets you in more trouble than it's worth:

1. the changes are out of date
2. the PR has tons of stuff that's not really needed
3. the PR is big and hard to understand... really hard
4. it's not clear what to do (obviously)

Here's what I recommend.

1. start on a new up to date branch
2. add a dropdown to the the breakpoints header (look at the PR to see how i did it). Maybe make a small PR for customizing the dropdown button :) Maybe make a small PR that adds this dropdown behind a feature [flag][f]
3. add one action to the dropdown (perhaps pause on exceptions)... make sure that works. Add all the other actions...
4. start removing the buttons from the command bar
5. profit

<img src='https://shipusercontent.com/6785b7e0e67a3010eb6867077a67a5b9/Screen%20Shot%202017-10-18%20at%206.54.44%20PM.png' title='Screen Shot 2017-10-18 at 6.54.44 PM.png' width=1230>

[f]: https://github.com/devtools-html/debugger.html/blob/master/docs/local-development.md#creating-a-new-feature-flag
For `SearchBar` this patch should do.

```patch
diff --git a/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js b/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
index e7b513af..f0ae28c2 100644
--- a/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
+++ b/src/components/Editor/SearchBar.js
@@ -204,7 +204,7 @@ class SearchBar extends Component {
     return this.doSearch(e.target.value);
   };

-  onKeyUp = (e: SyntheticKeyboardEvent) => {
+  onKeyDown = (e: SyntheticKeyboardEvent) => {
     if (e.key !== "Enter" && e.key !== "F3") {
       return;
     }
@@ -305,7 +305,7 @@ class SearchBar extends Component {
           placeholder={L10N.getStr("sourceSearch.search.placeholder")}
           summaryMsg={this.buildSummaryMsg()}
           onChange={this.onChange}
-          onKeyUp={this.onKeyUp}
+          onKeyDown={this.onKeyDown}
           handleNext={e => this.traverseResults(e, false)}
           handlePrev={e => this.traverseResults(e, true)}
           handleClose={this.closeSearch}
```

Hi @svitlana-galianova!
